Chapter 1 Probability basics

1.1 Probability spaces and a bit of measure theory

Underlying any probabilistic model is a probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™), where

  • â€¢

    Î© is the sample space that contains all possible outcomes Ï‰, called elementary events;

  • â€¢

    the event space â„±âŠ‚2Î© is a collection of subsets of the sample space that we wish to assign a probability to. A set Aâˆˆâ„± is called event;

  • â€¢

    â„™ is a probability measure that assigns to each event Aâˆˆâ„± a probability â„™â¢(A)âˆˆ[0,1].

Example 1.1.1.

Consider the experiment of throwing a fair coin twice. We model Î©={Hâ¢H,Hâ¢T,Tâ¢H,Tâ¢T}={Ï‰i:i=1,â€¦,4} and

â„±=2Î©={ âˆ…,Î©,{Hâ¢H},{Hâ¢T},{Tâ¢H},{Tâ¢T},{Hâ¢H,Hâ¢T},{Hâ¢H,Tâ¢H},{Hâ¢H,Tâ¢T},{Hâ¢T,Tâ¢H},{Hâ¢T,Tâ¢T},
{TH,TT},{HH,HT,TH},{HH,HT,TT},{HH,TH,TT},{HT,TH,TT}}

Since the coin is fair, each of the 4 elementary events {Hâ¢H},{Hâ¢T},{Tâ¢H},{Tâ¢T} has the same probability, which is given by 1/4, i.e., â„™â¢({Ï‰})=1/4 for all Ï‰âˆˆÎ©. The probability that one of the distinct outcomes Hâ¢T and Tâ¢H happens is intuitively obtained by summing up the probabilities, i.e., â„™â¢({Hâ¢T,Tâ¢H})=â„™â¢({Hâ¢T})+â„™â¢({Tâ¢H})=1/4+1/4=1/2. More generally, for CâŠ‚{1,â€¦,n}, we may set

â„™â¢({Ï‰i:iâˆˆC})=â„™â¢(â‹ƒiâˆˆC{Ï‰i})=âˆ‘iâˆˆCâ„™â¢({Ï‰i})=|C|/4.

Note however that with this definition, probabilities of unions of events (translates to â€œat least one of the events happensâ€) are not always obtained by summing up:

â„™â¢({Hâ¢T}âˆª{Hâ¢T,Tâ¢H})=â„™â¢({Hâ¢T,Tâ¢H})=1/2â‰ 3/4=â„™â¢({Hâ¢T})+â„™â¢({Hâ¢T,Tâ¢H}).

The reason here: the events are not disjoint! With the above model we can for example identify â€œheads appears in first throwâ€ with the event {Hâ¢H,Hâ¢T}, which has probability 1/2, or â€œheads appears at least onceâ€ with the event {Hâ¢T,Tâ¢H,Hâ¢H}, which has probability 3/4. A reformulation of this would be â€œtails does not appear twiceâ€ and the probability can be expressed as

3/4=1âˆ’1/4=1âˆ’â„™â¢(â€œtails appears twiceâ€)=1âˆ’â„™â¢({Tâ¢T})=1âˆ’â„™â¢(Î©âˆ–{Hâ¢T,Tâ¢H,Hâ¢H}).

To make these notions mathematically rigorous, we introduce some fundamental concepts from measure theory, where one builds a consistent theory of assigning volumes to sets on general spaces. First we deal with the types of event spaces that we allow for a probability space.

Definition 1.1.2.

â„±âŠ‚2Î© is called a Ïƒ-algebra if all of the following are satisfied:

  1. (i)

    Î©âˆˆâ„±

  2. (ii)

    Aâˆˆâ„±âŸ¹Acâ‰”Î©âˆ–Aâˆˆâ„±

  3. (iii)

    (An)nâˆˆâ„•âŠ‚â„±âŸ¹â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•Anâˆˆâ„±

If â„± is a Ïƒ-algebra over Î©, we call (Î©,â„±) a measurable space.

Lemma 1.1.3.

Any Ïƒ-algebra â„± has the following properties:

  1. (i)

    âˆ…âˆˆâ„±

  2. (ii)

    A,Bâˆˆâ„±âŸ¹AâˆªBâˆˆâ„±

  3. (iii)

    A,Bâˆˆâ„±âŸ¹Aâˆ©Bâˆˆâ„±

  4. (iv)

    (An)nâˆˆâ„•âŠ‚â„±âŸ¹â‹‚nâˆˆâ„•Anâˆˆâ„±

  5. (v)

    A,Bâˆˆâ„±âŸ¹Aâˆ–Bâˆˆâ„±

Proof.

Exercise. âˆ

Example 1.1.4.

The simplest examples of Ïƒ-algebras are the trivial Ïƒ-algebra â„±={âˆ…,Î©} and the power set â„±=2Î© (sometimes called discrete Ïƒ-algebra).

For uncountable spaces Î©, the power set 2Î© is usually a poor choice because it is simply too big in the sense that we cannot design meaningful measures that consistently assign volumes to all subsets of Î© (look up the Banachâ€“Tarski paradox if you are interested why). Instead, we usually start with a nice family of subsets â„° of Î© and works with the smallest Ïƒ-algebra that contains â„°.

Definition 1.1.5.

Let â„° be a family of subsets of Î©. Then Ïƒâ¢(â„°) is defined as the smallest Ïƒ-algebra over Î© that contains â„°, or equivalently,

Ïƒâ¢(â„°)â‰”â‹‚â„±âˆˆğ’œâ„±,

where ğ’œ={â„±âŠ‚2Î©:â„±â¢Â is aÂ â¢Ïƒâ¢-algebra andÂ â¢â„°âŠ‚â„±}. The family â„° is called a generator of Ïƒâ¢(â„°).

Exercise 1.1.6.

Let Î© be a countable set and â„°={{Ï‰}:Ï‰âˆˆÎ©}. Show that Ïƒâ¢(â„°)=2â„°.

For our statistical purposes the by far most important Ïƒ-algebra is the Borel Ïƒ-algebra â„¬â¢(â„) over the real numbers â„, which is defined as

â„¬â¢(â„)â‰”Ïƒâ¢({OâŠ‚â„:Oâ¢Â open}),

and we will always implicitly equip â„ with this Ïƒ-algebra when considering it as a measurable space. The Borel Ïƒ-algebra has the following simpler characterisation.

Lemma 1.1.7.

All of the following families of sets are generators of â„¬â¢(â„):

  1. (i)

    â„°1={(a,b):âˆ’âˆ<aâ‰¤b<âˆ}

  2. (ii)

    â„°2={[a,b]:âˆ’âˆ<aâ‰¤b<âˆ}

  3. (iii)

    â„°3={(a,b]:âˆ’âˆ<aâ‰¤b<âˆ}

  4. (iv)

    â„°4={(âˆ’âˆ,a):aâˆˆâ„}

  5. (v)

    â„°5={(âˆ’âˆ,a]:aâˆˆâ„}

Proof.

We only prove Ïƒâ¢(â„°1)=â„¬â¢(â„), the remaining statements are left as an exercise. Since any open interval (a,b) is open in â„ we have â„°1âŠ‚{OâŠ‚â„:Oâ¢Â open} and therefore

Ïƒâ¢(â„°1)âŠ‚Ïƒâ¢({OâŠ‚â„:Oâ¢Â open})=â„¬â¢(â„). (1.1)

Conversely, let OâŠ‚â„ be an arbitrary open set. Recall that O can then be written as a countable union of open intervals, that is, we can find sequences (an)nâˆˆâ„•,(bn)nâˆˆâ„• such that O=â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•(an,bn). Since (an,bn)âˆˆâ„°1âŠ‚Ïƒâ¢(â„°1) for all n, property (iii) of a Ïƒ-algebra implies that

O=â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•(an,bn)âŸâˆˆÏƒâ¢(â„°1)âˆˆÏƒâ¢(â„°1).

Since O was chosen arbitrarily we conclude that

{OâŠ‚â„:Oâ¢Â open}âŠ‚Ïƒâ¢(â„°1),

and therefore also

â„¬â¢(â„)=Ïƒâ¢({OâŠ‚â„:Oâ¢Â open})âŠ‚Ïƒâ¢(â„°1). (1.2)

Combining (1.1) and (1.2) gives the result. âˆ

Now that we have understood what a Ïƒ-algebra is, let us move on to the notion of a probability measure. We start a bit more general.

Definition 1.1.8.

A measure Î¼ on a measurable space (Î©,â„±) is a function Î¼:â„±â†’[0,âˆ] that satisfies the following properties:

  1. (i)

    Î¼â¢(âˆ…)=0

  2. (ii)

    if (An)nâˆˆâ„• is a pairwise disjoint sequence in â„±, it holds that

    Î¼â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•An)=âˆ‘nâˆˆâ„•Î¼â¢(An) (Ïƒ-additivity)

The measure Î¼ is called

  1. (iâ€™)

    finite, if Î¼â¢(Î©)<âˆ

  2. (iiâ€™)

    Ïƒ-finite, if there is a sequence (An)nâˆˆâ„• in â„± such that Î©=â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•An and Î¼â¢(An)<âˆ for all n.

Remark 1.1.9.

Note that by taking âˆ…=An+1=An+2=â‹¯ it follows from Ïƒ-additivity that for any finite, mutually disjoint collection A1,â€¦,Anâˆˆâ„± we have Î¼â¢(A1âˆªâ‹¯âˆªAn)=âˆ‘k=1nÎ¼â¢(Ak).

Definition 1.1.10.

A finite measure â„™ on a measurable space (Î©,â„±,â„™) is called probability measure if â„™â¢(Î©)=1. The triplet (Î©,â„±,â„™) is called probability space.

Definition 1.1.11.

A probability distribution (or simply distribution) is a probability measure on (â„,â„¬â¢(â„)).

Lemma 1.1.12.

Let (Î©,â„±,â„™) be a probability space and A,Bâˆˆâ„± be arbitrary events. Then,

  1. (i)

    if AâŠ‚B, it holds that â„™â¢(Bâˆ–A)=â„™â¢(B)âˆ’â„™â¢(A). In particular, â„™â¢(Ac)=1âˆ’â„™â¢(A).

  2. (ii)

    â„™â¢(AâˆªB)=â„™â¢(A)+â„™â¢(B)âˆ’â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B). In particular, â„™â¢(AâˆªB)â‰¤â„™â¢(A)+â„™â¢(B).

  3. (iii)

    if AâŠ‚B, it holds that â„™â¢(A)â‰¤â„™â¢(B).

Remark 1.1.13.

Analogous statements can be derived whenever we deal more generally with a finite measure Î¼. For infinite measures we need to be a bit more careful. E.g., while it is always true that Î¼â¢(AâˆªB)â‰¤Î¼â¢(A)+Î¼â¢(B), we can only make sense of Î¼â¢(A)+Î¼â¢(B)âˆ’Î¼â¢(Aâˆ©B) if Î¼â¢(Aâˆ©B)<âˆ, in which case indeed also Î¼â¢(AâˆªB)=Î¼â¢(A)+Î¼â¢(B)âˆ’Î¼â¢(Aâˆ©B).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    AâŠ‚B implies B=AâŠ(Bâˆ–A), whence by Ïƒ-additivity, â„™â¢(B)=â„™â¢(Bâˆ–A)+â„™â¢(A), or equivalently, â„™â¢(Bâˆ–A)=â„™â¢(B)âˆ’â„™â¢(A). Letting B=Î©, we obtain from this

    â„™â¢(Ac)=â„™â¢(Î©âˆ–A)=â„™â¢(Î©)âˆ’â„™â¢(A)=1âˆ’â„™â¢(A).
  2. (ii)

    Let C=Aâˆ©B. We can write AâˆªB=(Aâˆ–C)âŠ(Bâˆ–C)âŠC, which gives (using CâŠ‚A,CâŠ‚B and Ïƒ-additivity)

    â„™â¢(AâˆªB)=â„™â¢(Aâˆ–C)+â„™â¢(Bâˆ–C)+â„™â¢(C) =(i)â¢â„™â¢(A)âˆ’â„™â¢(C)+â„™â¢(B)âˆ’â„™â¢(C)+â„™â¢(C)
    =â„™â¢(A)+â„™â¢(B)âˆ’â„™â¢(C)
    =â„™â¢(A)+â„™â¢(B)âˆ’â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B).
  3. (iii)

    immediate from (i) since â„™â¢(Bâˆ–A)â‰¥0.

âˆ

Lemma 1.1.14 (Continuity of measures).

Let (Î©,â„±,Î¼) be a measure space.

  1. (i)

    If (An)nâˆˆâ„•âŠ‚â„± is an increasing sequence in the sense that AnâŠ‚An+1 for all nâˆˆâ„•, then

    Î¼â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•An)=limnâ†’âˆÎ¼â¢(An).
  2. (ii)

    If (An)nâˆˆâ„•âŠ‚â„± is a decreasing sequence in the sense that AnâŠƒAn+1 for all nâˆˆâ„•, and moreover Î¼â¢(A1)<âˆ, then

    Î¼â¢(â‹‚nâˆˆâ„•An)=limnâ†’âˆÎ¼â¢(An).
Proof.

See Appendix A. âˆ

Of special interest to us will be the following measures on (â„,â„¬â¢(â„)), which are in a certain sense on opposite ends of the spectrum. The Lebesgue measure Î» is the unique measure that satisfies

Î»â¢((a,b])=bâˆ’a,âˆ’âˆ<aâ‰¤b<âˆ,

and therefore assigns a volume to any set in â„¬â¢(â„) that we would consider as natural based on our physical perception of the world. The Dirac measure Î´x at a point xâˆˆâ„ is defined as

Î´xâ¢(A)={1,xâˆˆA0,xâˆ‰A,

i.e., it is a point mass that assigns unit volume to a measurable set A iff xâˆˆA. In particular we have Î´xâ¢({x})=1=Î´xâ¢(â„), so that Î´x is our first example of a probability measure. Conversely to this, for the Lebesgue measure it holds

Î»â¢({x})=Î»â¢(â‹‚nâˆˆâ„•(xâˆ’1/n,x+1/n])=limnâ†’âˆÎ»â¢((xâˆ’1/n,x+1/n])=limnâ†’âˆ2n=0.

For the the second equality we used continuity of measures from Lemma 1.1.14. This means that any singleton {x} is a nullset for the Lebesgue measure according to the next definition.

Definition 1.1.15.

Let Î¼ be a measure on some measurable space (Î©,â„±). A set Nâˆˆâ„± such that Î¼â¢(N)=0 is called a Î¼-nullset. If some property holds for all Ï‰âˆˆÎ©âˆ–N, where N is a Î¼-nullset, we say that this property holds Î¼-almost everywhere (Î¼-a.e.). If Î¼ is a probability measure we say instead Î¼-almost surely (Î¼-a.s.).

Exercise 1.1.16.

Show the following:

  1. (i)

    If â„™1,â„™2 are probability measures and Î»1,Î»2â‰¥0, then Î»1â¢â„™1+Î»2â¢â„™2 is a probability measure iff Î»1+Î»2=1.

  2. (ii)

    For any a,bâˆˆâ„ such that a<b it holds that

    Î»â¢([a,b])=Î»â¢([a,b))=Î»â¢((a,b])=Î»â¢((a,b)).
  3. (iii)

    The Lebesgue measure Î» is Ïƒ-finite but not finite.

1.2 Independence and Conditional Probability

Throughout this section we fix a probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™).

Definition 1.2.1 (Independence).

Two events A,Bâˆˆâ„± are defined to be independent if

â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B)=â„™â¢(A)â¢â„™â¢(B).
Example 1.2.2.

Let the probability space from Example 1.1.1 be given. Consider the events A={Hâ¢T,Hâ¢H}â‰œâ€œheads appears in first throwâ€ and B={Hâ¢T,Tâ¢T}â‰œâ€œtails appears in second throwâ€. Then

â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B)={Hâ¢T}=1/4=12â‹…12=â„™â¢({Hâ¢T,Hâ¢H})â¢â„™â¢({Hâ¢T,Tâ¢T})=â„™â¢(A)â¢â„™â¢(B),

so A and B are independent.

Definition 1.2.3 (Conditional Probability).

Let Aâˆˆâ„± s.t.Â â„™â¢(A)>0. The conditional probability â„™(â‹…âˆ£A) on (Î©,â„±) is defined by

â„™â¢(Bâˆ£A)=â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B)â„™â¢(A),âˆ€Bâˆˆâ„±,

and we call â„™â¢(Bâˆ£A) the conditional probability of B given A.

The definition entails that if â„™â¢(A)>0, an event Bâˆˆâ„± is independent of A, iff â„™â¢(Bâˆ£A)=â„™â¢(B).

Proposition 1.2.4.

The conditional probability â„™(â‹…âˆ£A) is a probability measure on (Î©,â„±).

Proof.

We need to show that (i) â„™â¢(âˆ…âˆ£A)=0, (ii) â„™â¢(Î©âˆ£A)=1 and (iii) for pairwise disjoint events (An)nâˆˆâ„• in â„± we have â„™â¢(â‹ƒnAnâˆ£A)=âˆ‘nâ„™â¢(Anâˆ£A). (i) is clear because Aâˆ©âˆ…=âˆ…. Since Î©âˆ©A=A, it also follows

â„™â¢(Î©âˆ£A)=â„™â¢(Î©âˆ©A)â„™â¢(A)=â„™â¢(A)â„™â¢(A)=1,

which establishes (ii). For (iii), note that we have Aâˆ©â‹ƒnAn=â‹ƒn(Anâˆ©A) and since (An)n are pairwise disjoint, the same remains true for (Anâˆ©A)n. Thus, Ïƒ-additivity of â„™ yields

â„™â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•Anâˆ£A)=â„™â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•(Anâˆ©A))â„™â¢(A)=âˆ‘nâˆˆâ„•â„™â¢(Anâˆ©A)â„™â¢(A)=âˆ‘nâˆˆâ„•â„™â¢(Anâˆ£A).

âˆ

Theorem 1.2.5 (Bayesâ€™ formula).

Let A,Bâˆˆâ„± such that â„™â¢(A),â„™â¢(B)>0. Then, for any Bâˆˆâ„±,

â„™â¢(Bâˆ£A)âposterior=â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)â¢â„™â¢(B)âpriorâ„™â¢(A)=â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)â¢â„™â¢(B)â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)â¢â„™â¢(B)+â„™â¢(Aâˆ£Bc)â¢â„™â¢(Bc).
Proof.

We have â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)=â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B)/â„™â¢(B), or equivalently, â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B)=â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)â¢â„™â¢(B). Plugging this expression for â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B) into â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)=â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B)/â„™â¢(B) gives the first stated equality. The second one follows from the first after decomposing A=(Aâˆ©B)âŠ(Aâˆ©Bc), which gives

â„™â¢(A) =â„™â¢(Aâˆ©B)+â„™â¢(Aâˆ©Bc) (law of total probability)
=â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)â¢â„™â¢(B)+â„™â¢(Aâˆ£Bc)â¢â„™â¢(Bc) (partition formula)

âˆ

Example 1.2.6.

A doping test is performed after a football match. The league is just a little bit crooked this year so that 0.5% of the players are doped. Moreover, the test detects a doped player with 95% accuracy, but is also positive in 1% of the cases when a non-doped player is tested (false positive). Let us calculate the probability that a player has actually doped if the test returns positive: if we let A=â€œtest positiveâ€ and B=â€œplayer is dopedâ€, then â„™â¢(B)=0.005, â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)=0.95 and â„™â¢(Aâˆ£Bc)=0.01. Thus, using Bayesâ€™ formula

â„™â¢(Bâˆ£AâŸâ€œplayer is doped given that test is positiveâ€)=â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)â¢â„™â¢(B)â„™â¢(Aâˆ£B)â¢â„™â¢(B)+â„™â¢(Aâˆ£Bc)â¢â„™â¢(Bc)=0.95â‹…0.0050.95â‹…0.005+0.01â‹…(1âˆ’0.005)=0.952.94â‰ˆ0.32.

This is why in sports there is always a B-sample taken.

Chapter 2 Random variables

2.1 Random variables and their distributions

2.1.1 Measurability

Definition 2.1.1.

Let (E,ğ’œ) be a measurable space. A function f:Eâ†’â„ is called measurable if for any Aâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„) it holds that fâˆ’1â¢(A)âˆˆğ’œ.

This definition appears rather cumbersome at first sight, since Ïƒ-algebras such as â„¬â¢(â„) are too complicated to check the measurability condition by hand in most circumstances. Fortunately, we can reduce this often impossible task by just checking the preimage condition for generating sets of the Borel Ïƒ-algebra, that is open sets or â€“ even simpler â€“ families of intervals as established in Lemma 1.1.7. The formal statement is the following.

Proposition 2.1.2.

Let (E,ğ’œ) be a measurable space and let â„° be a generator of â„¬â¢(â„), i.e., â„¬â¢(â„)=Ïƒâ¢(â„°). Then, a function f:Eâ†’â„ is measurable if, and only if, fâˆ’1â¢(â„°)âŠ‚ğ’œ.

Proof.

We skip the proof in the lecture. The proof is however quite enlightening, as it contains a powerful idea that is commonly applied in measure theory. I highly recommend to have a look at it in Appendix A. âˆ

Example 2.1.3.
  1. (i)

    Let (E,ğ’œ) be a measurable space and define the indicator function of a set Aâˆˆğ’œ as

    ğŸA:Eâ†’â„,xâ†¦{1,xâˆˆA,0,xâˆ‰A.

    For any set Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„) we have

    ğŸAâˆ’1â¢(B)={xâˆˆE:ğŸAâ¢(x)âˆˆB}={A,1âˆˆB,0âˆ‰B,Ac,0âˆˆB,1âˆ‰B,E,0,1âˆˆBâˆ…,0,1âˆ‰B,

    which shows ğŸAâˆ’1â¢(B)âˆˆğ’œ âŸ¹ ğŸA is measurable.

  2. (ii)

    Any continuous function f:â„â†’â„ is measurable: Let OâŠ‚â„ be open. By continuity fâˆ’1â¢(O) is open as well and since â„¬â¢(â„) is generated by open sets, this shows that fâˆ’1â¢(O)âˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„). By Proposition 2.1.2 this is sufficient to prove measurability.

Measurable functions are well-behaved under the usual analytic manipulations. We just record here a couple of important properties properties without proof (if you would like to try to prove some of these, Proposition 2.1.2 is very helpful).

Lemma 2.1.4.

Let (E,ğ’œ) be a measurable space.

  1. (i)

    If f,g are measurable functions on (E,ğ’œ), then f+g and fâ‹…g are also measurable.

  2. (ii)

    If f:Eâ†’â„ and g:â„â†’â„ are measurable, so is there composition gâˆ˜f.

  3. (iii)

    Let (fn)nâˆˆâ„• be a sequence of measurable functions mapping from E to â„ such that there exists a function f:Eâ†’â„ for which the pointwise convergence limnâ†’âˆfnâ¢(x)=fâ¢(x) holds for any xâˆˆE. Then, f is measurable.

2.1.2 Definition of random variables and their distributions

Definition 2.1.5.

A random variable on a probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™) is a measurable mapping X:Î©â†’â„, i.e., Xâˆ’1â¢(A)âˆˆâ„± for any Aâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„).

Remark 2.1.6.

In the following we will use the notation {XâˆˆA}â‰”Xâˆ’1â¢(A), which is motivated from the definition of the preimage Xâˆ’1â¢(A)={Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:Xâ¢(Ï‰)âˆˆA}. A random variable is therefore a mapping from the sample space Î© into the real numbers such that for any measurable set A in â„ the preimage {XâˆˆA} is a proper event on the probability space.

Since random variables are nothing else but measurable mappings in the context of probability spaces, we may recast Lemma 2.1.4 probabilistically.

Lemma 2.1.7.

Let (Î©,â„±,â„™) be a probability space.

  1. (i)

    If X,Y are random variables, then also X+Y and Xâ‹…Y are random variables.

  2. (ii)

    If X is a random variable and g:â„â†’â„ is measurable, then Y=gâ¢(X) is also a random variable.

  3. (iii)

    Let (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• be a sequence of random variables such that there exists X:Î©â†’â„ for which the pointwise convergence limnâ†’âˆXnâ¢(Ï‰)=Xâ¢(Ï‰) holds for any Ï‰âˆˆÎ©. Then, X is also a random variable.

Definition 2.1.8.

The distribution â„™X:â„¬â¢(â„)â†’[0,1] of a random variable X on a probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™) is defined by

â„™Xâ¢(B)=â„™â¢(Xâˆ’1â¢(B)),Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„).
Remark 2.1.9.

Analogously to before, we write interchangeably

â„™Xâ¢(B)=â„™â¢(Xâˆ’1â¢(B))=â„™â¢({XâˆˆB})=â„™â¢(XâˆˆB).

For an interval [a,b] we also write â„™â¢(Xâˆˆ[a,b])=â„™â¢(aâ‰¤Xâ‰¤b) with analogous conventions for open and half-open intervals. We also use the shorthand â„™â¢(Xâˆˆ(âˆ’âˆ,x])=â„™â¢(Xâ‰¤x) and write â„™â¢(XâˆˆA,XâˆˆB)=â„™â¢({XâˆˆA}âˆ©{XâˆˆB}), â„™â¢({XâˆˆA}âˆ£{XâˆˆB})=â„™â¢(XâˆˆAâˆ£XâˆˆB) for A,Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„).

Theorem 2.1.10.

Let X be a random variable on (Î©,â„±,â„™). Its distribution â„™X is a probability measure on (â„,â„¬â¢(â„)).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    â„™Xâ¢(âˆ…)=â„™â¢(Xâˆ’1â¢(âˆ…))=â„™â¢(âˆ…)=0.

  2. (ii)

    â„™Xâ¢(â„)=â„™â¢(Xâˆ’1â¢(â„))=â„™â¢(Î©)=1.

  3. (iii)

    It is easily checked that for a pairwise disjoint sequence (An)nâˆˆâ„•âŠ‚â„¬â¢(â„), the sequence (Xâˆ’1â¢(An))nâˆˆâ„• is also disjoint and by measurability of X it is a sequence in â„±. Consequently,

    â„™Xâ¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•An) =â„™â¢(Xâˆ’1â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•An))
    =â„™â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•Xâˆ’1â¢(An))
    =âˆ‘nâˆˆâ„•â„™â¢(Xâˆ’1â¢(An))
    =âˆ‘nâˆˆâ„•â„™Xâ¢(An),

    where we used Ïƒ-additivity of â„™ for the third line.

âˆ

Definition 2.1.11.

A random variable X is called discrete if there exists Nâˆˆâ„•âˆª{âˆ}, weights p1,â€¦,pNâ‰¥0 and points x1,â€¦,xNâˆˆâ„ (both interpreted as sequences if N=âˆ) such that âˆ‘k=1Npk=1 and

â„™X=âˆ‘k=1Npkâ¢Î´xk.

We call

fXâ¢(x)=â„™Xâ¢({x})=â„™â¢(X=x)=âˆ‘k=1Npkâ¢ğŸ{xk}â¢(x),xâˆˆâ„,

either the discrete density function or probability mass function (pmf).

Example 2.1.12.

Consider a simple coin toss with probability of heads equal to pâˆˆ[0,1]. We may model Î©={H,T},â„±=2Î©={{H},{T},{H,T},âˆ…} and â„™â¢({H})=p and then set Xâ¢(H)=1, Xâ¢(T)=0. The corresponding distribution â„™X can then be written as

â„™X=pâ¢Î´0+(1âˆ’p)â¢Î´1,

and we call â„™X a Bernoulli distribution with success rate p. Alternatively, we can start with â„™X as above and use it as a distributional model for the coin toss experiment with random outcome X directly, without specifying the underlying probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™).111Note here that if we start with a distribution â„™X on (â„,â„¬â¢(â„)), we can always construct a probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™) and a random variable X:Î©â†’â„ such that â„™X is the distribution of X. Indeed, we may simply set Î©=â„,â„±=â„¬â¢(â„),â„™=â„™X and Xâ¢(Ï‰)=Ï‰ for all Ï‰âˆˆâ„. This is referred to as the canonical construction. The latter modelling approach is particularly useful in situations, where a random phenomenon is far too complex to allow an explicit construction of the underlying probability space (think of a stock price for example) and is therefore the appropriate one for our statistical purposes.

Definition 2.1.13.

The distribution function FX:â„â†’[0,1] of a random variable X on a probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™) is defined by

FXâ¢(x)=â„™Xâ¢((âˆ’âˆ,x])=â„™â¢(Xâ‰¤x),xâˆˆâ„.
Remark 2.1.14.

Distribution functions are often also called cumulative distributions functions, abbreviated as cdf; we shall use this abbreviation from here on.

Exercise 2.1.15.
  1. (i)

    Sketch the cdf from Example 2.1.12 for p=1/4.

  2. (ii)

    Show that â„™â¢(Xâˆˆ(a,b])=Fâ¢(b)âˆ’Fâ¢(a) for all a<b.

Distribution functions play a special role because they are much simpler objects compared to distributions (function vs.Â measure), but are sufficient to fully characterise the distribution.

Theorem 2.1.16.

Let â„™X and â„™Y be two distributions. Then, â„™X=â„™Y (that is, â„™Xâ¢(B)=â„™Yâ¢(B) for all Bâˆˆâ„¬(â„)) if, and only if, FX=FY (that is, FXâ¢(x)=FYâ¢(x) for all xâˆˆâ„).

Proof (Sketch).

Generally, the following can be shown to be true: If â„™, â„š are two probability measures with underlying Ïƒ-algebra â„± generated by a âˆ©-stable family of sets â„°, i.e., â„±=Ïƒâ¢(â„°) and Aâˆ©Bâˆˆâ„° if A,Bâˆˆâ„°, then â„™=â„š iff â„™â¢(B)=â„šâ¢(B) for all Bâˆˆâ„°. Here, we have â„¬â¢(â„)=Ïƒâ¢(â„°) for â„°={(âˆ,x]:xâˆˆâ„}, see Lemma 1.1.7, and â„° is âˆ©-stable since (âˆ’âˆ,x]âˆ©(âˆ’âˆ,y]=(âˆ’âˆ,xâˆ§y]. Hence, â„™X=â„™Y iff

âˆ€xâˆˆâ„:â„™Xâ¢((âˆ’âˆ,x])âŸ=FXâ¢(x)=â„™Yâ¢((âˆ’âˆ,x])âŸ=FYâ¢(x).

âˆ

Proposition 2.1.17 (Properties of a cdf).

A cdf FX has the following properties

  1. (i)

    xâ†¦FXâ¢(x) is non-decreasing;

  2. (ii)

    limxâ†’âˆ’âˆFXâ¢(x)=0 and limxâ†’âˆFXâ¢(x)=1;

  3. (iii)

    xâ†¦FXâ¢(x) is right-continuous with left limits, i.e., for any aâˆˆâ„, limxâ†‘aFâ¢(x) exists and limxâ†“aFXâ¢(x)=Fâ¢(a).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    For x<y we have (âˆ’âˆ,x]âŠ‚(âˆ’âˆ,y] and hence by Lemma 1.1.12 FXâ¢(x)=â„™Xâ¢((âˆ’âˆ,x])â‰¤â„™Xâ¢((âˆ’âˆ,y])=Fâ¢(y).

  2. (ii)

    By the just established monotonicity and boundedness of FX, both limits exist and it is enough to check limnâ†’âˆFXâ¢(âˆ’n)=0 and limnâ†’âˆFXâ¢(n)=1. We only show the first claim, the second is left as an exercise: ((âˆ’âˆ,âˆ’n])nâˆˆâ„• is a decreasing sequence, so continuity of measures from Lemma 1.1.14 gives

    limnâ†’âˆFXâ¢(âˆ’n)=â„™Xâ¢(â‹‚nâˆˆâ„•(âˆ’âˆ,âˆ’n])=â„™Xâ¢(âˆ…)=0.
  3. (iii)

    Existence of left limits is a consequence of FX being increasing and bounded. Right-continuity can again be proven with continuity of measures (try it!).

âˆ

2.2 Continuous distributions and a very short sketch of integration theory

In Definition 2.1.11 we have already encountered discrete distributions that place probability mass on single points only. In undergrad probability modules you will also have encountered continuous distributions, which are defined via the cdf as follows: a random variable X is continuous if its cdf is given by

FXâ¢(x)=âˆ«âˆ’âˆxfâ¢(y)â¢dy

for a probability density function f:â„â†’â„, which is nice enough for the above integral to be well-defined as a Riemann integral. This gives rise to formulas such as

â„™â¢(aâ‰¤Xâ‰¤b)=âˆ«abfâ¢(y)â¢dy=âˆ«[a,b]fâ¢(y)â¢dy,

so that we are tempted to define the corresponding distribution as

â„™Xâ¢(B)=âˆ«Bfâ¢(y)â¢dy,Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„).

However, the meaning of such an integral in the sense of Riemann is unclear if the set B is not as nice as an interval (say B=â„š). We therefore need a different notion of an integral, which is the Lebesgue integral.

2.2.1 Lebesgue integral

We let (E,ğ’œ,Î¼) again be a general space. Integrals are supposed to calculate volumes or areas enclosed by functions. We have already interpreted Î¼â¢(A) as the volume of a set Aâˆˆğ’œ, which may be interpreted as well as an integral of the indicator ğŸA w.r.t.Â the measure Î¼. So, given some scalar Î±â‰¥0 it is natural for the function

fâ¢(x)=Î±â¢ğŸAâ¢(x),xâˆˆA,

to assign the scaled volume Î±â¢Î¼â¢(A) as an integral, that is we define

âˆ«Efâ¢(x)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)â‰”Î±â¢Î¼â¢(A).

Moreover, integrals should be linear, so for any simple function of the form

fâ¢(x)â‰”âˆ‘k=1nÎ±kâ¢ğŸAkâ¢(x)âŸfkâ¢(x),xâˆˆE,

for some nâˆˆâ„•, Î±1,â€¦,Î±nâ‰¥0, and A1,â€¦,Anâˆˆğ’œ pairwise disjoint, we define

âˆ«Efâ¢(x)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)â‰”âˆ‘k=1nÎ±kâ¢Î¼â¢(Ak)=âˆ‘k=1nâˆ«Efkâ¢(x)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x).

To extend the notion of the Lebesgue integral for simple functions to more general function classes, we use the following fundamental result.

Theorem 2.2.1.

For any non-negative, measurable function f:Eâ†’â„, there exists an increasing sequence of simple functions (fn)nâˆˆâ„• such that we have the pointwise convergence

âˆ€xâˆˆE:limnâ†’âˆfnâ¢(x)=fâ¢(x).
Proof.

Let

fnâ¢(x)â‰”âˆ‘k=0nâ¢2nâˆ’1k2nâ¢ğŸfâˆ’1([k2n,k+12n)âŸâˆˆğ’œ)â¢(x)+nâ¢ğŸfâˆ’1â¢([n,âˆ))âŸâˆˆğ’œâ¢(x),xâˆˆâ„.

Then fn is simple and for any xâˆˆâ„ it clearly holds that fnâ¢(x)â†’fâ¢(x) as nâ†’âˆ. Moreover, if xâˆˆfâˆ’1â¢([kâ¢2âˆ’n,(k+1)â¢2âˆ’n)), for some kâ‰¤nâ¢2nâˆ’1, then fnâ¢(x)=kâ¢2âˆ’nâ‰¤fâ¢(x) and similarly, fnâ¢(x)=nâ‰¤fâ¢(x) for xâˆˆfâˆ’1â¢([n,âˆ)). Thus, fnâ‰¤f. Finally, it follows from

[kâ¢2âˆ’n,(k+1)â¢2âˆ’n)=â¨„l=2â¢k2â¢k+1[lâ¢2âˆ’(n+1),(l+1)â¢2âˆ’(n+1)),[n,n+1)=â¨„l=2â¢(n+1)â¢(2nâˆ’1)(n+1)â¢2n+1âˆ’1[lâ¢2âˆ’(n+1),(l+1)â¢2âˆ’(n+1))

that fnâ‰¤fn+1 as desired. âˆ

Remark 2.2.2.

We call a sequence of simple functions as above an approximating sequence.

With this result and the intuitive definition of the Lebesgue integral for simple functions, we now define the general Lebesgue integral for any measurable function by taking limits. To this end, we let f+â¢(x)=maxâ¡{fâ¢(x),0} be the positive part and fâˆ’â¢(x)=maxâ¡{âˆ’fâ¢(x),0} be the negative part of a function f. Note that f=f+âˆ’fâˆ’ and |f|=f++fâˆ’. Moreover, if f is measurable, so are f+ and fâˆ’ and therefore also |f|.

Definition 2.2.3.

Let f:Eâ†’â„ be a non-negative measurable function and (fn)nâˆˆâ„• be an approximating sequence of simple functions. The Lebesgue integral of f is defined by

âˆ«Efâ¢dÎ¼â‰¡âˆ«Efâ¢(x)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)â‰”limnâ†’âˆâˆ«Efnâ¢(x)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x).

We call a measurable function f:Eâ†’â„ Î¼-integrable if âˆ«E|f|â¢dÎ¼<âˆ and define the Lebesgue integral of an integrable function by

âˆ«Efâ¢dÎ¼=âˆ«Ef+â¢dÎ¼âˆ’âˆ«Efâˆ’â¢dÎ¼.
Remark 2.2.4.
  1. (i)

    It can be shown that if (fn)n and (gn)n are two approximating functions of a non-negative measurable function f, then limnâ†’âˆâˆ«Efnâ¢dÎ¼=limnâ†’âˆâˆ«Egnâ¢dÎ¼, so that the Lebesgue integral is well-defined.

  2. (ii)

    We will use the notation âˆ«Afâ¢dÎ¼â‰”âˆ«Efâ¢ğŸAâ¢dÎ¼.

  3. (iii)

    If Î¼=Î» is the Lebesgue measure, we usually write âˆ«Afâ¢(x)â¢dÎ»â¢(x)=âˆ«Afâ¢(x)â¢dx.

Next, we state some important properties of the Lebesgue integral. We omit the proof but the strategy is always the same: first establish the desired statement for simple functions, then show it for non-negative measurable functions by taking limits and conclude for Î¼-integrable functions by decomposing into positive and negative parts.

Proposition 2.2.5.

Suppose that f,g:Eâ†’â„ are Î¼-integrable.

  1. (i)

    Linearity: for any Î±,Î²âˆˆâ„, the function Î±â¢f+Î²â¢g is Î¼-integrable and

    âˆ«E(Î±â¢f+Î²â¢g)â¢dÎ¼=Î±â¢âˆ«Efâ¢dÎ¼+Î²â¢âˆ«Egâ¢dÎ¼.
  2. (ii)

    Monotonicity: if fâ‰¤g Î¼-a.e., then

    âˆ«Efâ¢dÎ¼â‰¤âˆ«Egâ¢dÎ¼.
  3. (iii)

    Triangle inequality:

    |âˆ«Efâ¢dÎ¼|â‰¤âˆ«E|f|â¢dÎ¼.
  4. (iv)

    If Î¼â¢(N)=0 then âˆ«Nfâ¢dÎ¼=0.

In many situations it is desirable to switch the order of integration and taking limits and the next two powerful results identify situations where this is allowed.

Theorem 2.2.6 (Monotone convergence).

Let (fn)nâˆˆâ„• be an increasing sequence of measurable non-negative functions converging Î¼-a.e.Â  to a function f:Eâ†’â„, i.e., 0â‰¤f1â‰¤f2â‰¤â‹¯â¢fnâ‰¤â‹¯ and limnâ†’âˆfn=f, Î¼-a.e. Then,

limnâ†’âˆâˆ«Efnâ¢dÎ¼=âˆ«Efâ¢dÎ¼. (2.1)
Exercise 2.2.7.

Use continuity of measures to show (2.1) for the special case fn=ğŸAn, Anâˆˆğ’œ, and AnâŠ‚An+1 for any nâˆˆâ„•.

Theorem 2.2.8 (Dominated convergence).

Let f,f1,f2,â€¦ be Î¼-integrable functions such that

  1. (i)

    limnâ†’âˆfn=f Î¼-a.e.Â and

  2. (ii)

    there exists some non-negative Î¼-integrable function g s.t.Â |fn|â‰¤g Î¼-a.e.Â for any nâˆˆâ„•,

Then,

limnâ†’âˆâˆ«Efnâ¢dÎ¼=âˆ«Efâ¢dÎ¼.

2.2.2 Absolutely continuous distributions

With these preparations we can now finally construct continuous distributions.

Proposition 2.2.9 (Change of measure).

Let Î¼ be a measure on (E,ğ’œ) and f:Eâ†’â„ be a non-negative measurable function such that âˆ«Efâ¢dÎ¼=1. Then, the set function Î½ defined by

Î½â¢(B)â‰”âˆ«Bfâ¢dÎ¼,Bâˆˆğ’œ,

is a probability measure on (E,ğ’œ).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    Î½â¢(âˆ…)=âˆ«âˆ…fâ¢dÎ¼=âˆ«fâ¢ğŸâˆ…âŸâ‰¡0â¢dÎ¼=0.

  2. (ii)

    Î½â¢(E)=âˆ«Efâ¢dÎ¼=1 by assumption.

  3. (iii)

    Let (An)nâŠ‚ğ’œ be pairwise disjoint. Then âˆ‘n=1NğŸAn=ğŸâ‹ƒn=1NAn for all Nâˆˆâ„•âˆª{âˆ} and 0â‰¤fâ¢âˆ‘k=1nğŸAkâ‰¤fâ¢âˆ‘k=1n+1ğŸAkâ‰¤f. Thus,

    Î½â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•An) =âˆ«Efâ¢ğŸâ‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•Anâ¢dÎ¼
    =âˆ«Efâ¢limnâ†’âˆâˆ‘k=1nğŸAkâ¢dâ¢Î¼
    =limnâ†’âˆâˆ«Efâ¢âˆ‘k=1nğŸAkâ¢dâ¢Î¼
    =limnâ†’âˆâˆ«Eâˆ‘k=1nfâ¢ğŸAkâ¢dâ¢Î¼
    =limnâ†’âˆâˆ‘k=1nâˆ«Efâ¢ğŸAkâ¢dÎ¼
    =âˆ‘n=1âˆâˆ«Efâ¢ğŸAnâ¢dÎ¼
    =âˆ‘n=1âˆÎ¼â¢(An),

    where we used monotone convergence for the third and linearity for the fifth equality.

âˆ

Definition 2.2.10.

Let X be a random variable with distribution â„™X that is given by â„™Xâ¢(B)=âˆ«Bfâ¢dÎ¼ for a measure Î¼ on (â„,â„¬â¢(â„)) and a non-negative measurable function f:â„â†’â„ such that âˆ«fâ¢dÎ¼=1. Then we say that â„™X is absolutely continuous w.r.t.Â Î¼ (denoted â„™Xâ‰ªÎ¼) and call f its Î¼-density. If Î¼=Î» is the Lebesgue measure, we say that â„™X is absolutely continuous and that X is a continuous random variable. We then call f the probability density function (pdf) of â„™X. Generally, we call any non-negative measurable function f such that âˆ«â„fâ¢(x)â¢dx=1 a pdf and specify its associated distribution by â„¬â¢(â„)âˆ‹Bâ†¦âˆ«Bfâ¢(x)â¢dx.

Remark 2.2.11.

If â„™Xâ‰ªÎ¼ we also say that Î¼ dominates â„™X. The density is often symbolically written as f=dâ¢â„™Xdâ¢Î¼ (because then â„™Xâ¢(B)=âˆ«Bdâ¢â„™Xdâ¢Î¼â¢dÎ¼) and called the Radonâ€“Nikodym derivative of â„™X w.r.t.Â Î¼.

Exercise 2.2.12.

Let X be a continuous random variable. Show that â„™Xâ¢({x})=0 for every xâˆˆâ„. Deduce from this that FX is a continuous function.

2.3 Expectation of (transformed) random variables

Introducing the Lebesgue integral in the previous section now also allows us to define the expectation of a random variable. Throughout this section we fix a probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™) and implicitly understand all random variables to be defined there upon.

Definition 2.3.1.

Let X be a random variable that is either non-negative or â„™-integrable. The expectation of X is defined by

ğ”¼â¢[X]=âˆ«Î©Xâ¢dP.

Since the expectation is just a Lebesgue integral w.r.t.Â â„™, we can recast Proposition 2.2.5 probabilistically.

Corollary 2.3.2.

Suppose that X,Y are â„™-integrable random variables.

  1. (i)

    Linearity: for any Î±,Î²âˆˆâ„, Î±â¢X+Î²â¢Y is â„™-integrable and ğ”¼â¢[Î±â¢X+Î²â¢Y]=Î±â¢ğ”¼â¢[X]+Î²â¢ğ”¼â¢[Y].

  2. (ii)

    Monotonicity: if Xâ‰¤Y, â„™-a.s., then

    ğ”¼â¢[X]â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[Y].
  3. (iii)

    Triangle inequality:

    |ğ”¼â¢[X]|â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[|X|].
  4. (iv)

    If X=Y â„™-a.s., then ğ”¼â¢[X]=ğ”¼â¢[Y].

Recall that if g:â„â†’â„ is measurable, Y=gâ¢(X) is also a random variable, so that the expectation ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)] is well defined provided g is non-negative or âˆ«Î©|gâ¢(X)|â¢dâ„™<âˆ. To see how to calculate an expected value, let us first look at the case g=ğŸA for some Aâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„). Then,

ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)]=ğ”¼â¢[ğŸAâ¢(X)]=âˆ«Î©ğŸAâ¢(X)â¢dâ„™=âˆ«Î©ğŸ{XâˆˆA}â¢dâ„™=â„™â¢(XâˆˆA)=â„™Xâ¢(A)=âˆ«â„ğŸAâ¢dâ„™X=âˆ«â„gâ¢dâ„™X, (2.2)

by the definition of the integral for simple functions. As it turns out, this result is generally true.

Theorem 2.3.3 (Transformation theorem for random variables).

Let X be a random variable and g:â„â†’â„ be a measurable function that is either non-negative or such that âˆ«â„|g|â¢dâ„™X<âˆ. Then,

ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)]=âˆ«â„gâ¢dâ„™X.
Proof.

Consider first the case that g=âˆ‘k=1nÎ±kâ¢ğŸAk is a simple function. Then, using (2.2) and linearity it follows

âˆ«â„gâ¢dâ„™X=âˆ‘k=1nÎ±kâ¢âˆ«â„ğŸAkâ¢dâ„™X=âˆ‘k=1nÎ±kâ¢ğ”¼â¢[ğŸAkâ¢(X)]=ğ”¼â¢[âˆ‘k=1nÎ±kâ¢ğŸAkâ¢(X)]=ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)].

Next, let gâ‰¥0 be measurable and let (gn)nâˆˆâ„• be an approximating sequence of simple functions (recall: increasing and converges pointwise to g. Then also (gnâ¢(X))nâˆˆâ„• increasing sequence of measurable functions on Î© and limnâ†’âˆgnâ¢(X)=gâ¢(X)). From above, ğ”¼â¢[gnâ¢(X)]=âˆ«â„gnâ¢dâ„™X and therefore, applying monotone convergence twice

âˆ«â„gâ¢dâ„™X=âˆ«â„limnâ†’âˆgnâ¢dâ¢â„™X=limnâ†’âˆâˆ«â„gnâ¢dâ„™X=limnâ†’âˆğ”¼â¢[gnâ¢(X)]=ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)].

Finally, suppose that g is measurable and âˆ«â„|g|â¢dâ„™X<âˆ. We have just shown that

âˆ«â„|g|â¢dâ„™X=âˆ«Î©|gâ¢(X)|â¢dâ„™,

so that gâ¢(X) is â„™-integrable. Consequently, the above yields

âˆ«â„gâ¢dâ„™X=âˆ«â„g+â¢dâ„™Xâˆ’âˆ«â„gâˆ’â¢dâ„™X=ğ”¼â¢[g+â¢(X)]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[gâˆ’â¢(X)]=ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)]

as claimed. âˆ

As a consequence, the expectations of transformations of a random variable X do not depend on the underlying probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™), but can be entirely expressed in terms of the distribution â„™X. This is particularly handy for modelling and explains why in statistics we wish to draw inference on â„™X for a given sample of random variables following this distribution. The above observation also motivates the following definition.

Definition 2.3.4.
  1. (i)

    Let X and Y be two random variables (not necessarily defined on the same probability space). We say that they are equal in distribution if â„™X=â„™Y and denote this by Xâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢Y.

  2. (ii)

    If Î½ is some distribution, we write Xâˆ¼Î½ if â„™X=Î½. If â„™X is absolutely continuous with density f, we simply write Xâˆ¼f.

Remark 2.3.5.

Since distribution functions uniquely characterise the distribution, we have Xâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢Y iff FX=FY.

Theorem 2.3.6 (Calculation rules).
  1. 1.

    Let X be a continuous random variable with pdf f. Let g:â„â†’â„ be a measurable function that is either non-negative or such that âˆ«â„|gâ¢(x)|â¢fâ¢(x)â¢dx<âˆ. It then holds that

    ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)]=âˆ«â„gâ¢(x)â¢fâ¢(x)â¢dx.
  2. 2.

    Let X be a discrete random variable with discrete density function f=âˆ‘k=1Npkâ¢ğŸ{xk} for some Nâˆˆâ„•âˆª{âˆ}, pkâ‰¥0, xkâˆˆâ„. Let also g:â„â†’â„ be a measurable function that is either non-negative or such that âˆ‘k=1N|gâ¢(xk)|â¢pk<âˆ. It then holds that

    ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)]=âˆ‘k=1Ngâ¢(xk)â¢pk=âˆ‘k=1Ngâ¢(xk)â¢â„™â¢(X=xk).
Remark 2.3.7.

In particular, for the expectation of X we get ğ”¼â¢[X]=âˆ«â„xâ¢fâ¢(x)â¢dx and âˆ‘k=1Nxkâ¢pk, respectively, provided integral and sum are well-defined.

Proof.

By Theorem 2.3.3 it suffices to show

âˆ«â„gâ¢dâ„™X={âˆ«â„gâ¢(x)â¢fâ¢(x)â¢dx,Xâ¢Â continuous,ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)]=âˆ‘k=1Ngâ¢(xk)â¢pk,Xâ¢Â discrete.

This can be proved analogously to Theorem 2.3.3: (1) show the statement for simple g using linearity and the definition of â„™X; (2) extend to non-negative measurable functions via monotone convergence; (3) use (2) to show it for g satisfying the integrability criteria by splitting g=g+âˆ’gâˆ’. We leave the details to you. âˆ

You may still be concerned about the expression âˆ«â„fâ¢(x)â¢gâ¢(x)â¢dx: the notation looks quite inviting as it reminds us of the (improper) Riemann integral âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆfâ¢(x)â¢gâ¢(x)â¢dx, which you have learned to calculate for many different choices of f,g. Fortunately, under mild assumptions (that will always be satisfied in any example/exercise of the module!) the integrals coincide and you can calculate as usual.

Theorem 2.3.8.

Let X be a continuous random variable with pdf f that is piecewise continuous. Let g:â„â†’â„ be a also a piecewise continuous function that is either non-negative or such that âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆ|gâ¢(x)|â¢fâ¢(x)â¢dx<âˆ (read as a Riemann integral). It then holds that

ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X)]=âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆgâ¢(x)â¢fâ¢(x)â¢dx=limnâ†’âˆâˆ«âˆ’nnfâ¢(x)â¢gâ¢(x)â¢dx.
Exercise 2.3.9.

Let Î»>0 and fÎ»:â„â†’â„ be given by

fÎ»â¢(x)=Î»â¢eâˆ’Î»â¢xâ¢ğŸ[0,âˆ)â¢(x),xâˆˆâ„.
  1. (i)

    Show that âˆ«â„fÎ»â¢(x)â¢dx=1 and for any kâˆˆâ„•, âˆ«â„|x|kâ¢fÎ»â¢(x)â¢dx<âˆ.

  2. (ii)

    Let X be a random variable with pdf fÎ» as above. Show that FXâ¢(x)=(1âˆ’eâˆ’Î»â¢x)â¢ğŸ[0,âˆ)â¢(x), ğ”¼â¢[X]=1/Î» and ğ”¼â¢[X2]=2/Î»2.

Exercise 2.3.10.

Let X be a continuous random variable with continuous pdf f. Show that FXâ€²â¢(x)=fâ¢(x) for all xâˆˆâ„.

2.4 Moments and moment generating functions

We finish this chapter with some important transformations that are particularly important in statistics.

Definition 2.4.1.

The variance Varâ¡(X) of a random variable X such that ğ”¼â¢[|X|2]<âˆ is defined by

Varâ¡(X)â‰”ğ”¼â¢[(Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X])2].

The standard deviation is defined by

ÏƒXâ‰”Varâ¡(X).

We first note that the variance is well-defined because ğ”¼â¢[|X|2]<âˆ implies ğ”¼â¢[|X|]<âˆ. This follows from the Cauchyâ€“Schwarz inequality for random variables.

Theorem 2.4.2.

Let X,Y be two random variables on (Î©,â„±,â„™). Then,

ğ”¼â¢[|Xâ¢Y|]â‰¤(ğ”¼â¢[X2])1/2â¢(ğ”¼â¢[Y2])1/2. (Cauchyâ€“Schwarz inequality)

More generally, it holds for any p,qâ‰¥1 s.t.Â 1/p+1/q=1 that

ğ”¼â¢[|Xâ¢Y|]â‰¤(ğ”¼â¢[Xp])1/pâ¢(ğ”¼â¢[Yq])1/q. (HÃ¶lder inequality)
Lemma 2.4.3.

Suppose that ğ”¼â¢[|X|2]<âˆ. Then,

Varâ¡(X)=ğ”¼â¢[X2]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]2.
Proof.

By integrability we can use linearity of the expectation and calculate as follows:

ğ”¼â¢[(Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X])2]=ğ”¼â¢[X2âˆ’2â¢Xâ¢ğ”¼â¢[X]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]2]=ğ”¼â¢[X2]âˆ’2â¢ğ”¼â¢[Xâ¢ğ”¼â¢[X]]âŸ=ğ”¼â¢[X]â¢ğ”¼â¢[X]+ğ”¼â¢[ğ”¼â¢[X]2]âŸ=ğ”¼â¢[X]2=ğ”¼â¢[X2]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]2.

âˆ

Exercise 2.4.4.

Suppose that ğ”¼â¢[|X|2]<âˆ. Show that for any aâˆˆâ„, we have Varâ¡(aâ¢X)=a2â¢Varâ¡(X) and Varâ¡(X+a)=Varâ¡(X).

The variance is a quantity that roughly encodes how much a random variable X fluctuates around its mean ğ”¼â¢[X]. To underline this point we need a fundamental integral inequality that in spite of its simplicity is of fundamental value in statistics.

Theorem 2.4.5 (Markovâ€™s inequality).

Let X be a random variable and Ï†:[0,âˆ)â†’[0,âˆ) be a non-negative, non-decreasing and measurable function such that Ï†â¢((0,âˆ))âŠ‚(0,âˆ). Then, for any t>0 it holds that

â„™â¢(|X|â‰¥t)â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[Ï†â¢(|X|)]Ï†â¢(t).
Proof.

Since Ï† is increasing we have

âˆ€Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:|Xâ¢(Ï‰)|â‰¥tâŸ¹Ï†â¢(|Xâ¢(Ï‰)|)â‰¥Ï†â¢(t)

and therefore

{|X|â‰¥t}âŠ‚{Ï†â¢(|X|)â‰¥Ï†â¢(t)}. (2.3)

Note also that

ğŸ{Ï†â¢(|X|)â‰¥Ï†â¢(t)}â‰¤ğŸ{Ï†(|Xâˆ¥)â‰¥Ï†(t)}â¢Ï†â¢(|X|)Ï†â¢(t). (2.4)

We therefore obtain

â„™â¢(|X|â‰¥t)â¢â‰¤(â¢2.3â¢)â¢â„™â¢(Ï†â¢(|X|)â‰¥Ï†â¢(t)) =ğ”¼â¢[ğŸ{Ï†(|Xâˆ¥)â‰¥Ï†(t)}]
â‰¤(â¢2.4â¢)â¢ğ”¼â¢[ğŸ{Ï†(|Xâˆ¥)â‰¥Ï†(t)}â¢Ï†â¢(|X|)Ï†â¢(t)]
â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[Ï†â¢(|X|)Ï†â¢(t)]
=ğ”¼â¢[Ï†â¢(|X|)]Ï†â¢(t),

where for the second and third inequality we used monotonicity of the expectation, cf.Â Corollary 2.3.2. âˆ

Corollary 2.4.6 (Chebyshevâ€™s inequality).

For any random variable X such that ğ”¼â¢[X2]<âˆ it holds that

â„™â¢(|Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]|â‰¥t)â‰¤Varâ¡(X)t2,t>0.

In particular, we have

â„™â¢(|Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]ÏƒX|â‰¥t)â‰¤1t2,t>0.
Remark 2.4.7.

We call (Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X])/ÏƒX the standardisation of a random variable X.

Proof.

Exercise! âˆ

Definition 2.4.8.

Let kâˆˆâ„•. If ğ”¼â¢[|X|k]<âˆ, we define the k-th moment of X as

Î¼kâ€²â¢(X)â‰”ğ”¼â¢[Xk],

and the k-th centered moment of X as

Î¼kâ¢(X)â‰”ğ”¼â¢[(Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X])k].

We have already encountered the second centered moment as the variance of X. The third and and fourth centered moment also yield quantities with specific names:

  • â€¢

    Skewness: Î¼3ÏƒX3=ğ”¼â¢[(Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]ÏƒX)3]. Indicates graphically whether a density is left-leaning (skewness positive) or right-leaning (skewness negative).

  • â€¢

    Kurtosis: Î¼4ÏƒX4=ğ”¼â¢[(Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]ÏƒX)4]. By comparing it to kurtosis of a normal density (see next chapter) used to indicate how heavy the tails of the distribution are, i.e.Â how likely it is to observe outliers in a sample.

Definition 2.4.9.

The moment generating function (mgf) of a random variable X or a distribution â„™X is defined as

ÏˆXâ¢(t)â‰”ğ”¼â¢[etâ¢X]=âˆ«â„etâ¢xâ¢dâ„™Xâ¢(x),tâˆˆâ„.

We say that the mgf exists at âˆˆâ„, if ÏˆXâ¢(t)<âˆ.

The name originates from the fact that for a random variable, whose mgf around the origin, all moments can be derived from differentiation of the mgf.

Theorem 2.4.10.

Suppose that ÏˆX exists on (âˆ’h,h) for some h>0. Then, we have for any nâˆˆâ„•,

ğ”¼â¢[Xn]=dndâ¢tnâ¢ÏˆXâ¢(t)|t=0.
Proof (Sketch).

It holds that

dndâ¢tnâ¢etâ¢X=Xnâ¢etâ¢X.

So, supposing that we may switch the order of differentiation and integration on (âˆ’h,h), it follows that

dndâ¢tnâ¢ÏˆXâ¢(t)=dndâ¢tnâ¢ğ”¼â¢[etâ¢X]=ğ”¼â¢[dndâ¢tnâ¢etâ¢X]=ğ”¼â¢[Xnâ¢etâ¢X],tâˆˆ(âˆ’h,h),

which gives the result by plugging in t=0. The fact that pulling the derivative inside the expectation is allowed can be proven by dominated convergence. âˆ

We have already seen that the distribution function FX uniquely characterises â„™X. The same holds true for the moment generating function, provided it exists. The proof is unfortunately out of scope of this lecture.

Theorem 2.4.11.

Suppose that X,Y are random variables such that their mgfs ÏˆX,ÏˆY exist on some open interval (âˆ’h,h), h>0. Then,

Xâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢Yâ‡”ÏˆX=ÏˆYâ¢Â onÂ â¢(âˆ’h,h).
Exercise 2.4.12.

Let fÎ» be the density from Exercise 2.3.9 and Xâˆ¼fÎ».

  1. (i)

    Show that ÏˆXâ¢(t) exists iff t<Î» and calculate ÏˆX for these values.

  2. (ii)

    Deduce from (i) that ğ”¼â¢[Xn]=n!Î»n.

2.5 P-values and quantiles

Here we get to know two important summary statistics of a random variable X that will be of central importance in our discussion of hypothesis testing later in the lecture. The situation is the following: suppose we are given a test statistic X and we want to check whether the hypothesis Xâˆ¼P0 is plausible for some given distribution P0 with associated cdf F0. There are different ways to approach this problem:

  1. 1.

    Check whether the observed realization Xâ¢(Ï‰) is suspiciously small by calculating P0â¢((âˆ’âˆ,Xâ¢(Ï‰)])=F0â¢(X).

  2. 2.

    Check whether the observed realization Xâ¢(Ï‰) is suspiciously large by calculating P0â¢([Xâ¢(Ï‰),âˆ))=1âˆ’F0â¢(Xâ¢(Ï‰)âˆ’).

  3. 3.

    Check both simultaneously by calculating 2â¢minâ¡{F0â¢(Xâ¢(Ï‰)),1âˆ’F0â¢(Xâ¢(Ï‰)âˆ’)}.

This motivates the definition of the p-value.

Definition 2.5.1 (p-value).

Suppose that X is a random variable on a probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™0) such that Xâˆ¼P0 under â„™0.

  1. (i)

    The left-sided p-value pl is defined by plâ‰”F0â¢(X).

  2. (ii)

    The right-sided p-value pr is defined by prâ‰”1âˆ’F0â¢(Xâˆ’).

  3. (iii)

    The two-sided p-value ps is defined by psâ‰”2min{F0(X,1âˆ’F0(Xâˆ’)}.

A small p-value always indicates that the hypothesis Xâˆ¼P0 might not be true. More precisely:

Lemma 2.5.2.

Suppose that Xâˆ¼P0 under â„™0. Then, the following are true for any Î±âˆˆ(0,1):

(i)â„™0â¢(F0â¢(X)â‰¤Î±)(ii)â„™0â¢(1âˆ’F0â¢(Xâˆ’)â‰¤Î±)(iii)â„™0â¢(2â¢minâ¡{F0â¢(X),1âˆ’F0â¢(Xâˆ’)}â‰¤Î±)}â¢â‰¤Î±,

with equality if X is continuous.

For the proof we introduce the pseudo-inverse of a distribution function F0 as

q0:(0,1)â†’â„,q0â¢(Î±)â‰”inf{xâˆˆâ„:F0â¢(x)>Î±}.
Proof.

For simplicity, we only consider the case that X is continuous. From Exercise 2.2.12 we know that then F0 is a continuous function and we claim that

F0â¢(q0â¢(Î±))=Î±. (2.5)

Indeed, observe that for any x<q0â¢(Î±) we have F0â¢(x)â‰¤Î±, and therefore by continuity of F0,

F0â¢(q0â¢(Î±))=limxâ†‘q0â¢(Î±)Fâ¢(x)â‰¤Î±.

On the other hand, for x>q0â¢(Î±) it holds that F0â¢(x)>Î± and hence by right-continuity

F0â¢(q0â¢(Î±))=limxâ†“q0â¢(Î±)Fâ¢(x)â‰¥Î±.

Combining both statements gives (2.5). Let us also show that

xâ‰¤q0â¢(Î±)â‡”F0â¢(x)â‰¤F0â¢(q0â¢(Î±)). (2.6)

Direction âŸ¹ is clear since F0 is increasing. Conversely, if F0â¢(x)â‰¤Fâ¢(q0â¢(Î±)), then by (2.5), we have F0â¢(x)â‰¤Î±, whence xâ‰¤q0â¢(Î±). Thus,

â„™0(F0(X)â‰¤Î±)=(â¢2.5â¢)â„™0(F0(X)â‰¤F0(q0(Î±))=(â¢2.6â¢)â„™0(Xâ‰¤q0(Î±))=F0(q0(Î±))=(â¢2.5â¢)Î±.

The remaining statements are easily derived from the first (try this!). âˆ

Definition 2.5.3 (Î³-quantile).

Let Î³âˆˆ(0,1). A real number qÎ³ is called Î³-quantile of a distribution P, if

Pâ¢((âˆ’âˆ,qÎ³])â‰¥Î³andPâ¢([qÎ³,âˆ))â‰¥1âˆ’Î³.
Remark 2.5.4.
  1. (i)

    Interpretation: qÎ³ splits the real axis in left and right half-lines with probability at least Î³ and 1âˆ’Î³, respectively.

  2. (ii)

    Equivalently, qÎ³ is a Î³-quantile iff Fâ¢(qÎ³âˆ’)â‰¤Î³â‰¤Fâ¢(qÎ³).

  3. (iii)

    If F0 is strictly increasing, Î³-quantiles are unique.

2.6 Some basic univariate distributions

2.6.1 Discrete distributions

Bernoulli distribution

We say that X has a Bernoulli distribution with success probability pâˆˆ[0,1] if

â„™â¢(X=x)={p,x=11âˆ’p,x=0,0,else

and we then write Xâˆ¼â„¬â¢(p). The distribution of X can be equivalently written as

â„™X=pâ¢Î´1+(1âˆ’p)â¢Î´0.

We have

ğ”¼â¢[X]=1â‹…â„™â¢(X=1)+0â‹…â„™â¢(X=0)=p,

and since

ğ”¼â¢[X2]=12â‹…â„™â¢(X=1)+02â‹…â„™â¢(X=0)=p,

it follows that

Varâ¡(X)=ğ”¼â¢[X2]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]2=pâˆ’p2=pâ¢(1âˆ’p).

The mgf exists for all tâˆˆâ„ and is given by

ÏˆXâ¢(t)=ğ”¼â¢[expâ¡(tâ¢X)]=etâ‹…1â¢â„™â¢(X=1)+etâ‹…0â¢â„™â¢(X=0)=etâ¢p+(1âˆ’p)=1+pâ¢(etâˆ’1),tâˆˆâ„.

Interpretation: X models a single trial of a random experiment with probability of success p and probability of failure 1âˆ’p.

Binomial distribution

We say that X has a Binomial distribution with success probability pâˆˆ[0,1] and number of trials nâˆˆâ„• if

â„™â¢(X=x)={(nk)â¢pkâ¢(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’k,x=kâˆˆ{0,1,â€¦,n},0,else,

where the binomial coefficient

(nk)â‰”n!k!â¢(nâˆ’k)!,

describes the number of possibilities to choose k unordered elements (without replacement) from a set of n elements. We then write Xâˆ¼Binâ¢(n,p). The distribution of the discrete random variable X can be equivalently written as

â„™X=âˆ‘k=0n(nk)â¢pkâ¢(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’kâŸ=â„™â¢(X=k)â£=pkâ¢Î´k.

The fact that â„™X is a probability distribution follows from the binomial theorem:

âˆ‘k=0n(nk)â¢pkâ¢(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’k=(p+(1âˆ’p))n=1.

For p=0 (p=1) we have X=n a.s.Â (X=0 a.s.) and hence in both cases ğ”¼â¢[X]=nâ¢p,Varâ¡(X)=0=nâ¢pâ¢(1âˆ’p). For pâˆˆ(0,1) we get

ğ”¼â¢[X]=âˆ‘k=0nkâ¢pk =âˆ‘k=0nkâ¢(nk)â¢pkâ¢(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’k
=âˆ‘k=1nâˆ’1n!(kâˆ’1)!â¢(nâˆ’k)!â¢pkâ¢(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’k
=nâ¢pâ¢âˆ‘k=1nâˆ’1(nâˆ’1)!(kâˆ’1)!â¢(nâˆ’1âˆ’(kâˆ’1))!â¢pkâˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’1âˆ’(kâˆ’1)
=nâ¢pâ¢âˆ‘l=0nâˆ’1(nâˆ’1l)â¢plâ¢(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’l
=nâ¢p,

where we substituted l=kâˆ’1 for the penultimate line. To show that generally Varâ¡(X)=nâ¢pâ¢(1âˆ’p) we could try to calculate ğ”¼â¢[X2] directly by invoking some combinatorial transformations as above, or we may try a different route by calculating the mgf. The latter is simple: by the binomial theorem,

ÏˆXâ¢(t)=âˆ‘k=0netâ¢kâ¢(nk)â¢pkâ¢(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’k=âˆ‘k=0n(nk)â¢(pâ¢et)kâ¢(1âˆ’p)nâˆ’k=(pâ¢et+(1âˆ’p))n,tâˆˆâ„.

Since

ÏˆXâ€²â¢(t)=nâ¢pâ¢etâ¢(pâ¢et+(1âˆ’p))nâˆ’1,ÏˆXâ€²â€²â¢(t)=nâ¢pâ¢etâ¢(pâ¢et+(1âˆ’p))nâˆ’1+nâ¢(nâˆ’1)â¢p2â¢e2â¢tâ¢(pâ¢et+(1âˆ’p))nâˆ’2,

it follows that

ğ”¼â¢[X2]=ÏˆXâ€²â€²â¢(0)=nâ¢p+nâ¢(nâˆ’1)â¢p2,

and therefore

Varâ¡(X)=ğ”¼â¢[X2]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]2=nâ¢p+nâ¢(nâˆ’1)â¢p2âˆ’n2â¢p2=nâ¢pâˆ’nâ¢p2=nâ¢pâ¢(1âˆ’p).

Interpretation: X models the number of successes in n independent Bernoulli trials.

Geometric distribution

We say that a random variable X has a geometric distribution with success probability pâˆˆ(0,1], if

â„™â¢(X=x)={pâ¢(1âˆ’p)kâˆ’1,x=kâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦}0,else

and we then write Xâˆ¼Geoâ¢(p). Equivalently, we may express the distribution as

â„™X=âˆ‘k=1âˆpâ¢(1âˆ’p)kâˆ’1â¢Î´k.
Proposition 2.6.1 (Memorylessness).

If Xâˆ¼Geoâ¢(p), then for any m,nâˆˆâ„• it holds that

â„™â¢(X>n+mâ¢âˆ£X>â¢n)=â„™â¢(X>m).

Interpretation: X models the number of independent Bernoulli trials with success probability p, until the first occurrence of success (X=k means that the first kâˆ’1 trials were unsuccessful, which happens with probability (1âˆ’p)âˆ’1, and the k-th trial is a success. Be aware that there are different conventions as to how to define the geometric distribution. Some authors prefer to model it as the number of failures until a success occurs, which changes the distribution to â„™X=âˆ‘k=0âˆpâ¢(1âˆ’p)k.

Exercise 2.6.2.

Show that â„™X is indeed a distribution. Determine the values tâˆˆâ„, at which the mgf ÏˆXâ¢(t) exists and calculate it for these. Use the mgf to show that ğ”¼â¢[X]=1p and Varâ¡(X)=(1âˆ’p)/p2.

Poisson distribution

We say that a random variable X has a Poisson distribution with with rate Î»>0, if

â„™â¢(X=x)={Î»kk!â¢eâˆ’Î»,x=kâˆˆ{0,1,2,â€¦}0,else

and we then write Xâˆ¼Poiâ¢(Î»). â„™X is accordingly given by

â„™X=âˆ‘k=0âˆÎ»kk!â¢eâˆ’Î»â¢Î´k.
Exercise 2.6.3.

Show that â„™X is indeed a distribution. Show that the mgf exists for all tâˆˆâ„ and is given by

ÏˆXâ¢(t)=expâ¡(Î»â¢(etâˆ’1)),tâˆˆâ„.

Use the mgf to show that ğ”¼â¢[X]=Varâ¡(X)=Î».

Interpretation: consider a situation, where random events occur subsequently at rate Î» (i.e.Â on average Î» events per time unit) and the interarrival time between two events is independent of the arrival times of previous events. If we let X be the number of events that have occurred in a unit time interval, then Xâˆ¼Poiâ¢(Î»).

2.6.2 Continuous distributions

Uniform distribution

A continuous random variable X is said to be uniformly distributed on an interval [a,b] with a<b if its pdf is given by

fâ¢(x)=1bâˆ’aâ¢ğŸ[a,b]â¢(x),xâˆˆâ„,

and we then write Xâˆ¼ğ’°â¢([a,b]). The piecewise linear cdf is given by

FXâ¢(x)=âˆ«âˆ’âˆx1bâˆ’aâ¢ğŸ[a,b]â¢(y)â¢dy={0,x<axâˆ’abâˆ’a,xâˆˆ[a,b],1,else.

Expectation and variance are easily calculated as follows,

ğ”¼â¢[X] =âˆ«â„xâ¢fâ¢(x)â¢dx=1bâˆ’aâ¢âˆ«abxâ¢dx=12â¢(bâˆ’a)â¢(b2âˆ’a2)âŸ=(a+b)â¢(bâˆ’a)=a+b2
Varâ¡(X) =âˆ«â„(xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X])2â¢fâ¢(x)â¢dx=1bâˆ’aâ¢âˆ«ab(xâˆ’a+b2)2â¢dx=1bâˆ’aâ¢âˆ«(aâˆ’b)/2(bâˆ’a)/2x2â¢dx
=2bâˆ’aâ¢âˆ«0(bâˆ’a)/2x2â¢dx=2â¢((bâˆ’a)/2)33â¢(bâˆ’a)=(bâˆ’a)212,

and the mgf exists everywhere and is given by

ÏˆXâ¢(t)=1bâˆ’aâ¢âˆ«abetâ¢xâ¢dx={etâ¢bâˆ’etâ¢atâ¢(bâˆ’a),tâ‰ 0,1,t=0.
Exponential distribution

We say that a continuous random variable X is exponentially distributed with rate Î»>0 if its pdf is given by

fâ¢(x)=Î»â¢eâˆ’Î»â¢xâ¢ğŸ[0,âˆ)â¢(x),xâˆˆâ„,

and we then write Xâˆ¼Expâ¢(Î»). We recognize this as the pdf explored in Exercise 2.3.9 and Exercise 2.4.12, so we already know that

ğ”¼â¢[Xn]=n!Î»n,Varâ¡(X)=1Î»2,FXâ¢(x)=1âˆ’eâˆ’Î»â¢x,

and that the mgf exists on (âˆ’âˆ,Î») and is there given by

ÏˆXâ¢(t)=Î»Î»âˆ’t,t<Î».

Like the discrete geometric distribution, the continuous exponential distribution has a lack of memory property.

Proposition 2.6.4.

Let Xâˆ¼Expâ¢(Î») for some Î»>0. Then, for any x,yâ‰¥0 we have

â„™â¢(X>x+yâ¢âˆ£X>â¢x)=â„™â¢(X>y).
Proof.

By definition of the conditional probability, we have

â„™â¢(X>x+yâ¢âˆ£X>â¢x)=â„™â¢(X>x+y,X>x)â„™â¢(X>x)=â„™â¢(X>x+y)â„™â¢(X>x)=1âˆ’FXâ¢(x+y)1âˆ’FXâ¢(x) =eâˆ’Î»â¢(x+y)eâˆ’Î»â¢x
=eâˆ’Î»â¢y
=â„™â¢(X>y),

where we used {X>x+y}âŠ‚{X>x} for the second equality. âˆ

Remark 2.6.5.

It can be shown that exponential distributions are the only class of continuous probability distributions that is memoryless.

Interpretation: Suppose that X models the waiting time until the occurrence of a random event that arrives at rate Î» and the waiting time is memoryless in the sense above. Then Xâˆ¼Expâ¢(Î»). Equivalently, we may describe an exponential distribution as the distribution of the independent interarrival times underlying the random events counted by a Poisson distribution with rate Î».

Normal distribution

A continuous random variable X is said to be normally distributed with mean Î¼âˆˆâ„ and variance Ïƒ2 for Ïƒ>0, it its pdf is given by

fâ¢(x)=12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ2â¢eâˆ’(xâˆ’Î¼)22â¢Ïƒ2,xâˆˆâ„,

and we write Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2).

Exercise 2.6.6.

Show that f is a pdf.
Hint: Consider (âˆ«â„fâ¢(x)â¢dx)2=âˆ«â„fâ¢(x)â¢dxâ¢âˆ«â„fâ¢(y)â¢dy and use a polar substitution for x and y.

We call ğ’©â¢(0,1) the standard normal distribution and denotes its cdf by Î¦. The cdf cannot be expressed in terms of elementary functions, but efficient numerical approximations are available. We observe that

Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2)âŸ¹Y=a+bâ¢Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(a+bâ¢Î¼,b2â¢Ïƒ2),a,bâˆˆâ„,

since

FYâ¢(x)=â„™â¢(Xâ‰¤(xâˆ’a)/b)=12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ2â¢âˆ«âˆ’âˆ(xâˆ’a)/beâˆ’(yâˆ’Î¼)22â¢Ïƒ2â¢dy=12â¢Ï€â¢b2â¢Ïƒ2â¢âˆ«âˆ’âˆxeâˆ’(zâˆ’(a+bâ¢Î¼))22â¢b2â¢Ïƒ2â¢dz=Fğ’©â¢(a+bâ¢Î¼,b2â¢Ïƒ2)â¢(x).

In particular the normalisation Z=(Xâˆ’Î¼)/Ïƒ of Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2) is standard normal, i.e., Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1). The mgf exists everywhere and is calculated as follows: assume first that Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1). Then

ÏˆZâ¢(t)=12â¢Ï€â¢âˆ«â„etâ¢xâ¢eâˆ’x22â¢dx =12â¢Ï€â¢âˆ«â„etâ¢xâˆ’x22â¢dx
=12â¢Ï€â¢âˆ«â„eâˆ’((xâˆ’t)22âˆ’t22)â¢dx (completing the square)
=et22â¢12â¢Ï€â¢âˆ«â„eâˆ’(xâˆ’t)22â¢dxâŸ=â„™â¢(Yâˆˆâ„)=1â¢Â forÂ â¢Yâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(t,1)
=et22.

For general Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2), we have Xâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢Î¼+Ïƒâ¢Z for some Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1), and hence by the above,

ÏˆXâ¢(t)=ğ”¼â¢[expâ¡(tâ¢(Î¼+Ïƒâ¢Z))]=etâ¢Î¼â¢ğ”¼â¢[expâ¡(tâ¢Ïƒâ¢Z)]=etâ¢Î¼â¢ÏˆZâ¢(Ïƒâ¢t)=eÎ¼â¢t+Ïƒ2â¢t22,tâˆˆâ„.

This gives

ğ”¼â¢[X] =ÏˆXâ€²â¢(0)=(Î¼+Ïƒ2â¢t)|t=0=Î¼
ğ”¼â¢[X2] =ÏˆXâ€²â€²â¢(0)=Ïƒ2+Î¼2âŸ¹Varâ¡(X)=ğ”¼â¢[X2]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X]2=Ïƒ2,

justifying us calling Î¼ the mean and Ïƒ2 the variance of a normal distribution. Recall that the skewness and kurtosis are defined as the third and fourth moment, respectively of the standardised random variable Z=(Xâˆ’Î¼)/Ïƒ.

Exercise 2.6.7.

Show that skewness of a normal random variable Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2) is 0 and its kurtosis is 3.

Interpretation: Many natural phenomena follow approximately a normal distribution, which can be mathematically explained by the Central Limit Theorem, which we will encounter soon.

Chapter 3 Multivariate distributions

3.1 Random vectors

Definition 3.1.1.

Let X1,â€¦,Xn be random variables, all defined on the same probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™). We call X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ an (n-dimensional) random vector.

Note that X:Î©â†’â„n and we will now see that we can equivalently characterise a random vector X as a â„n-valued random variable. The Borel Ïƒ-algebra on â„n is defined analogously to the one-dimensional case,

â„¬â¢(â„n)â‰”Ïƒâ¢({O:Oâ¢Â open inÂ â¢â„n}).
Definition 3.1.2.

An â„n-valued random variable X on (Î©,â„±,â„™) is a measurable mapping between the measurable space (Î©,â„±) and (â„n,â„¬â¢(â„n)), that is, X:Î©â†’â„n and

âˆ€Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„n):Xâˆ’1â¢(B)âˆˆâ„±.

To see the equivalence between both definitions, note that it can be shown that

â„¬â¢(â„n)=Ïƒâ¢(â„¬â¢(â„)Ã—â‹¯Ã—â„¬â¢(â„)âŸnâ¢Â times).

Thus, according to Proposition 2.1.2, to show that a random vector X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ is â„±/â„¬â¢(â„n)-measurable and thereby an â„n-valued random variable, it suffices to show that for any Cartesian product

B=Ã—i=1nBi,B1,â€¦,Bnâˆˆâ„¬(â„),

it holds that Xâˆ’1â¢(B)âˆˆâ„±. This follows from

Xâˆ’1â¢(B1Ã—â‹¯Ã—Bn)={Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:Xiâ¢(Ï‰)âˆˆBiâ¢âˆ€i=1,â€¦,n}=â‹‚i=1nXiâˆ’1â¢(Bi)âŸâˆˆâ„±âˆˆâ„±,

whence any n-dimensional random vector is an â„n-valued random variable. Conversely, if X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ is an â„n-valued random variable, then for any i=1,â€¦,n and Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„),

Xiâˆ’1â¢(B)=Xâˆ’1â¢(â„Ã—â‹¯Ã—BâŸiâ¢-th entryÃ—â‹¯Ã—â„ââˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„n))âˆˆâ„±,

so each of the coordinate mappings Xi is a (â„-valued) random variable on (Î©,â„±,â„™). We cast this observation in a lemma.

Lemma 3.1.3.

Every n-dimensional random vector is an â„n-valued random variable and vice versa.

With this observation, it makes sense to speak of the distribution â„™X of a random vector.

Definition 3.1.4.

We call any probability measure on (â„n,â„¬â¢(â„n)) a multivariate distribution and define the joint distribution â„™X=â„™X1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—Xn of a random vector X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ by the pushforward measure

â„™X1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—Xnâ¢(B)â‰”â„™â¢(Xâˆ’1â¢(B)),Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„n).

In complete analogy to the one-dimensional case it can be shown that this indeed defines a probability measure on (â„n,â„¬â¢(â„n)). We leave the details to you.

Theorem 3.1.5.

The joint distribution of a random vector is a multivariate distribution.

Let us now introduce the natural analogue to a cdf in the multivariate case.

Definition 3.1.6.

Let X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ be a random vector. Its multivariate distribution function FX:â„nâ†’[0,1] is defined by

FXâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â‰”â„™Xâ¢((âˆ’âˆ,x1],â€¦,(âˆ’âˆ,xn])=â„™â¢(X1â‰¤x1,â€¦,Xnâ‰¤xn),x1,â€¦,xnâˆˆâ„.

Moreover, we call â„™Xi the marginal distribution of Xi.

Remark 3.1.7.

Given a multivariate distribution, its marginal distributions are obtained via the relation

â„™Xiâ¢(B)=â„™X1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—Xnâ¢(â„Ã—â‹¯Ã—BâŸiâ¢-th entryÃ—â‹¯Ã—â„).

As in the one-dimensional case, the multivariate cdf uniquely characterises a multivariate distribution.

Theorem 3.1.8.

Suppose that X and Y are two random vectors. Then,

â„™X=â„™Yâ‡”FX=FY.

We can again construct multivariate distributions in terms of an appropriate change of measure. We will be primarily dealing with continuous multivariate distribution, which are constructed via Lebesgue integrals w.r.t.Â the multivariate Lebesgue measure, which is the unique measure on (â„n,â„¬â¢(â„n)) that assigns a hypercuboid its natural volume, i.e.,

Î»nâ¢((a1,b1]Ã—â‹¯Ã—(an,bn])=âˆi=1n(biâˆ’ai)=âˆi=1nÎ»â¢((ai,bi]),ai,biâˆˆâ„â¢Â for allÂ â¢i=1,â€¦,n.
Definition 3.1.9.

We say that a random vector X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ is absolutely continuous, if there exists a non-negative measurable function f:â„nâ†’â„ such that âˆ«â„nfâ¢(x)â¢dxâ‰¡âˆ«â„dfâ¢(x)â¢dÎ»nâ¢(x)=1 and

â„™Xâ¢(B)=âˆ«Bfâ¢(x)â¢dxâ‰¡âˆ«Bfâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢dÎ»nâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn),Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„n).
Remark 3.1.10.

Using the general Proposition 2.2.9, it follows that any such f indeed yields a probability measure.

Next we state the analogue to Theorem 2.3.3 that tells us how to calculate the expectation of the one-dimensional random variable gâ¢(X1,â€¦,Xn) obtained from transforming the random vector with a function g:â„nâ†’â„.

Theorem 3.1.11.

Let X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ be a random vector. Suppose that g:â„nâ†’â„ is a measurable function that is either non-negative or such that âˆ«â„n|gâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)|â¢dâ„™Xâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)<âˆ. Then,

ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X1,â€¦,Xn)]=âˆ«â„ngâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢dâ„™X1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—Xnâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn).

3.1.1 Product measures and Fubiniâ€™s theorem

Calculating such expectations can be very challenging, unless the joint distribution has a fairly nice structure. The essential tool in such situations is Fubiniâ€™s theorem. This, however, first requires the understanding of a product measure, which we will also heavily encounter in the next section on independence. Let (E1,ğ’œ1,Î¼1) and (E2,ğ’œ2,Î¼2) be Ïƒ-finite measure spaces. The product Ïƒ-algebra is defined as

ğ’œ1âŠ—ğ’œ2â‰”Ïƒâ¢(ğ’œ1Ã—ğ’œ2)=Ïƒâ¢({A1Ã—A2:A1âˆˆğ’œ1,A2âˆˆğ’œ2}),

and the product measure Î¼1âŠ—Î¼2 is the unique measure on ğ’œ1âŠ—ğ’œ2 that satisfies

âˆ€A1Ã—A2âˆˆğ’œ1Ã—ğ’œ2:Î¼1âŠ—Î¼2(A1Ã—A2)=Î¼1(A1)Î¼2(A2).

Observe here that we have already encountered such a product measure before: the multivariate Lebesgue measure Î»n.

Fubiniâ€™s theorem now tells us that for product measures and non-negative transformations g, we may always integrate in arbitrary order.

Theorem 3.1.12 (Fubiniâ€™s theorem).

Let (E1,ğ’œ1,Î¼1) and (E2,ğ’œ2,Î¼2) be Ïƒ-finite measure spaces. Let g:E1Ã—E2â†’[0,âˆ) be a measurable function w.r.t.Â the product Ïƒ-algebra ğ’œ1âŠ—ğ’œ2. Then,111it is implicit here that the integrals make sense, that is Fubiniâ€™s theorem also states that xâ†¦âˆ«E2gâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ¼2â¢(y) and yâ†¦âˆ«E1gâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ¼1â¢(x) are measurable

âˆ«E1Ã—E2gâ¢dÎ¼1âŠ—Î¼2=âˆ«E2(âˆ«E1gâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ¼1â¢(x))â¢dÎ¼2â¢(y)=âˆ«E1(âˆ«E2gâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ¼2â¢(y))â¢dÎ¼1â¢(x).

Iterating this theorem yields the following for continuous random vectors.

Corollary 3.1.13.

Let X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ be a random vector with multivariate density f and g:â„nâ†’[0,âˆ) be measurable. Then, for any permutation (i1,â€¦,in) of {1,â€¦,n} it holds that

ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X1,â€¦,Xn)]=âˆ«â„(âˆ«â„(â‹¯â¢âˆ«â„gâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢fâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢dxi1â¢â‹¯)â¢dxinâˆ’1)â¢dxin.
Remark 3.1.14.

Because the order of integration does not matter, in short we may therefore just write

ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X1,â€¦,Xn)]=âˆ«â„ngâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢fâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢dx1â¢â‹¯â¢dxn.

In particular, for any iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n} we get

â„™â¢(XiâˆˆB)=âˆ«B(âˆ«â„nâˆ’1fâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢dx1â¢â‹¯â¢dxiâˆ’1â¢dxi+1â¢â‹¯â¢dxn)â¢dxi,

so the marginal Xi is absolutely continuous with density

fiâ¢(xi)â‰”âˆ«â„nâˆ’1fâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢dx1â¢â‹¯â¢dxiâˆ’1â¢dxi+1â¢â‹¯â¢dxn,xiâˆˆâ„,

which we call the i-th marginal density.

3.1.2 Expectation and covariance

Given a random vector we define its expectation to be the vector of expectations of the marginals.

Definition 3.1.15.

For a random vector X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ with well-defined marginal expectations ğ”¼â¢[Xi], i=1,â€¦,n, its expectation is defined as the vector

ğ”¼â¢[X]â‰”(ğ”¼â¢[X1],â€¦,ğ”¼â¢[Xn])âŠ¤.
Definition 3.1.16.
  1. (i)

    For two random variables X,Y that are defined on the same probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™) and are such that ğ”¼â¢[X2],ğ”¼â¢[Y2]<âˆ, their covariance is defined as

    Covâ¡(X,Y)â‰”ğ”¼â¢[(Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X])â¢(Yâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[Y])].

    If Covâ¡(X,Y)=0 we call X and Y uncorrelated. If Varâ¡X,Varâ¡Y>0, their correlation is defined by

    ÏX,Yâ‰”Covâ¡(X,Y)Varâ¡(X)â¢Varâ¡(Y)=Covâ¡(X,Y)ÏƒXâ¢ÏƒY.
  2. (ii)

    The covariance matrix of a random vector X=(X1,â€¦,Xn) is defined as

    Î£Xâ‰”(Covâ¡(Xi,Xj))i,j=1,â€¦,n=(Covâ¡(X1,X1)â‹¯Covâ¡(X1,Xn)â‹®â‹±â‹®Covâ¡(Xn,X1)â‹¯Covâ¡(Xn,Xn)).
Remark 3.1.17.

We equivalently use the notation Î£Xâ‰¡ğ”¼â¢[(Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X])â¢(Xâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X])âŠ¤].

Exercise 3.1.18.

Show that

  1. (i)

    for any a,bâˆˆâ„, Covâ¡(aâ¢X,bâ¢Y)=aâ¢bâ¢Covâ¡(X,Y).

  2. (ii)

    Covâ¡(X,Y)=0 if X and Y are independent (see next subsection for definition of independence).

  3. (iii)

    ÏX,Yâˆˆ[âˆ’1,1] if the correlation is well-defined.

Exercise 3.1.19.

Suppose that (X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ is a random vector such that ğ”¼â¢[Xi2]<âˆ for all i=1,â€¦,n. Show that

Varâ¡(X1+â‹¯+Xn)=âˆ‘i=1nVarâ¡(Xi)+âˆ‘iâ‰ jCovâ¡(Xi,Xj).

Conclude that Varâ¡(X1+â‹¯+Xn)=âˆ‘i=1nVarâ¡(Xi), if X1,â€¦,Xn are pairwise uncorrelated.

Exercise 3.1.20.

Let X be an n-dimensional random vector. Show that

  1. (i)

    Î£X is positive semi-definite, i.e., for any column vector aâˆˆâ„n it holds that aâŠ¤â¢Î£Xâ¢aâ‰¥0.

  2. (ii)

    for bâˆˆâ„k and Aâˆˆâ„kÃ—n a (kÃ—n)-matrix, it holds that Î£b+Aâ¢X=Aâ¢Î£Xâ¢AâŠ¤.

3.2 Independence

The standard assumption in statistics is the following: we are given n random samples X1,â€¦,Xn that are independent and follow a common distribution P that we wish to infer from the data. The definition of independence of random variables naturally derives from independence of events that we discussed in Chapter 1.

Definition 3.2.1 (Independence of random variables).
  1. (i)

    Let X1,â€¦,Xn be random variables, all defined on the same probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™). We say that X1,â€¦,Xn are independent if

    âˆ€B1,â€¦,Bnâˆˆâ„¬(â„):â„™(X1âˆˆB1,â€¦,XnâˆˆBn)=âˆi=1nâ„™(XiâˆˆBi).

    If additionally â„™X1=â‹¯=â„™Xn we say that X1,â€¦,Xn are i.i.d.Â (independent and identically distributed). We then also call X1,â€¦,Xn an i.i.d.Â sample

  2. (ii)

    A sequence of random variables X1,X2,â€¦ on a common probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™) is defined to be independent (resp., i.i.d) if for any nâˆˆâ„• the random variables X1,â€¦,Xn are independent (resp., i.i.d.).

In terms of the joint distribution and the product distribution, the definition of independence reads equivalently

â„™X1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—Xn(B)=â„™X1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—â„™Xn(B),âˆ€BâˆˆÃ—i=1nâ„¬(â„).

Since Ã—i=1nâ„¬â¢(â„) is a âˆ©-stable generator of â„¬â¢(â„n) and probability measures are uniquely characterised on such, we obtain the following nice formula.

Proposition 3.2.2.

A family of random variables X1,â€¦,Xn is independent if, and only if,

â„™X1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—Xn=â„™X1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—â„™Xn.

Based on this we collect other useful characterisations of independence.

Corollary 3.2.3.

A family of random variables X1,â€¦,Xn is independent if, and only if, for every collection g1,â€¦,gn:â„â†’â„ of measurable, non-negative functions it holds that

ğ”¼â¢[âˆi=1ngiâ¢(Xi)]=âˆi=1nğ”¼â¢[giâ¢(Xi)]. (3.1)
Proof.

Suppose that X1,â€¦,Xn are independent. Then, using Theorem 3.1.11, Proposition 3.2.2 and Fubiniâ€™s theorem, we have

ğ”¼â¢[âˆi=1ngiâ¢(Xi)] =âˆ«â„ng1â¢(x1)â¢â‹¯â¢gnâ¢(xn)â¢dâ„™X1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—â„™Xnâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)
=âˆ«â„nâˆ’1(âˆ«â„g1â¢(x1)â¢âˆi=2ngiâ¢(xi)â¢dâ¢â„™X1â¢(x1))â¢dâ„™X2âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—â„™Xnâ¢(x2,â€¦,xn)
=lin.â¢âˆ«â„nâˆ’1âˆi=2ngiâ¢(xi)â¢(âˆ«â„g1â¢(x1)â¢dâ„™X1â¢(x1))â¢dâ¢â„™X2âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—â„™Xnâ¢(x2,â€¦,xn)
=lin.â¢âˆ«â„g1â¢(x1)â¢dâ„™X1â¢(x1)â¢âˆ«â„nâˆ’1âˆi=2ngiâ¢(xi)â¢dâ¢â„™X2âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—â„™Xnâ¢(x2,â€¦,xn).

Iterating the argument and then using Theorem 2.3.3 yields

ğ”¼â¢[âˆi=1ngiâ¢(Xi)]=âˆi=1nâˆ«â„giâ¢(xi)â¢dâ„™Xiâ¢(xi)=âˆi=1nğ”¼â¢[giâ¢(Xi)].

If conversely (3.1) holds for any collection of non-negative measurable functions, we choose gi=ğŸBi for arbitrary Biâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„) to conclude independence of X1,â€¦,Xn. âˆ

Corollary 3.2.4.

A family of random variables X1,â€¦,Xn is independent if, and only if,

âˆ€x1,â€¦,xnâˆˆâ„:FX1âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—Xn(x1,â€¦,xn)=âˆi=1nFXi(xi).
Proof.

Follows from Proposition 3.2.2 and Theorem 3.1.8. âˆ

Corollary 3.2.5.

If X1,â€¦,Xn are independent and g1,â€¦,gn:â„â†’â„ are measurable functions, then g1â¢(X1),â€¦,gnâ¢(Xn) are independent as well.

Proof.

Exercise! âˆ

Corollary 3.2.6.

Suppose that X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ is a continuous random vector with multivariate density f and marginal densities fi. Then, X1,â€¦,Xn are independent if, and only if, for Î»n-a.e.Â xâˆˆâ„n we have

fâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)=âˆi=1nfiâ¢(xi).

Our final corollary of this section pertains to sums of independent random variables, which we will encounter frequently in the next chapters.

Corollary 3.2.7.

If X1,â€¦,Xn are independent, then for the mgf of âˆ‘i=1nXi it holds that

Ïˆâˆ‘i=1nXiâ¢(t)=âˆi=1nÏˆXiâ¢(t),tâˆˆâ„.

In particular, if X1,â€¦,Xn are i.i.d.Â with â„™Xi=â„™X for all i, we have

Ïˆâˆ‘i=1nXiâ¢(t)=(ÏˆXâ¢(t))n.
Proof.

Exercise! âˆ

Example 3.2.8 (Revisiting the binomial distribution).

When we introduced the binomial distribution Binâ¢(n,p), we interpreted it as modeling the number of successes in n independent Bernoulli trials, without having a meaningful definition of independence at hand. We can make this precise now: let X1,â€¦,Xn be i.i.d.Â random variables such that X1âˆ¼â„¬â¢(p). Then, ÏˆXiâ¢(t)=pâ¢et+1âˆ’p and by Corollary 3.2.7 it follows that

ÏˆX1+â‹¯+Xnâ¢(t)=(pâ¢et+1âˆ’p)n=ÏˆXâ¢(t),tâˆˆâ„,

where Xâˆ¼Binâ¢(n,p). Since by Theorem 2.4.10 the mgf uniquely characterises the distribution of a random variable it follows that

X1+â‹¯+Xnâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢X.
Exercise 3.2.9.

Suppose that X,Y are independent and continuous random variables with densities fX,fY respectively. Show that the density fX+Y of X+Y is given by the convolution

fX+Yâ¢(z)=fXâˆ—fYâ¢(z)â‰”âˆ«â„fXâ¢(x)â¢fYâ¢(zâˆ’x)â¢dx,zâˆˆâ„.
Exercise 3.2.10.

Let Î»1,Î»2>0 and let X1âˆ¼Expâ¡(Î»1) and X2âˆ¼Expâ¡(Î»2) be independent. Show that minâ¡{X1,X2}âˆ¼Expâ¡(Î»1+Î»2).

Exercise 3.2.11.

Let X1âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼1,Ïƒ12) and X2âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼2,Ïƒ22) be independent. Show that X1+X2âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼1+Î¼2,Ïƒ12+Ïƒ22).

3.2.1 Multivariate normal distribution

Definition 3.2.12.

Let Î¼âˆˆâ„n and Î£âˆˆâ„nÃ—n be a symmetric positive semi-definite matrix. A random vector X=(X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ is defined to have a multivariate normal (or Gaussian) distribution with mean vector Î¼ and covariance matrix Î£, if for any real numbers a1,â€¦,an,

aâŠ¤â¢X=âˆ‘i=1aiâ¢Xiâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(aâŠ¤â¢Î¼,aâŠ¤â¢Î£â¢a)=ğ’©â¢(âˆ‘i=1naiâ¢Î¼i,âˆ‘i,j=1naiâ¢ajâ¢Î£i,j).

It is immediate from this definition that every entry Xi of a multivariate normal vector is normally distributed as well with Xiâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼i,Î£i,i). It is important to remember however that if we are given Xiâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Ïƒi2), i=1,â€¦,n, then (X1,â€¦,Xn)âŠ¤ is not necessarily a multivariate random vector. If Î¼=0 and Î£=ğ•€n is the identity, i.e., Covâ¡(Xi,Xj)=ğŸ{i}â¢(j), Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,ğ•€n) is called a standard normal random vector.

Multivariate normal distributions can always be generated by linearly transforming a standard normal random vector. Let Î£1/2âˆˆâ„nÃ—n denote the symmetric square root of a covariance matrix Î£, that is Î£=Î£1/2â¢Î£1/2=Î£1/2â¢(Î£1/2)âŠ¤ (the square root always exists because we have seen that covariance matrices are symmetric positive semi-definite).

Theorem 3.2.13.

Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Î£) if, and only if, Xâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢Î¼+Î£1/2â¢Z for a standard normal random vector Z.

For the proof we use the fact that the distribution of a random vector is uniquely characterised by the distributions of all linear combinations of its components, which can be proven via multivariate characteristic functions (not part of this module).

Theorem 3.2.14.

For two n-dimensional random vectors X and Y it holds that

Xâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢Yâ‡”âˆ€aâˆˆâ„n:aâŠ¤â¢Xâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢aâŠ¤â¢Y.
Proof of Theorem 3.2.13.

By the previous theorem it suffices to check that aâŠ¤â¢Xâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢aâŠ¤â¢(Î¼+Î£1/2â¢Z) for any aâˆˆâ„n and some Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,ğ•€n). By definition of X and Z it holds that aâŠ¤â¢Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(aâŠ¤â¢Î¼,aâŠ¤â¢Î£â¢a) and

aâŠ¤â¢(Î¼+Î£1/2â¢Z)=aâŠ¤â¢Î¼+aâŠ¤â¢Î£1/2â¢ZâŸâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,aâŠ¤â¢Î£1/2â¢(aâŠ¤â¢Î£1/2)âŠ¤)=ğ’©â¢(0,aâŠ¤â¢Î£1/2â¢(Î£1/2)âŠ¤â¢a)=ğ’©â¢(0,aâŠ¤â¢Î£â¢a)âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(aâŠ¤â¢Î¼,aâŠ¤â¢Î£â¢a),

whence aâŠ¤â¢Xâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢aâŠ¤â¢(Î¼+Î£1/2â¢Z). âˆ

Corollary 3.2.15.

If Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Î£), then Covâ¡(Xi,Xj)=Î£i,j.

Using a multivariate extension of the moment generating function, the following can be established, which is a unique feature of normal random vectors.

Theorem 3.2.16.

Let Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Î£) be an n-dimensional normal random vector. Then X1,â€¦,Xn are independent, if, and only if, Î£=ğ•€n.

Remark 3.2.17.

In other words, for the components of a normal random vector to be independent, it suffices to check that they are pairwise uncorrelated.

By Theorem 3.2.16 we know that the multivariate density of a standard normal random vector Z is given by

fZâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)=âˆi=1nfZiâ¢(xi)=âˆi=1n12â¢Ï€â¢eâˆ’xi2/2=1(2â¢Ï€)n/2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nxi22)=1(2â¢Ï€)n/2â¢expâ¡(âˆ’âˆ¥xâˆ¥22).

Using the transformation formula from real analysis and Theorem 3.2.13 it can then be shown that for general Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Î£) with invertible Î£, the density is given by

fXâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)=fÎ¼+Î£1/2â¢Zâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)=1(2â¢Ï€)nâ¢detâ¡Î£â¢expâ¡(âˆ’12â¢(xâˆ’Î¼)âŠ¤â¢Î£âˆ’1â¢(xâˆ’Î¼)),xâˆˆâ„n.

3.2.2 Univariate distributions related to independent random variables

Gamma distribution

We say that a continuous random variable X has a Gamma distribution with shape parameter Î± and scale parameter Î²>0, if its density is given by

fÎ±,Î²â¢(x)=Î²Î±Î“â¢(Î±)â¢xÎ±âˆ’1â¢eâˆ’Î²â¢xâ¢ğŸ(0,âˆ)â¢(x),

where

Î“â¢(z)â‰”âˆ«(0,âˆ)xzâˆ’1â¢eâˆ’xâ¢dx,z>0,

is the Gamma function, which is easily shown to satisfy Î“â¢(1)=1 and the recurrence relation

Î“â¢(z+1)=zâ¢Î“â¢(z),z>0.

Moreover, for later use we note that Î“â¢(1/2)=Ï€ since substituting x=y2 (â†dx=2ydy) yields

Î“â¢(1/2)=âˆ«(0,âˆ)xâˆ’1/2â¢eâˆ’xâ¢dx=âˆ«0âˆ1yâ¢eâˆ’y2â¢2â¢yâ¢dy=2â¢âˆ«0âˆeâˆ’y2â¢dy=âˆ«â„eâˆ’y2â¢dy=Ï€.

We then write Xâˆ¼Î“â¢(Î±,Î²). We first note that for Î±=1, the Gamma distribution coincides with an exponential distribution, that is, Î“â¢(1,Î²)=Expâ¢(Î²). As it turns out, for Î±âˆˆâ„• the Gamma distribution is the distribution of the sum of i.i.d.Â exponential random variables. More precisely, the mgf of Xâˆ¼Î“â¢(Î±,Î²) exists for all t<Î² and is obtained from the following calculation for t<Î²:

ÏˆXâ¢(t) =Î²Î±Î“â¢(Î±)â¢âˆ«(0,âˆ)etâ¢xâ¢xÎ±âˆ’1â¢eâˆ’Î²â¢xâ¢dx
=Î²Î±Î“â¢(Î±)â¢âˆ«(0,âˆ)xÎ±âˆ’1â¢eâˆ’(Î²âˆ’t)â¢xâ¢dx
=Î²Î±Î“â¢(Î±)â¢âˆ«(0,âˆ)(y/(Î²âˆ’t))Î±âˆ’1â¢eâˆ’yâ¢1Î²âˆ’tâ¢dy (substitution y=(Î²âˆ’t)â¢x)
=(Î²Î²âˆ’t)Î±â¢1Î“â¢(Î±)â¢âˆ«(0,âˆ)yÎ±âˆ’1â¢eâˆ’yâ¢dyâŸ=â„™â¢(Y>0)=1â¢Â forÂ â¢Yâˆ¼Î“â¢(Î±,1)
=(Î²Î²âˆ’t)Î±.

This implies that if Xâˆ¼Î“â¢(Î±,Î²) and Yâˆ¼Î“â¢(Î³,Î²) are independent, then

ÏˆX+Yâ¢(t)=ÏˆXâ¢(t)â¢ÏˆYâ¢(t)=(Î²Î²âˆ’t)Î±+Î³=ÏˆÎ“â¢(Î±+Î³,Î²),t<Î²,

and therefore X+Yâˆ¼Î“â¢(Î±+Î³,Î²) by Theorem 2.4.10. Iterating this argument for n i.i.d.Â Expâ¢(Î²)=Î“â¢(1,Î²) distributed random variables, yields âˆ‘i=1nXiâˆ¼Î“â¢(n,Î²). We cast this formally into a proposition.

Proposition 3.2.18.

Let Î±,Î³,Î²>0. If Xâˆ¼Î“â¢(Î±,Î²) and Yâˆ¼Î“â¢(Î³,Î²) are independent, then X+Yâˆ¼Î“â¢(Î±+Î³,Î²). In particular, if X1,â€¦,Xn are i.i.d.Â with X1âˆ¼Expâ¡(Î²) for some Î²>0, then âˆ‘i=1nXiâˆ¼Î“â¢(n,Î²).

Ï‡2-distribution

The Ï‡2-distribution plays an important role in statistical test theory. Its definition derives from the following observation.

Lemma 3.2.19.

If Xâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1), then X2âˆ¼Î“â¢(1/2,1/2).

Proof.

Let gâ‰¥0 be a measurable function. Then, by the transformation theorem

ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(X2)] =12â¢Ï€â¢âˆ«â„gâ¢(x2)â¢eâˆ’x22â¢dx
=2Ï€â¢âˆ«(0,âˆ)gâ¢(x2)â¢eâˆ’x22â¢dx
=2Ï€â¢âˆ«(0,âˆ)gâ¢(y)â¢eâˆ’y/2â¢12â¢yâ¢dy (substitution y=x2)
=âˆ«(0,âˆ)gâ¢(y)â¢(1/2)1/2Î“â¢(1/2)â¢y1/2âˆ’1â¢eâˆ’y/2â¢dy (Î“â¢(1/2)=Ï€)
=ğ”¼â¢[gâ¢(Y)],

for Yâˆ¼Î“â¢(1/2,1/2). âˆ

Definition 3.2.20.

The Ï‡2-distribution with n degrees of freedom is defined by Ï‡n2=Î“â¢(n/2,1/2), so that the density and mgf of Xâˆ¼Ï‡n2 are respectively given by

fâ¢(x)=12n/2â¢Î“â¢(n/2)â¢xn/2âˆ’1â¢eâˆ’x/2â¢ğŸ(0,âˆ)â¢(x),

and

ÏˆXâ¢(t)=1(1âˆ’2â¢t)n/2,t<1/2.

Combining the previous lemma and Proposition 3.2.18 yields the following.

Theorem 3.2.21.

If X1,â€¦,Xn are i.i.d.Â and X1âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1), then

âˆ‘i=1nXi2âˆ¼Ï‡n2.

3.3 Conditional distributions and expectations

We now introduce conditional distributions and expectations. The general measure theoretic route would go via specifying conditional expectations first and then define conditional distributions from there. For the purposes of this module, we donâ€™t need that sort of generality and will rather start with introducing the notion of a conditional distribution in a restricted setting.

Let us therefore assume in this section that X is an n-dimensional random vector and Y is an m-dimensional random vector such that their joint distribution can be expressed as

â„™X,Yâ¢(B)=âˆ«BfX,Yâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ¼âŠ—Î½â¢(x,y)â¢=Fubiniâ¢âˆ«BfX,Yâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)â¢dÎ½â¢(y),Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„n+1),

for some dominating product measure Î¼âŠ—Î½ (Î¼,Î½ Ïƒ-finite). If both Î¼ and Î½ are Lebesgue measures, (X,Y) would simply be absolutely continuous, but with the above we also allow situations where X is continuous, Y is discrete, etc. We let

fXâ¢(x)â‰”âˆ«â„mfX,Yâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ½â¢(y),fYâ¢(y)â‰”âˆ«â„nfX,Yâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x),

be the marginal densities of X and Y, respectively.

Inspired by the definition of conditional probability from Chapter 1, we then introduce the conditional density of X given Y=y as

fXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£y)â‰”{fX,Yâ¢(x,y)fYâ¢(y),fYâ¢(y)â‰ 00.else

and define the conditional distribution of X given Y=y via

â„™Xâˆ£Y=yâ¢(B)â‰”âˆ«BfXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£y)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x),Bâˆˆâ„n.

Note that for any y such that fYâ¢(y)â‰ 0, â„™Xâˆ£Y=y is indeed a distribution because then

â„™Xâˆ£Y=yâ¢(â„n)=1fXâ¢(x)â¢âˆ«â„nfX,Yâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)âŸ=fXâ¢(x)=1.

If n=1, i.e., X is a random variable, we define

ğ”¼â¢[Xâˆ£Y=y]â‰”âˆ«â„xâ¢dâ„™Xâˆ£Y=yâ¢(x)=âˆ«â„xâ¢fXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£y)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x),yâˆˆâ„m,

as the conditional expectation of X given Y=y provided that ğ”¼â¢[|X|]<âˆ (check that the integral on the rhs is then well-defined!). If we understand this as a function, i.e.Â yâ†¦gâ¢(y)=ğ”¼â¢[Xâˆ£Y=y], the conditional expectation given Y=y then induces a random variable by plugging in,

ğ”¼â¢[Xâˆ£Y]â‰”gâ¢(Y)=âˆ«â„xâ¢fXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£Y)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x),providedÂ â¢ğ”¼â¢[|X|]<âˆ.

that we call the conditional expectation of X given Y. This now also motivates the the definition of the conditional distribution of X given Y, â„™Xâˆ£Y, which is defined via

â„™Xâˆ£Yâ¢(B)â‰”âˆ«BfXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£Y)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x),Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„n),

such that (for n=1) ğ”¼â¢[Xâˆ£Y]=âˆ«â„xâ¢dâ„™Xâˆ£Yâ¢(x). Conceptually, it is important to acknowledge that

  1. (i)

    for any Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„n), â„™Xâˆ£Yâ¢(B) is again a random variable;

  2. (ii)

    Bâ†¦â„™Xâˆ£Yâ¢(B) is a probability measure â„™-a.s.,222this is because for any Ï‰âˆ‰{Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:fY(Y(Ï‰))=0)}â‰•N, Bâ†¦â„™Xâˆ£Yâ¢(B)â¢(Ï‰) is a probability distribution and â„™â¢(N)=âˆ«{fY=0}fYâ¢(y)â¢dÎ½â¢(y)=0.

which is why we call it a random probability measure.

We now state Bayesâ€™ formula (recall the one for events from Chapter 1), which is at the heart of Bayesian statistics.

Theorem 3.3.1 (Bayesâ€™ formula).

It holds that

fYâˆ£Xâ¢(yâˆ£x)âŸposterior density=fXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£y)â¢fYâ¢(y)âprior densityfXâ¢(x),fXâ¢(x)>0,fYâ¢(y)>0.
Proof.

If x,y are such that fXâ¢(x),fYâ¢(y)>0, then

fYâˆ£Xâ¢(yâˆ£x)â¢fXâ¢(x)=fX,Yâ¢(x,y)=fXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£y)â¢fYâ¢(y).

âˆ

For completeness, we also give some important properties of the conditional expectation, which we justify in the appendix.

Proposition 3.3.2.

Let X,X1,X2,Y be as above s.t.Â ğ”¼â¢[|X|],ğ”¼â¢[|Xi|]<âˆ, i=1,2.

  1. (i)

    For any Î±,Î²âˆˆâ„ we have the â„™-a.s.Â equality

    ğ”¼â¢[Î±â¢X1+Î²â¢X2âˆ£Y]=Î±â¢ğ”¼â¢[X1âˆ£Y]+Î²â¢ğ”¼â¢[X2âˆ£Y]. (Linearity)
  2. (ii)
    ğ”¼â¢[ğ”¼â¢[Xâˆ£Y]]=ğ”¼â¢[X]. (tower property)
  3. (iii)

    if X and Y are independent,333similarly to random variables, if X, Y are n and m-dimensional random vectors, respectively, they are said to be independent if â„™â¢(XâˆˆB1,YâˆˆB2)=â„™â¢(XâˆˆB1)â¢â„™â¢(YâˆˆB2) for any Borel sets B1,B2, which is equivalent to the factorisation identity fX,Yâ¢(x,y)=fXâ¢(x)â¢fYâ¢(y) a.e.Â w.r.t.Â their dominating measure. then ğ”¼â¢[Xâˆ£Y]=ğ”¼â¢[X], â„™-a.s.

Chapter 4 Asymptotic Theory

4.1 Convergence of random variables

4.1.1 Convergence concepts

Definition 4.1.1.

Let X be a random variable and (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• be a sequence of random variables that are all defined on a common probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™). We say that

  1. (i)

    (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• converges almost surely to X, if

    â„™(limnâ†’âˆXn=X)=1(â‡”â„™({Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:limnâ†’âˆXn(Ï‰)=X(Ï‰)})=1.)

    We then write Xnâ¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢X.

  2. (ii)

    given a real number pâ‰¥1, (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• converges in p-th mean to X, if

    ğ”¼â¢[|Xnâˆ’X|p]â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0.

    We then write Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„’pâ¢0.

  3. (iii)

    (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• converges in probability to X, if

    âˆ€Îµ>0:â„™(|Xnâˆ’X|â‰¥Îµ)âŸ¶nâ†’âˆ0(â‡”âˆ€Îµ>0:â„™(|Xnâˆ’X|<Îµ)âŸ¶nâ†’âˆ1).

    We then write Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢X.

Let us state some important relations between the different convergence concepts.

Theorem 4.1.2.

The following implications hold:

  1. (i)

    Xnâ¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢XâŸ¹Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢X

  2. (ii)

    Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„’pâ¢XâŸ¹Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢X

  3. (iii)

    if 1â‰¤r<s, then Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„’sâ¢XâŸ¹Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„’râ¢X.

The reverse implications generally do not hold.

Proof.
  1. (i)

    Let Î›â‰”{Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:limnâ†’âˆXnâ¢(Ï‰)=Xâ¢(Ï‰)}. Then, by the assumption Xnâ¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢X, we have â„™â¢(Î›c)=0. Let Îµ be arbitrarily chosen. Since ğŸ{|Xnâˆ’X|}â‰¥Îµâ¢ğŸÎ›â‰¤1 for any nâˆˆâ„•. Moreover, by definition of Î›,

    âˆ€Ï‰âˆˆÎ›:limnâ†’âˆğŸ{|Xnâ¢(Ï‰)âˆ’Xâ¢(Ï‰)|â‰¥Îµ}=0, (4.1)

    which shows that

    ğŸ{|Xnâˆ’X|â‰¥Îµ}â¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢0.

    We therefore obtain from dominated convergence (cf.Â Theorem 2.2.8) that

    limnâ†’âˆâ„™â¢(|Xnâˆ’X|â‰¥Îµ) =limnâ†’âˆğ”¼â¢[ğŸ{|Xnâˆ’X|â‰¥Îµ}]=ğ”¼â¢[limnâ†’âˆğŸ{|Xnâˆ’X|â‰¥Îµ}]=0.

    Since Îµ>0 was arbitrary, this shows Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢X.

  2. (ii)

    We use Markovâ€™s inequality (Theorem 2.4.5) with the strictly increasing function Ï†â¢(x)=xp, xâ‰¥0. Then, for any Îµ>0

    â„™â¢(|Xnâˆ’X|â‰¥Îµ)â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[Ï†â¢(|Xâˆ’Xn|)]Ï†â¢(Îµ)=ğ”¼â¢[|Xnâˆ’X|p]Îµpâ¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0.
  3. (iii)

    Using HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality (Theorem 2.4.2) with p=s/r and q=s/rs/râˆ’1 (note that then 1/p+1/q=1),

    ğ”¼â¢[|Xnâˆ’X|r]=ğ”¼â¢[|Xnâˆ’X|râ‹…1]â‰¤(ğ”¼â¢[(|Xnâˆ’X|r)s/r])r/sâ¢(ğ”¼â¢[1q])1/q=(ğ”¼â¢[|Xnâˆ’X|s])r/sâ¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0.

âˆ

Theorem 4.1.3 (Continuous mapping theorem).

Let Ï†:â„â†’â„ be a continuous function.

  1. (i)

    Xnâ¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢XâŸ¹Ï†â¢(Xn)â¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢Ï†â¢(X).

  2. (ii)

    Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢XâŸ¹Ï†â¢(Xn)â¢âŸ¶â„™â¢Ï†â¢(X).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    Let again Î›â‰”{Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:limnâ†’âˆXnâ¢(Ï‰)=Xâ¢(Ï‰)} such that by assumption, â„™â¢(Î›)=1. By continuity of Ï†,

    âˆ€Ï‰âˆˆÎ›:limnâ†’âˆÏ†â¢(Xnâ¢(Ï‰))=Ï†â¢(limnâ†’âˆXnâ¢(Ï‰))=Ï†â¢(Xâ¢(Ï‰)).

    Thus, Î›âŠ‚{limnâ†’âˆÏ†â¢(Xn)=Ï†â¢(X)} and therefore â„™â¢(limnâ†’âˆÏ†â¢(Xn)=Ï†â¢(X))â‰¥â„™â¢(Î›)=1.

  2. (ii)

    For simplicity we only give the proof for the case that Ï† is uniformly continuous, that is for any Îµ>0 there exists Î´>0 such that

    âˆ€x,yâˆˆâ„:|xâˆ’y|<Î´âŸ¹|Ï†(x)âˆ’Ï†(y)|<Îµ.

    Let Îµ>0 be given. Since Ï† is uniformly continuous, there exists Î´>0 such that |Ï†â¢(Xnâ¢(Ï‰))âˆ’Ï†â¢(Xâ¢(Ï‰))|<Îµ, whenever |Xnâ¢(Ï‰)âˆ’Xâ¢(Ï‰)|<Î´, which implies {|Xnâˆ’X|<Î´}âŠ‚{|Ï†â¢(Xn)âˆ’Ï†â¢(X)|<Îµ} and therefore

    â„™â¢(|Xnâˆ’X|<Î´)â‰¤â„™â¢(|Ï†â¢(Xn)âˆ’Ï†â¢(X)|<Îµ).

    By our assumption that Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢X, it follows that â„™â¢(|Xnâˆ’X|<Î´)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢1, and thus by the above also â„™â¢(|Ï†â¢(Xn)âˆ’Ï†â¢(X)|<Îµ)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢1. Since Îµ>0 was arbitrary, this shows Ï†â¢(Xn)â¢âŸ¶â„™â¢Ï†â¢(X).

âˆ

4.1.2 The Law of Large Numbers

For a given sample X1,â€¦,Xn we call
