XÂ¯nâ‰”1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi

the sample mean. If, ğ”¼â¢[X1]=â‹¯=ğ”¼â¢[Xn]=Î¼, the sample mean is an unbiased estimator of the expectation Î¼ in the sense that ğ”¼â¢[XÂ¯n]=Î¼. For i.i.d.Â data with second moment, we obtain convergence of the sample mean in â„’2.

Proposition 4.1.4 (â„’2-version of the LLN).

Let (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• be an i.i.d.Â sequence of random variables such that ğ”¼â¢[|X1|2]<âˆ. Then, for Î¼â‰”ğ”¼â¢[X1] and Ïƒ2â‰”Varâ¡(X1) it holds that

ğ”¼â¢[|1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXiâˆ’Î¼|2]=Ïƒ2n,

and hence in particular,

1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXiâ¢âŸ¶â„’2â¢Î¼.
Proof.

Using Exercise 2.4.4 and Exercise 3.1.19 we find for the i.i.d.Â sample X1,â€¦,Xn that

Varâ¡(1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi)=1n2â¢Varâ¡(âˆ‘i=1nXi)=1n2â¢(âˆ‘i=1nVarâ¡(Xi)âŸ=nâ¢Varâ¡(X1)â¢Â sinceÂ â¢â„™Xi=â„™Xj+âˆ‘iâ‰ jCovâ¡(Xi,Xj)âŸ=0â¢Â by independence)=1nâ¢Varâ¡(X1). (4.2)

Therefore,

ğ”¼â¢[|1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXiâˆ’Î¼|2]=ğ”¼â¢[|1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXiâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi]|2]=Varâ¡(1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi)=Varâ¡(X1)nâ¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0.

âˆ

The strong Law of Large Numbers (LLN) now states that for an i.i.d.Â sample, just the existence of the expectation is sufficient to get almost sure convergence to it.

Theorem 4.1.5 (strong LLN).

Let (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• be an i.i.d.Â sequence of random variables such that ğ”¼â¢[|X1|]<âˆ. Then, for Î¼â‰”ğ”¼â¢[X1] it holds that

1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXiâ¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢Î¼.

The full proof of the strong LLN is rather involved and unfortunately out of scope of these lectures. We therefore only give a fairly compact proof under the additional (but not necessary!) assumption that the samples have finite fourth moment. To this end, we need the following, which is a direct consequence of the Borelâ€“Cantelli lemma (see appendix).

Lemma 4.1.6.

Let Y be a random variable and (Yn)nâˆˆâ„• be a sequence of random variables on a common probability space (Î©,â„±,â„™). Then,

âˆ‘n=1âˆâ„™â¢(|Ynâˆ’Y|>Îµ)â¢<âˆâ¢Â for allÂ â¢Îµ>â¢0âŸ¹Ynâ¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢Y.
Proof of LLN when fourth moment is finite.

Assume additionally that ğ”¼â¢[X14]<âˆ. By the previous lemma it suffices to check that

âˆ€Îµ>0:âˆ‘n=1âˆâ„™â¢(|XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼|>Îµ)<âˆ, (4.3)

where XÂ¯n=nâˆ’1â¢âˆ‘i=1nXi, Î¼=ğ”¼â¢[X1]. Fix Îµ>0. Using Markovâ€™s inequality and the assumption ğ”¼â¢[X14]<âˆ, it follows that

â„™â¢(|XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼|>Îµ) â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[|XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼|4]Îµ4.

Let Yi=Xiâˆ’Î¼. Then, for any i,j,k,lâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n} with iâˆ‰{j,k,l} we get by independence and ğ”¼â¢[Yi]=0 that

ğ”¼â¢[Yiâ¢Yjâ¢Ykâ¢Yl]=ğ”¼â¢[Yi]â¢ğ”¼â¢[Yjâ¢Ykâ¢Yl]=0,

and therefore

ğ”¼â¢[|XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼|4] =1n4â¢âˆ‘i,j,k,l=1nğ”¼â¢[Yiâ¢Yjâ¢Ykâ¢Yl]
=1n4â¢(âˆ‘i=1nğ”¼â¢[Yi4]+(42)â¢âˆ‘iâ‰ jğ”¼â¢[Yi2â¢Yj2])
=1n4â¢(nâ¢ğ”¼â¢[Y14]+3â¢nâ¢(nâˆ’1)â¢ğ”¼â¢[Y12]2).

Consequently,

â„™â¢(|XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼|>Îµ)â‰¤nâ¢ğ”¼â¢[Y14]+3â¢nâ¢(nâˆ’1)â¢ğ”¼â¢[Y12]2Îµ4â¢n4â‰¤4â¢ğ”¼â¢[Y14]Îµ4â¢n2,

which yields

âˆ‘n=1âˆâ„™â¢(|XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼|>Îµ)â‰¤4â¢ğ”¼â¢[Y14]Îµ4â¢âˆ‘n=1âˆ1n2<âˆ.

This proves (4.3) and therefore establishes

XÂ¯nâ¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢ğ”¼â¢[X1].

âˆ

Let us also note that the strong LLN is not the strongest version: for instance, it is sufficient to require pairwise independence of the identically distributed samples (Etemadiâ€™s LLN).

4.2 Convergence in distribution

The previous convergence concepts for random variables express in different ways the idea that Xnâ†’X if Xn and X are close to another with increasing probability as nâ†’âˆ. In many situations, this concept is however too strong. Consider for e.g.Â the case that we choose Xâˆ¼ğ’°â¢([0,1]) and Xn=1âˆ’X for all n. Then Xnâˆ¼ğ’°â¢([0,1]) for all n, but for any Îµ>0,

â„™â¢(|Xnâˆ’X|<Îµ)=â„™â¢(|2â¢Xâˆ’1|<Îµ)â†’Ì¸1.

So although â„™X=â„™Xn, i.e., the distributions are identical, the previous convergence concepts cannot catch this intimate relationship. We therefore aim at a convergence concept that expresses the idea that Xnâ†’X if â„™Xnâ†’â„™X in some appropriate sense.

Definition 4.2.1.

Let X be a random variable and (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• be a sequence of random variables. We say that (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• converges in distribution to X if for any point of continuity111that is, limyâ†’xFXâ¢(y)=x xâˆˆâ„ of FX, it holds that

limnâ†’âˆFXnâ¢(x)=FXâ¢(x).

We then write Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X.

Letâ€™s have a look at the continuity requirement in the above definition. Consider the sequence Xn=1n (that is, Xnâ¢(Ï‰)=1/n for all Ï‰âˆˆÎ©). Then Xnâ¢(Ï‰)â†’0â‰•X for any Ï‰âˆˆÎ©, so we would certainly want Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢0 for convergence in distribution to be a meaningful concept. Since FXnâ¢(x)=ğŸ[1/n,âˆ)â¢(x) and FX=ğŸ[0,âˆ)â¢(x), we have at the discontinuity point 0 of FX that

FXnâ¢(0)=0â‰ 1=FXâ¢(0),

and therefore FXnâ¢(0)â†’Ì¸FXâ¢(0). This illustrates why we do not want to factor in discontinuity points of the limiting cdf.

We now state an equivalent and very useful alternative characterisation of convergence in distribution. We let

ğ’â¢(â„)â‰”{g:â„â†’â„:gâ¢Â continuous},ğ’bâ¢(â„)â‰”{g:â„â†’â„:gâ¢Â continuous and bounded}.
Theorem 4.2.2.

We have Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X if, and only if,

âˆ€gâˆˆğ’b(â„):ğ”¼[g(Xn)]âŸ¶nâ†’âˆğ”¼[g(X)].
Corollary 4.2.3 (Continuous mapping).

Let Ï†âˆˆğ’â¢(â„). Then,

Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢XâŸ¹Ï†â¢(Xn)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Ï†â¢(X).
Proof.

Choose an arbitrary gâˆˆğ’bâ¢(â„). Since g and Ï† are continuous, so is gâˆ˜Ï†; and since g is bounded, the same is also true for gâˆ˜Ï†. Thus, gâˆ˜Ï†âˆˆğ’bâ¢(â„) and Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X implies that

ğ”¼[g(Ï†(Xn)]âŸ¶nâ†’âˆğ”¼[g(Ï†(X)].

Since g was arbitrary, this gives Ï†â¢(Xn)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X. âˆ

Exercise 4.2.4.

Suppose that Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X. Show that for aâˆˆâ„ then aâ¢Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢aâ¢X and Xn+aâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X+a.

Theorem 4.2.5.

The following hold:

  1. (i)

    Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢XâŸ¹Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X.

  2. (ii)

    If Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢c for some constant câˆˆâ„, then Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢c.

Proof.
  1. (i)

    Let x be a continuity point of FX. We need to show FXnâ¢(x)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢FXâ¢(x). To this end, let Îµ>0 be arbitrarily chosen and observe that

    {Xâ‰¤xâˆ’Îµ}âˆ©{Xn>x}âŠ‚{|Xnâˆ’X|>Îµ}, (4.4)

    which implies

    FXâ¢(xâˆ’Îµ)=â„™â¢(Xâ‰¤xâˆ’Îµ) =â„™â¢(Xâ‰¤xâˆ’Îµ,Xn>x)+â„™â¢(Xâ‰¤xâˆ’Îµ,Xnâ‰¤x)
    â‰¤â„™â¢(Xâ‰¤xâˆ’Îµ,Xn>x)+â„™â¢(Xnâ‰¤x)
    â‰¤â„™â¢(|Xnâˆ’X|>Îµ)+FXnâ¢(x) (by (4.4))

    Thus, taking nâ†’âˆ and using that by assumption â„™â¢(|Xnâˆ’X|>Îµ)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0, it follows that

    FXâ¢(xâˆ’Îµ)â‰¤lim infnâ†’âˆFXnâ¢(x),

    and thus, using that x was chosen such that FXâ¢(xâˆ’)=FXâ¢(x),

    FXâ¢(x)=FXâ¢(xâˆ’)=limÎµâ†“0FXâ¢(xâˆ’Îµ)â‰¤lim infnâ†’âˆFXnâ¢(x).

    In the same way, we can show that

    FXâ¢(x+Îµ)â‰¥lim supnâ†’âˆFXnâ¢(x),

    and thus by right-continuity of FX,

    FXâ¢(x)=limÎµâ†“0FXâ¢(x+Îµ)â‰¥lim supnâ†’âˆFXnâ¢(x).

    Combining both estimates,

    FXâ¢(x)â‰¤lim infnâ†’âˆFXnâ¢(x)â‰¤lim supnâ†’âˆFXnâ¢(x)â‰¤FXâ¢(x),

    which implies limnâ†’âˆFXnâ¢(x)=FXâ¢(x).

  2. (ii)

    Fix Îµ>0. We have {|Xnâˆ’c|>Îµ}={Xn>c+Îµ}âŠ{Xn<câˆ’Îµ} and câˆ’Îµ,c+Îµ are continuity points of FX for Xâ‰¡c. Since Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢c it follows that

    â„™â¢(|Xnâˆ’c|>Îµ) =â„™â¢(Xn>c+Îµ)+â„™â¢(Xn<câˆ’Îµ)
    â‰¤1âˆ’FXnâ¢(c+Îµ)+FXnâ¢(câˆ’Îµ)
    âŸ¶1âˆ’FXâ¢(c+Îµ)+FXâ¢(câˆ’Îµ)
    =1âˆ’1+0=0,

    where we used for the last line that FXâ¢(x)=ğŸ[c,âˆ)â¢(x). Since Îµ>0 was arbitrary, this shows Xnâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢c.

âˆ

Theorem 4.2.6 (Slutskyâ€™s theorem).

Let X,X1,X2,â€¦ and Y1,Y2,â€¦ be random variables on a common probability space such that Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X and Ynâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢c for some câˆˆâ„. Then,

  1. (i)

    Xn+Ynâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X+c.

  2. (ii)

    Ynâ¢Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢câ¢X.

  3. (iii)

    Xn/Ynâ¢ğŸ{Ynâ‰ 0}â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X/c if câ‰ 0.

Remark 4.2.7.

Note that by Theorem 4.2.5, the assumption Ynâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢c for a constant câˆˆâ„ is equivalent to only requiring Ynâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢c. If instead Ynâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Y for some random variable that is not a.s.Â constant, it is generally not true that Xn+Ynâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X+Y.

Proof.

We only prove part (i). Let tâˆˆâ„ be a fixed continuity point of FX+c and Îµ>0. Then,

FXn+Ynâ¢(t) =â„™â¢(Xn+Ynâ‰¤t)
=â„™â¢(Xn+Ynâ‰¤t,|Ynâˆ’c|<Îµ)+â„™â¢(Xn+Ynâ‰¤t,|Ynâˆ’c|â‰¥Îµ)
â‰¤â„™â¢(Xn+Ynâ‰¤t,|Ynâˆ’c|<Îµ)+â„™â¢(|Ynâˆ’c|â‰¥Îµ)
â‰¤â„™â¢(Xnâ‰¤tâˆ’c+Îµ)+â„™â¢(|Ynâˆ’c|â‰¥Îµ),

and similarly,

FXn+Ynâ¢(t)â‰¥â„™â¢(Xnâ‰¤tâˆ’câˆ’Îµ)âˆ’â„™â¢(|Ynâˆ’c|â‰¥Îµ). (4.5)

Since any cdf can have at most countable discontinuities (why?), we may choose a sequence (Îµm)mâˆˆâ„•, such that each of the points tâˆ’c+Îµm and tâˆ’câˆ’Îµm are points of continuity of FX. Since Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X and Ynâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢c, it therefore follows that for any mâˆˆâ„•,

lim supnâ†’âˆFXn+Ynâ¢(t) â‰¤lim supnâ†’âˆ(â„™â¢(Xnâ‰¤tâˆ’câˆ’Îµm)âˆ’â„™â¢(|Ynâˆ’c|â‰¥Îµm))
=FXâ¢(tâˆ’c+Îµm)
=FX+câ¢(tâˆ’Îµm).

Taking mâ†’âˆ and using that t is a point of continuity of X+c, we obtain

lim supnâ†’âˆFXn+Ynâ¢(t)â‰¤FX+câ¢(t).

Similarly, using (4.5), it follows that

lim infnâ†’âˆFXn+Ynâ¢(t)â‰¥FX+câ¢(t).

Combining both statements yields limnâ†’âˆFXn+Ynâ¢(t)=FX+câ¢(t) for the arbitrarily chosen point of continuity t and therefore Xn+Ynâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X+c. âˆ

Lemma 4.2.8.

Suppose that Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X for a continuous random variable X. Then, for any âˆ’âˆ<aâ‰¤b<âˆ it holds that

â„™â¢(Xnâˆˆ[a,b])â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢â„™â¢(Xâˆˆ[a,b]).
Proof.

Note that

â„™â¢(Xnâˆˆ[a,b])=FXnâ¢(b)âˆ’FXnâ¢(a)âŸ=â„™â¢(Xnâˆˆ(a,b])+â„™â¢(Xn=a).

Since X is continuous, a and b are continuity points of FX and therefore by assumption

FXnâ¢(b)âˆ’FXnâ¢(a)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢FXâ¢(b)âˆ’FXâ¢(a)=â„™â¢(Xâˆˆ(a,b])â¢=FXâ¢Â cont.â¢â„™â¢(Xâˆˆ[a,b]).

It therefore remains to prove that â„™â¢(Xn=a)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0. To this end let us define the tent function

Ï†kâ¢(x)â‰”{1+kâ¢(aâˆ’x),xâˆˆ[a,a+1/k],1+kâ¢(xâˆ’a),xâˆˆ[aâˆ’1/k,a),0,otherwise,xâˆˆâ„,kâˆˆâ„•.

Then, for any k, Ï†kâˆˆğ’bâ¢(â„) and ğŸ{a}â‰¤Ï†k. Since Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X, this implies that

â„™â¢(Xn=a)=ğ”¼â¢[ğŸ{a}â¢(Xn)]â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[Ï†kâ¢(Xn)]â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢ğ”¼â¢[Ï†kâ¢(X)],

and therefore for any k,

lim supnâ†’âˆâ„™â¢(Xn=a)â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[Ï†kâ¢(X)].

Since Ï†kâ¢âŸ¶kâ†’âˆâ¢ğŸ{a} pointwise and |Ï†k|â‰¤1, we conclude with dominated convergence and continuity of X that

lim supnâ†’âˆâ„™â¢(Xn=a)â‰¤limkâ†’âˆğ”¼â¢[Ï†kâ¢(X)]=ğ”¼â¢[limkâ†’âˆÏ†kâ¢(X)]=â„™â¢(X=a)=0,

which yields

limnâ†’âˆâ„™â¢(Xn=a)=lim supnâ†’âˆâ„™â¢(Xn=a)=0.

âˆ

We now head towards the big result in asymptotic probability that together with the LLN forms the basis of all of asymptotic statistics. Consider an i.i.d.Â sample X1,â€¦,Xn with finite variance Ïƒ2 and mean Î¼. Recall that the sample mean is given by XÂ¯nâ‰”1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi. By (4.2) it holds that

Varâ¡(XÂ¯n)=Ïƒ2nâŸ¹ÏƒXÂ¯n=Ïƒn

and by linearity ğ”¼â¢[XÂ¯n]=Î¼. The normalisation of XÂ¯n is therefore given by

Znâ‰”XÂ¯nâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[XÂ¯n]ÏƒXÂ¯n=XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼Ïƒ/n=nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼Ïƒ.
Exercise 4.2.9.

Show that if X1,â€¦,Xn are i.i.d.Â with X1âˆ¼ğ’©â¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2), the normalisation Zn satisfies Znâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1).

The Central Limit Theorem now states that for arbitrary i.i.d.Â samples with finite second moment, the exact relationship for the standardisation of normal random variables becomes an asymptotic relationship in distribution.

Theorem 4.2.10 (Central Limit Theorem (CLT)).

Let (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• be an i.i.d.Â sequence such that ğ”¼â¢[|X1|2]<âˆ and Varâ¡(X1)>0. Let

Znâ‰”XÂ¯nâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[XÂ¯n]Varâ¡(XÂ¯n)=nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼Ïƒ,

for Î¼â‰”ğ”¼â¢[X1], Ïƒ2â‰”Varâ¡(X1). Then, for Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1), it holds that

Znâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1).
Remark 4.2.11.

This is often denoted as Znâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢ğ’©â¢(0,1), with the right hand side representing a generic standard normal random variable. If we let Yiâ‰”(Xiâˆ’Î¼)/Ïƒ, then the CLT reads

nâ‹…YÂ¯nâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢ğ’©â¢(0,1).

Thus, while the empirical mean YÂ¯n converges almost surely to the trivial limit 0 according to the LLN, the CLT states that scaling it by n gives convergence in distribution to a standard normal.

As for the LLN, we cannot give a full proof of the CLT in these notes, but we illustrate the argument with an object that we have already encountered: the moment generating function. A deep result on the mgf is the following.

Theorem 4.2.12 (LÃ©vyâ€™s continuity theorem).

Let (Yn)nâˆˆâ„• be a sequence of random variables, whose mgfs exist in some common neighborhood (âˆ’h,h) of 0:

ÏˆYnâ¢(t)=ğ”¼â¢[expâ¡(tâ¢Yn)]<âˆ,âˆ€tâˆˆâ„,nâˆˆâ„•.

Let Y be another random variable whose mgf ÏˆY also exists on (âˆ’h,h). If

âˆ€tâˆˆ(âˆ’h,h):ÏˆYn(t)âŸ¶nâ†’âˆÏˆY(t),

then Ynâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Y.

Proof of a restricted version of the CLT.

We assume for simplicity that ÏˆX1 exists and is twice continuously differentiable in some interval (âˆ’h,h). Let us first consider the special case Î¼=0,Ïƒ2=1. Let Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1). From Chapter 2 we know that ÏˆYâ¢(t)=et2/2, so that by LÃ©vyâ€™s continuity theorem it is enough to show

âˆ€tâˆˆ(âˆ’h,h):ÏˆZn(t)âŸ¶nâ†’âˆÏˆZ(t),forÂ Znâ‰”nXÂ¯n=âˆ‘i=1nXin.

By Corollary 3.2.7 it holds that

ÏˆZnâ¢(t)=ğ”¼â¢[expâ¡(tnâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi)]=Ïˆâˆ‘i=1nXiâ¢(t/n)=âˆi=1nÏˆXiâ¢(t/n)=(ÏˆX1â¢(tn))n. (4.6)

Let Lâ¢(t)â‰”logâ¡ÏˆX1â¢(t). Then, using the differentiability assumption on ÏˆX1,

Lâ¢(0) =0
Lâ€²â¢(0) =ÏˆX1â€²â¢(0)â=ğ”¼â¢[X1]ÏˆX1â¢(0)âŸ=1=ğ”¼â¢[X1]=0
Lâ€²â€²â¢(0) =ÏˆX1â€²â€²â¢(0)â¢ÏˆX1â¢(0)â=ğ”¼â¢[X12]âˆ’ÏˆX1â€²â¢(0)2â=ğ”¼â¢[X1]2ÏˆX1â¢(0)2=ğ”¼â¢[X12]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X1]2=Varâ¡(X1)=1.

By (4.6), we need to show

(ÏˆX1â¢(tn))nâ¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢ÏˆZâ¢(t)=et2/2,tâˆˆ(âˆ’h,h),

which by taking logs is equivalent to

nâ¢Lâ¢(tn)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢t22,tâˆˆ(âˆ’h,h).

Using Lâ€™HÃ´pitalâ€™s rule twice and the above, we indeed get

limnâ†’âˆnâ¢Lâ¢(tn)=limnâ†’âˆLâ¢(t/n)nâˆ’1 =limnâ†’âˆâˆ’n3/2â¢tâ¢Lâ€²â¢(t/n)âˆ’2â¢nâˆ’2
=limnâ†’âˆtâ¢Lâ€²â¢(t/n)2â¢nâˆ’1/2
=limnâ†’âˆâˆ’nâˆ’3/2â¢t2â¢Lâ€²â€²â¢(t/n)âˆ’2â¢nâˆ’3/2
=t22â¢limnâ†’âˆLâ€²â€²â¢(t/n)
=t22â¢Lâ€²â€²â¢(0)=t22.

Thus, for the special case Î¼=0,Ïƒ2=1 we have proved that Znâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1). For general Î¼ and Ïƒ2 consider X^nâ‰”(Xnâˆ’Î¼)/Ïƒ. Then, (X^n)nâˆˆâ„• is an i.i.d.Â sequence with Varâ¡(X^1)=1,ğ”¼â¢[X1^]=0, such that from above it follows

Zn=nâ¢1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXiâˆ’Î¼Ïƒ=âˆ‘i=1nXi^nâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Zâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,1).

âˆ

Theorem 4.2.13 (delta method).

Let Î¼âˆˆâ„, Ïƒ>0 and g:â„â†’â„ be a measurable function that is differentiable at Î¼ and is such that gâ€²â¢(Î¼)â‰ 0. Suppose that (Yn)nâˆˆâ„• is a sequence of random variables such that

nâ¢Ynâˆ’Î¼Ïƒâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢ğ’©â¢(0,1).

Then,

nâ¢gâ¢(Yn)âˆ’gâ¢(Î¼)Ïƒâ¢gâ€²â¢(Î¼)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢ğ’©â¢(0,1).
Proof.

Let

râ¢(h)â‰”{gâ¢(Î¼+h)âˆ’gâ¢(Î¼)hâˆ’gâ€²â¢(Î¼),hâ‰ 00,h=0.

Then,

gâ¢(Yn)âˆ’gâ¢(Î¼)=gâ€²â¢(Î¼)â¢(Ynâˆ’Î¼)+(Ynâˆ’Î¼)â¢râ¢(Ynâˆ’Î¼),

and therefore

nâ¢gâ¢(Yn)âˆ’gâ¢(Î¼)Ïƒâ¢gâ€²â¢(Î¼)=nâ¢Ynâˆ’Î¼Ïƒ+nâ¢Ynâˆ’Î¼Ïƒâ¢gâ€²â¢(Î¼)â¢râ¢(Ynâˆ’Î¼). (4.7)

Let us show that the second term converges to zero in probability. By assumption we have

Zn:-nâ¢Ynâˆ’Î¼Ïƒâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢ğ’©â¢(0,1), (4.8)

and therefore Ynâˆ’Î¼=Ïƒâ¢nâˆ’1/2â¢Znâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢0 (this follows, e.g., from Slutskyâ€™s theorem and Theorem 4.2.5). Since g is differentiable at Î¼, r is a continuous function. Consequently, the continuous mapping theorem implies that

râ¢(Ynâˆ’Î¼)â¢âŸ¶â„™â¢0. (4.9)

Combining (4.8) and (4.9) with Slutskyâ€™s theorem therefore yields

nâ¢Ynâˆ’Î¼Ïƒâ¢gâ€²â¢(Î¼)â¢râ¢(Ynâˆ’Î¼)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢0,

which by Theorem 4.2.5 also gives

nâ¢Ynâˆ’Î¼Ïƒâ¢gâ€²â¢(Î¼)â¢râ¢(Ynâˆ’Î¼)â¢âŸ¶â„™â¢0.

This together with (4.7) and (4.8) finally yields

nâ¢gâ¢(Yn)âˆ’gâ¢(Î¼)Ïƒâ¢gâ€²â¢(Î¼)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢ğ’©â¢(0,1),

by yet another application of Slutskyâ€™s theorem. âˆ

Finally, let us also discuss the multivariate CLT, which concerns convergence in distribution of normalisations of sample means of random vectors. To this end, we need to talk about independence of random vectors and convergence in distribution of random vectors. These concepts extend straightforwardly from the univariate case.

Definition 4.2.14.
  1. (a)

    A collection of d-dimensional random vectors X1,â€¦,Xn (that is, Xk=(Xk,1,â€¦,Xk,d)âŠ¤ for some random variables Xk,i) is defined to be independent, if

    âˆ€Aâˆˆâ„¬(â„d):â„™(X1âˆˆA1,â€¦,XnâˆˆAn)=âˆi=1nâ„™(XiâˆˆAi).
  2. (b)

    A sequence of random vectors (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• is defined to be independent, if for any nâˆˆâ„•, X1,â€¦,Xn are independent.

  3. (c)

    A sequence of d-dimensional random vectors (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• is said to converge in distribution to a d-dimensional random vector X (denoted by Xnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢X) if

    âˆ€Ï†âˆˆğ’b(â„d):limnâ†’âˆğ”¼[Ï†(Xn)]=ğ”¼[Ï†(X)],

    where

    ğ’bâ¢(â„d):-{Ï†:â„dâ†’â„:Ï†â¢Â continuous and bounded}.
Theorem 4.2.15 (Multivariate CLT).

Let (Xn)nâˆˆâ„• be an i.i.d.Â sequence of d-dimensional random vectors such that Î£:-Î£X1 exists and is invertible. Let XÂ¯n:-1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi and Î¼â‰”ğ”¼â¢[X1]. Let

Znâ‰”Î£XÂ¯nâˆ’1/2â¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[XÂ¯n])=nâ¢Î£âˆ’1/2â¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼).

Then, it holds that

Znâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢ğ’©â¢(0,ğ•€d).
Remark 4.2.16.

Equivalently, we have

nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢ğ’©â¢(0,Î£).

The proof is a straightforward consequence of the univariate CLT and the CramÃ©râ€“Wold device, which allows us to break down multivariate distributional convergence to univariate distributional convergences of linear combinations of the random vector entries.

Theorem 4.2.17 (CramÃ©râ€“Wold device).

Let Z,Z1,Z2,â€¦ be d-dimensional random vectors. Then,

Znâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Zâ‡”âˆ€aâˆˆâ„d:aâŠ¤â¢Znâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢aâŠ¤â¢Z.

Chapter 5 Fundamental concepts in inference

5.1 Introduction

Suppose that a set of n data points ğ’™={x1,â€¦,xn} are collected in an experiment to estimate some unknown quantity. Statisticians view ğ’™ as realisations from random variables ğ‘¿={X1,â€¦,Xn}. Throughout the rest of this course, we will focus on the case where X1,â€¦,Xn are i.i.d with some distribution P. The goal of statistical inference is to learn about the data generating mechanism P, using the available sample ğ’™.

Example 5.1.1.
  • â€¢

    Coin flipping;

  • â€¢

    Quality control in manufacturing;

  • â€¢

    Clinical trials for new drug efficacy;

  • â€¢

    Language ability tests in a school;

  • â€¢

    Tracking someoneâ€™s weight over time; (the i.i.d assumption is unlikely to be true in this case; Time series analysis is predominately concerned with statistical inference under temporal dependence, which relax the independence assumption)

  • â€¢

    â€¦

Remark 5.1.2.

To distinguish quantities that are deterministic and random, we mostly use lowercase letters to denote deterministic quantities, e.g.Â x, and uppercase letters to denote random variables, e.g.Â X. In particular, for deterministic quantities, we have ğ”¼â¢[x]=x and Var(x)=0.

We will work under the assumption that P belongs to some statistical model that can be parameterised by some parameter Î¸, as defined below. Again, there are many situations where such an assumption may not be appropriate - see the course on Nonparametric Statistics for further discussions.

Definition 5.1.3 (Statistical model).

Let Î˜ denote the parameter space and ğ’® denote the sample space. A statistical model is a family of probability distributions on ğ’®. A parametric statistical model is a set of distributions parametrised by Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„d, written as {PÎ¸:Î¸âˆˆÎ˜}.

Example 5.1.4.

Some examples of statistical models

  • â€¢

    {Nâ¢(Î¸,1):Î¸âˆˆÎ˜=â„};

  • â€¢

    {Nâ¢(Î¸,1):Î¸âˆˆÎ˜=[âˆ’2,5]};

  • â€¢

    {Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2â¢Id):Î¸=(Î¼,Ïƒ)âˆˆÎ˜=â„d+1};

  • â€¢

    {Ber(Î¸):Î¸âˆˆ[0,1]}.

We shall write

X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢PÎ¸,Î¸âˆˆÎ˜, (5.1)

to denote that random variables X1,â€¦,Xn:Î©â†’ğ’® are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) with distribution PÎ¸. Recall that this means for some probability measure â„™Î¸ on (Î©,â„±), X1,â€¦,Xn are i.i.d. with distribution â„™Î¸â¢(Xâˆ’1â¢(â‹…))=PÎ¸â¢(â‹…). We shall always assume that PÎ¸ is dominated by some (Ïƒ-finite) measure Î¼ on ğ’®, and therefore it is equivalent to write (5.1) as

X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜,

where fâ¢(x;Î¸)=dâ¢PÎ¸dâ¢Î¼â¢(x). In statistics, the measure Î¼ is often the Lebesgue measure (for continuous random variables) or the counting measure (for discrete random variables).

Definition 5.1.5 (Statistic).

Given X={X1,â€¦,Xn}, any (measurable) function of X that does not depend on unknown quantities is called a statistic.

Remark 5.1.6.

We often use Î¸^nâ¢(X) to denote a statistic. Statistics are computed mostly to estimate the unknown quantity Î¸ in the data generating mechanism PÎ¸, and therefore we often also call it an estimator. Note that the subscript n in Î¸^nâ¢(X) indicate that it is a function of the sample size n. Note also that it is a random variable since it depends on X which is random, whereas Î¸ is a deterministic quantity in this course. We will explore the possibility of viewing Î¸ as a random variable in the Bayesian Inference and Computation course.

Example 5.1.7.

Some examples of statistics

  • â€¢

    Î¸^nâ¢(X)=X;

  • â€¢

    Î¸^nâ¢(X)=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi

  • â€¢

    Î¸^nâ¢(X)= median(X)

Most statistical problems can be identified as one of following three types:

  • â€¢

    (Point) Estimation: Constructing Î¸^nâ¢(X) such that for all Î¸âˆˆÎ˜, when Xiâˆ¼PÎ¸, our estimator Î¸^n is close to Î¸.

  • â€¢

    (Hypothesis) Testing: Making decisions about whether we are under the null hypothesis H0 or the alternative hypothesis H1 using some test statistic Tnâ¢(X) that takes value 0 or 1. The goal is constructing Tnâ¢(X) such that Tnâ¢(X)=0 when H0 is true and Tnâ¢(X)=1 when H1 is true, with high probability.

  • â€¢

    Confidence sets: Finding sets or intervals (depending on the dimensionality of the parameter) Cnâ¢(X) such that for Î±âˆˆ(0,1) we have â„™Î¸â¢(Î¸âˆˆCnâ¢(X))â‰¥1âˆ’Î±, for all Î¸âˆˆÎ˜.

5.2 Point estimation

We consider the task of estimating the parameter Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„. Given an an i.i.d.Â sample X1,â€¦,Xn for a statistical model (PÎ¸)Î¸âˆˆÎ˜, an estimator Î¸^nâ¢(X1,â€¦,Xn) is a statistic that is designed to estimate the unknown parameter of interest Î¸. To assess the quality of the estimator Î¸^n, we may consider the following quantities.

Definition 5.2.1 (Bias and mean squared error).
  1. (i)

    We call

    Biasâ¡(Î¸^n)â‰”ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]âˆ’Î¸

    the bias of Î¸^n (w.r.t.Â the unknown parameter Î¸). We say that Î¸^n is unbiased, if

    âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜:Biasâ¡(Î¸^n)=0.

    Note that to compute the bias, we need to compute ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]=âˆ«â„nÎ¸^nâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢ğ‘‘PÎ¸nâ¢(x1,â€¦,xn) which usually leads to a function of the unknown parameter Î¸. Sometimes people use ğ”¼Î¸ to emphasize the fact that the random variables have distribution PÎ¸, but we simply write ğ”¼ as long as the source of randomness is clear. Moreover, using properties of expectation (especially linearity) can often simplify the calculation.

  2. (ii)

    We call

    MSEâ¡(Î¸^n)â‰”ğ”¼â¢(Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸)2

    the mean squared error of Î¸^n (w.r.t.Â the unknown parameter Î¸). As we will show shortly, computing MSE is equivalent to computing the bias and variance of Î¸^n.

Example 5.2.2.

Let PÎ¸=ğ’©â¢(Î¸,Ïƒ2) for Î¸âˆˆâ„ and variance Ïƒ2. Let X1,X2,â€¦,Xn be an i.i.d.Â sample from PÎ¸ and define Î¸^nâ‰”XÂ¯n=âˆ‘i=1nXi/n. For any Î¸âˆˆâ„, ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]=ğ”¼â¢[XÂ¯n]=Î¸, so the sample mean XÂ¯n is an unbiased estimator for Î¸. For the mean squared error, note that

ğ”¼â¢(Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸)2=ğ”¼â¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸)2=ğ”¼â¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’ğ”¼â¢(XÂ¯n))2=Varâ¢(XÂ¯n)=Ïƒ2/n.
Lemma 5.2.3 (Bias-variance decomposition).

Let Î¸^n be an estimator for the unknown parameter Î¸ of a statistical model (PÎ¸)Î¸âˆˆÎ˜. It holds that

âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜:MSE(Î¸^n)=(Bias(Î¸^n))2+Var(Î¸^n).
Proof.
MSEâ¡(Î¸^n) =ğ”¼â¢[|(Î¸^nâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n])+(ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]âˆ’Î¸)|2]
=ğ”¼â¢[|Î¸^nâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]|2]+2â¢ğ”¼â¢[(Î¸^nâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n])â¢(ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]âˆ’Î¸)]âŸ=ğ”¼â¢[(Î¸^nâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n])]âŸ=ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]=0â¢(ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]âˆ’Î¸)+ğ”¼â¢[|ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]âˆ’Î¸|2]âŸ=|ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]âˆ’Î¸|2
=ğ”¼â¢[|Î¸^nâˆ’ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]|2]+|ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n]âˆ’Î¸|2
=Varâ¡(Î¸^n)+(Biasâ¡(Î¸^n))2

âˆ

Example 5.2.4.

Let PÎ¸=Expâ¡(Î¸) for Î¸âˆˆ(0,âˆ), i.e.

fâ¢(x;Î¸)=Î¸â¢eâˆ’Î¸â¢x,xâ‰¥0,Î¸>0.

Suppose n>2. Consider Î¸^n=1XÂ¯n and we would like to compute its bias and mean squared error. Since X1,â€¦,Xn are i.i.d Exp(Î¸), we have âˆ‘i=1nXi has distribution Î“â¢(n,Î¸) (See Proposition 3.2.18) with density function fn,Î¸. Therefore,

ğ”¼â¢[1XÂ¯n] =ğ”¼â¢[nâˆ‘i=1nXi]=âˆ«0âˆnyâ¢fn,Î¸â¢(y)â¢ğ‘‘y=âˆ«0âˆnyâ¢Î¸nÎ“â¢(n)â¢ynâˆ’1â¢eâˆ’Î¸â¢yâ¢ğ‘‘y
=nâ¢Î¸â¢Î“â¢(nâˆ’1)Î“â¢(n)â¢âˆ«0âˆÎ¸nâˆ’1Î“â¢(nâˆ’1)â¢ynâˆ’2â¢eâˆ’Î¸â¢yâ¢ğ‘‘y=nnâˆ’1â¢Î¸â¢âˆ«0âˆfnâˆ’1,Î¸â¢(y)â¢ğ‘‘y=nnâˆ’1â¢Î¸.

Then we have

Biasâ¢(Î¸^n)=nnâˆ’1â¢Î¸âˆ’Î¸=1nâˆ’1â¢Î¸.

We leave it as an exercise to show that

Varâ¢(Î¸^n)=n2â¢Î¸2(nâˆ’1)2â¢(nâˆ’2).

Combining the results for bias and variance of Î¸^n, we can conclude using Lemma 5.2.3 that

MSEâ¢(Î¸^n)=Biasâ¢(Î¸^n)2+Varâ¢(Î¸^n)=(1nâˆ’1â¢Î¸)2+n2â¢Î¸2(nâˆ’1)2â¢(nâˆ’2)=n+2(nâˆ’1)â¢(nâˆ’2)â¢Î¸2.

Bias, variance, and mean squared error are all important quantities regarding an estimator that we might be interested in. In particular, they describe different aspects of the finite-sample (non-asymptotic) behavior of an estimator. We are also interested in asymptotic properties of an estimator, which describes the behavior of an estimator as the sample size n becomes infinite. The power of asymptotic evaluation is that when we let the sample size becomes infinite, calculations simplify.

Definition 5.2.5 (Consistency and Asymptotics).
  1. 1.

    We say that Î¸^n is consistent, if

    âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜:Î¸^nâŸ¶â„™Î¸Î¸(â‡”âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜,Îµ>0:â„™Î¸(|Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸|â‰¥Îµ)âŸ¶nâ†’âˆ0)
  2. 2.

    We say Î¸^n is mean square consistent, if

    MSEâ¢(Î¸^n)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0,

    and Î¸^n is asymptotically unbiased if

    Biasâ¢(Î¸^n)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0.
Remark 5.2.6.

Note that mean square consistent is equivalent to say Î¸^nâ¢âŸ¶â„’2â¢Î¸ by definition. However, ğ”¼â¢(Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸)â†’0 does not imply ğ”¼â¢|Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸|â†’0, and therefore asymptotically unbiasedness does not imply convergence in â„’1.

Proposition 5.2.7.

Let (Î¸^n)nâˆˆâ„• be a sequence of estimators for the unknown parameter Î¸ of a statistical model (PÎ¸)Î¸âˆˆÎ˜. If MSEâ¡(Î¸^n)â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0 for all Î¸âˆˆÎ˜, then (Î¸^n)nâˆˆâ„• is consistent.

Proof.

It is a direct consequence of convergence in â„’2 implies convergence in probability (Theorem 4.1.2). We repeat this proof here again. For all Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ and Îµ>0, Markovâ€™s inequality gives

â„™Î¸â¢(|Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸|â‰¥Îµ)â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[|Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸|2]Îµ2=MSEâ¡(Î¸^n)Îµ2â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢0.

This establishes Î¸^nâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢Î¸ for all Î¸âˆˆÎ˜, i.e., consistency. âˆ

Example 5.2.8.

Let PÎ¸=ğ’©â¢(0,Î¸2) for Î¸âˆˆ(0,âˆ) and let X1,X2,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢PÎ¸. Consider Î¸^n2â‰”1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi2, we have immediately

ğ”¼â¢[Î¸^n2]=ğ”¼â¢[X12]=Î¸2,

and therefore it is an unbiased estimator for Î¸2. Moreover, since Î¸2<âˆ, by the strong LLN, for any Î¸2âˆˆ(0,âˆ) it holds that Î¸^n2â¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢Î¸2 and therefore also Î¸^n2â¢âŸ¶â„™â¢Î¸2, so Î¸^n2 is a consistent estimator for Î¸2.

Now, consider Î¸^nâ‰”1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi2. By the continuous mapping theorem, it holds that

âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜:Î¸^nâŸ¶â„™Î¸.

If we tried to show the consistency of Î¸^n for Î¸ by computing its MSE, it would be much more difficult.

We can draw the following conclusion between various concepts introduced so far. Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢PÎ¸. All the statements below are regarding the parameter Î¸.

  • â€¢

    If Î¸^n is unbiased, then it is asymptotically unbiased. The converse is not true (See Example 5.2.4).

  • â€¢

    If Î¸^n is mean square consistent, then it is consistent (Proposition 5.2.7). The converse is not true.

  • â€¢

    If Î¸^n is mean square consistent, then it is asymptotically unbiased.

  • â€¢

    Asymptotically unbiased and consistency generally do not imply each other. (See exercises below).

Exercise 5.2.9.

Show that if X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Expâ¢(Î¸), then Xmin=minâ¡{X1,â€¦,Xn} has distribution Exp(nâ¢Î¸). Use this to show that Tnâ¢(X)=nâ¢Xmin is unbiased for 1/Î¸, i.e.Â ğ”¼â¢(nâ¢Xmin)=1/Î¸. Also compute Varâ¢(Tnâ¢(X)) and conclude that it is not mean square consistent for 1/Î¸.

Given the result from the above exercise, we have for any Îµ>0

â„™Î¸(|nXminâˆ’1/Î¸|>Îµ)â‰¥â„™Î¸(nXminâˆ’1/Î¸>Îµ)=â„™Î¸(Xmin>(Îµ+(1/Î¸))/n)=exp(âˆ’(Î¸Îµ+1),

and therefore we can conclude that nâ¢Xmin is an unbiased estimator for 1/Î¸, but it is not consistent.

Exercise 5.2.10 (*).

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢PÎ¸,Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„, and suppose we have an estimator Î¸^n that is consistent and ğ”¼â¢(Î¸^n2)â‰¤C, for some constant C>0 and any nâˆˆâ„•. Show that Î¸^n is also asymptotically unbiased.

Having discussed various desirable properties of an estimator, we will introduce a principled way of deriving estimators that enjoy some of these properties (especially from an asymptotic point of view) in the next chapter. It is known as the Maximum Likelihood Estimator (MLE).

5.3 Confidence intervals

A confidence interval is a random interval C expressed in terms of the data X1,â€¦,Xn such that with a certain degree of confidence â€“ that needs to be made precise â€“ contains the unknown parameter Î¸.

Definition 5.3.1.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢â„™Î¸,Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„.

  1. (i)

    A random interval Cnâ¢(X)=[Lnâ¢(X1,â€¦,Xn),Unâ¢(X1,â€¦,Xn)]âŠ†â„, where Ln,Un are measurable functions, is called a (non-asymptotic) confidence interval (CI) at level 1âˆ’Î±âˆˆ(0,1) for Î¸, if âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜

    â„™Î¸â¢(Î¸âˆˆCnâ¢(X))âŸ=â„™Î¸â¢(Lnâ¢(X1,â€¦,Xn)â‰¤Î¸â‰¤Unâ¢(X1,â€¦,Xn))â‰¥1âˆ’Î±.
  2. (ii)

    We call Cnâ¢(X) an asymptotic (or approximate) confidence interval for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±, if for âˆ€Î¸âˆˆÎ˜

    limnâ†’âˆâ„™Î¸â¢(Î¸âˆˆCnâ¢(X))â‰¥1âˆ’Î±.
Remark 5.3.2.
  • â€¢

    It is important to stress that the confidence interval Cnâ¢(X) is a random quantity and the parameter Î¸ is fixed (non-random)! The correct interpretation of CIs is that if we construct many confidence intervals from repeated random samples, at least 100â¢(1âˆ’Î±)% of these intervals would contain the true parameter Î¸.

  • â€¢

    Confidence intervals often requires distributional properties of some estimator for Î¸ to be understood. It is typically difficult to characterize the distribution of some estimator for every finite n, but their limiting distributions are often easier to obtain thanks to results like CLT and Delta method (Theorem 4.2.13). Under the same statistical model, CIs are often wider than asymptotic CIs, but they are valid for every finite n (hence the same non-asymptotic) whereas asymptotic CIs are only valid when n is sufficiently large.

Confidence interval for the unknown mean of a population
Example 5.3.3.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¸,1), Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„. The interval C=(âˆ’âˆ,âˆ) is a CI at level 1âˆ’Î± for any Î±âˆˆ(0,1), but it is useless in the sense that it does not help us infer anything about Î¸. In general, for a given Î±, we are interested in finding Cn such that its length |Cn| is as small as possible. However, we shall not dive into this issue here in this course; see Section 9,3 in Casella and Berger (2024) for a complete treatment.

A more reasonable way of think about CIs is viewing it as quantifying the uncertainty of a point estimator. Consider XÂ¯n as an estimator for Î¸. Then if we can show

â„™Î¸â¢(|XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸|â‰¤uÎ±)â‰¥1âˆ’Î±, (5.2)

then we have [XÂ¯nâˆ’uÎ±,XÂ¯n+uÎ±] is a CI for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±. Indeed, if (5.2) is true, then we have

â„™Î¸â¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’uÎ±â‰¤Î¸â‰¤XÂ¯n+uÎ±)â‰¥1âˆ’Î±.

In practice, we can replace XÂ¯n with the observed data xÂ¯n=âˆ‘i=1nxi/n, and the remaining question is to find uÎ± such that (5.2) holds. This can be done using the fact that XÂ¯nâˆ¼Nâ¢(Î¸,1/n) and therefore nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸)âˆ¼Nâ¢(0,1)

â„™Î¸(|XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸|â‰¤uÎ±)=â„™Î¸(|n|XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸|â‰¤nuÎ±)=â„™(|Z|â‰¤nuÎ±)=â„™(âˆ’nuÎ±<Z<nuÎ±)=2(Î¦(nuÎ±)âˆ’1/2),

where Zâˆ¼Nâ¢(0,1) and Î¦â¢(z)=â„™â¢(Zâ‰¤z) is the CDF of the standard normal distribution. For the above to be greater equal than 1âˆ’Î±, we need

2â¢(Î¦â¢(nâ¢uÎ±)âˆ’1/2)â‰¥1âˆ’Î±âŸ¹uÎ±â‰¥1nâ¢Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2).

Therefore, we conclude that

[XÂ¯nâˆ’1nâ¢Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2),XÂ¯n+1nâ¢Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2)],

is a CI for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±.

For a given value of Î±âˆˆ(0,1), Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2) is sometimes called critical values and it can be explicitly found from the normal table (also known as the z-score table) in Table A.1. More easily, if you use R as the programming language, Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2) can be found using

â¬‡
qnorm(1-alpha/2)

where alpha is your input value for Î±. Sometimes, we write z1âˆ’Î±/2:=Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2) so that

â„™â¢(Xâ‰¤z1âˆ’Î±/2)=1âˆ’Î±/2.

To give a specific example, suppose that x={2.86,3.45,1.76,4,3.7,2.88,5.6}, then we have n=7 and xÂ¯n=3.464. For Î±=0.05, Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2)=1.96, and therefore, we conclude that

[XÂ¯nâˆ’1.96n,XÂ¯n+1.96n]â‰ˆ[3.464âˆ’1.967,3.464+1.967]â‰ˆ[2.724,4.204]

is a 95% CI for Î¸.

The same arguments used in the above example leads immediately to the following result.

Proposition 5.3.4.

If X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¸,Ïƒ2), Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„, and assume Ïƒ>0 is known. Then

Cn=[XÂ¯nâˆ’Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2,XÂ¯n+Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2],

is a CI for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±.

Example 5.3.5.

In the example above, the key step in deriving the CI for Î¸ is that we use the distributional property of XÂ¯n to control (5.2). Now, consider X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢PÎ¸, Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„, with ğ”¼â¢(X1)=Î¸ and Varâ¢(X1)=Ïƒ2. We assume Ïƒ>0 is known. Even if we do not know the distribution of XÂ¯n, we can still show

[XÂ¯nâˆ’1.96â¢Ïƒn,XÂ¯n+1.96â¢Ïƒn]

is an asymptotic 95% CI for Î¸ by using CLT and Lemma 4.2.8. Indeed, we have nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸Ïƒâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,1) by CLT, and therefore

â„™Î¸â¢(nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸Ïƒâˆˆ[âˆ’z,z])â¢âŸ¶nâ†’âˆâ¢2â¢Î¦â¢(z)âˆ’1,

and choosing z=z1âˆ’Î±/2=Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2) gives an asymptotic CI for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î± as

Cn=[XÂ¯nâˆ’Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2,XÂ¯n+Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2].

Further choosing Î±=0.05 leads to an asymptotic 95% CI for Î¸.

Exercise 5.3.6.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢PÎ¸, Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„, with ğ”¼â¢(X1)=Î¸ and Varâ¢(X1)=1.Then, for any Î±âˆˆ(0,1),

Cnâ¢(X)â‰”[XÂ¯nâˆ’1Î±â¢n,XÂ¯n+1Î±â¢n],

is an 1âˆ’Î± confidence interval for the unknown mean Î¸.

Note that the size difference between the asymptotic confidence intervals Cn from Example 5.3.5 and the non-asymptotic confidence intervals from Exercise 5.3.6 â€“ denoted for the moment by C~n â€“ can be large. E.g., for the typical choice Î±=0.05, we |C~n|â‰ˆ8.94â¢nâˆ’1/2. On the other hand, for the same choice of Î±, |Cn|=3.92â¢Ïƒâ¢nâˆ’1/2. Keep in mind however that Cn only guarantees an asymptotic 1âˆ’Î± coverage and is therefore only useful for sufficiently large sample sizes, whereas C~n gives a 1âˆ’Î± coverage in probability for any finite sample size n.

Asymptotic normality and CI in the case of unknown variance

As we saw above, a common way to establish asymptotic CIs for Î¸ is by showing some estimator Î¸^n has an asymptotic normal distribution, as defined below.

Definition 5.3.7.

Let (PÎ¸)Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ be a statistical model with parameter space Î˜âŠ†â„. We say an estimator Î¸^n is asymptotically normal if, for some Ïƒnâ†’0 as nâ†’âˆ,

Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸Ïƒnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,1).

If Ïƒn=Ïƒ/n, for some Ïƒ>0, then we say Î¸^n is asymptotically normal with asymptotic variance Ïƒ2, since in this case

nâ¢(Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,Ïƒ2)
Exercise 5.3.8.

Given a statistical model (PÎ¸)Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ and an asymptotically normal estimator Î¸^n with known Ïƒnâ†’0, show that the interval

Cn=[Î¸^nâˆ’Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2,Î¸^n+Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2]

is an asymptotic confidence interval (CI) for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±.

Proposition 5.3.9.

If Î¸^n is asymptotically normal, as defined above, then it is also consistent for Î¸, i.e.Â Î¸^nâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢Î¸. If, in addition, ğ”¼â¢(Î¸^n2)<âˆ for all nâˆˆâ„•, then Î¸^n is also asymptotically unbiased.

Proof.

Since Ïƒnâ†’0 as nâ†’âˆ, by Slutskyâ€™s theorem, we have

Ïƒnâ‹…Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸Ïƒnâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢0âŸ¹Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸â¢âŸ¶â„™â¢0â‡”Î¸^nâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢Î¸.

The second part of proof follows from exercise 5.2.10. âˆ

Example 5.3.10.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢PÎ¸, Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„, with ğ”¼â¢(X1)=Î¸ and Varâ¢(X1)=Ïƒ2, but with unknown Ïƒ>0. CLT shows Î¸^n=XÂ¯n is asymptotically normal with Ïƒn=Ïƒ/n, i.e.

nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸Ïƒâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,1).

From Exercise 5.3.8, we have

[XÂ¯nâˆ’Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2,XÂ¯n+Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2]

is an asymptotic CI for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±. In practice, we often do not know the value of Ïƒ and it has to be estimated using the data. However, as long as we have a consistent estimator for Ïƒ, i.e.Â Ïƒ^nâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘ƒâ¢Ïƒ then

[XÂ¯nâˆ’Ïƒ^nnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2,XÂ¯n+Ïƒ^nnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2]

is again an asymptotic CI for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±. This is because we actually have

nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸Ïƒ^n=nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸Ïƒâ¢ÏƒÏƒ^nâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,1),

due to Slutskyâ€™s theorem, where ÏƒÏƒ^nâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢1 can seen by applying continuous mapping theorem to Ïƒ^nâ¢âŸ¶ğ‘ƒâ¢Ïƒ.

Chapter 6 Maximum Likelihood Estimation

The construction of estimators for individual problems is made much simpler by the existence of some general techniques for doing so. One of the most widely used approaches in statistics centers around the likelihood function.

6.1 Likelihood function and maximum likelihood estimator (MLE)

Definition 6.1.1.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜. The likelihood function is defined as

Lâ¢(Î¸;X):=âˆi=1nfâ¢(Xi;Î¸),

and the log-likelihood function is defined as

lâ¢(Î¸;X):=logâ¡Lâ¢(Î¸;X)=âˆ‘i=1nlogâ¡fâ¢(Xi;Î¸).

The maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) is defined as

Î¸^Mâ¢Lâ¢Eâ¢(X):=argâ¢maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡Lâ¢(Î¸;X)=argâ¢maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡lâ¢(Î¸;X).
Remark 6.1.2.
  • â€¢

    Suppose we observed x=(x1,â€¦,xn) as the realisations of X=(X1,â€¦,Xn). Then, we call Lâ¢(Î¸;x):=âˆi=1nfâ¢(xi;Î¸) the observed likelihood function, lâ¢(Î¸;x):=logâ¡Lâ¢(Î¸;x) the observed log-likelihood function, and Î¸^Mâ¢Lâ¢Eâ¢(x):=argâ¢maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡Lâ¢(Î¸;x) the maximum likelihood estimate. These quantities are fixed and can computed once the actual data x=(x1,â€¦,xn) is given.

  • â€¢

    Both the Lâ¢(Î¸;X) and lâ¢(Î¸;X) should be viewed as a function of Î¸, and MLE is the maximiser of both functions in Î¸.

  • â€¢

    Lâ¢(Î¸;X) is not a pdf/pmf for Î¸ and in particular âˆ«Î˜Lâ¢(Î¸;X)â¢ğ‘‘Î¸â‰ 1.

  • â€¢

    Finding MLE is essentially an optimisation problem. MLE may not exist and it may not be unique, depending on the complexity of the statistical model {fâ¢(x,Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜}. However, we shall later implicitly assume a set of regularity conditions that avoids such issues so that MLE exists and is unique.

  • â€¢

    Note that, by definition, Î¸^Mâ¢Lâ¢Eâ¢(X)âˆˆÎ˜, i.e.Â the estimator always belongs to the parameter space.

  • â€¢

    We note that Î¸^Mâ¢Lâ¢Eâ¢(X) is a random variable with distribution depending on fâ¢(x,Î¸), so we will be interested in studying the statistical properties of Î¸^Mâ¢Lâ¢Eâ¢(x), e.g.Â bias, consistency, and asymptotic normality.

  • â€¢

    MLE usually turns out to be quite intuitive if there is a clear interpretation of the parameter that you try to estimate. It gives a principled way to obtain point estimation and confidence intervals when the statistical model becomes more complex, and it also enjoys several desirable statistical properties.

One could view the definition of likelihood function as the joint pdf/pmf of X1,â€¦,Xn and it takes the product form due to our assumption that they are independent. This view also leads to the following motivation for MLE:

If Lâ¢(Î¸1;X)>Lâ¢(Î¸2;X) (equivalently, if lâ¢(Î¸1;X)>lâ¢(Î¸2;X)), then Î¸1 is more likely to have been responsible for producing the observed X1,â€¦,Xn. In other words, fâ¢(x;Î¸1) is a better model than fâ¢(x;Î¸2) in terms of how well it fits the observed data.

One can extend the definition of Likelihood function to allow dependence as well as change in distribution. The simplest extension is perhaps to the case where the data are independent but not identically distributed. A prominent example of this case is the linear regression problem.

Example 6.1.3.

Suppose that Yi=xiâŠ¤â¢Î²+Îµi,i=1,â€¦,n, where Îµiâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(0,Ïƒ2) with known Ïƒ>0, and xiâˆˆâ„d is assumed to be known and fixed/deterministic/non-random. The parameter Î²âˆˆRd is the regression coefficient. Using properties of Gaussian random variables, we have

Yiâˆ¼Nâ¢(xiâŠ¤â¢Î²,Ïƒ2),

and they are independent. Therefore, the likelihood function, or joint pdf of Y=(Y1,â€¦,Yn), in this case is

Lâ¢(Î²;Y,x)=âˆi=1n12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’12â¢Ïƒ2â¢(Yiâˆ’xiâŠ¤â¢Î²)2),

and the MLE for Î² can be found as

Î²^Mâ¢Lâ¢Eâ¢(Y,x)=argâ¢maxÎ²âˆˆâ„dâ¡Lâ¢(Î²;Y,x)

The following exercise shows that the MLE for Î² in a regression problem can be obtained by a method known commonly as the least square method.

Exercise 6.1.4.

Suppose that Yi=xiâŠ¤â¢Î²+Îµi,i=1,â€¦,n, where Îµiâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(0,Ïƒ2) with known Ïƒ>0, and xiâˆˆâ„d is assumed to be known and fixed/deterministic/non-random. Show that the MLE for Î² coincides with

Î²^â¢(Y,x):=argâ¢minÎ²âˆˆâ„dâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Yiâˆ’xiâŠ¤â¢Î²)2,

i.e. Î²^Mâ¢Lâ¢Eâ¢(Y,x)=Î²^â¢(Y,x). Find Î²^â¢(Y,x) explicitly by solving the above optimization problem, assuming âˆ‘i=1nxiâ¢xiâŠ¤ is invertible.

6.2 Examples

Example 6.2.1.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), where

fâ¢(x;Î¸)=12â¢Ï€â¢expâ¡(âˆ’(xâˆ’Î¸)2/2),xâˆˆâ„,Î¸âˆˆâ„.

Now, the likelihood function is

Lâ¢(Î¸;X)=(12â¢Ï€)nâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’12â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¸)2),

and the log-likelihood function is

lâ¢(Î¸;X)=âˆ’nâ¢logâ¡(2â¢Ï€)âˆ’12â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¸)2.

To find the maximiser of lâ¢(Î¸;X), we first compute âˆ‚lâˆ‚Î¸ and set it to zero to find stationary points:

âˆ‚lâ¢(Î¸;X)âˆ‚Î¸=âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¸)=0âŸ¹Î¸^n=XÂ¯n.

To conclude Î¸^n is indeed the global maximiser, we can take the second derivative

âˆ‚2lâ¢(Î¸;X)âˆ‚Î¸2=âˆ’n<0.

Note that fâ¢(x;Î¸) is actually the density function of Nâ¢(Î¸,1). Now that we have established XÂ¯n is MLE for Î¸, we consider some statistical properties of it

  • â€¢

    Bias(XÂ¯n) = ğ”¼â¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸)=0, Var(XÂ¯n)=1/n, MSE(XÂ¯n)=1/n.

  • â€¢

    XÂ¯n is consistent and asymptotically unbiased for Î¸ since it is mean square consistent for Î¸.

  • â€¢

    Since XÂ¯nâˆ¼Nâ¢(Î¸,1/n), we have XÂ¯n is asymptotically normal with Ïƒn=1/n. As a result, by Exercise 5.3.8, we have [XÂ¯nâˆ’z1âˆ’Î±/2n,XÂ¯n+z1âˆ’Î±/2n] is an asymptotic CI for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±. (Alternatively, one can directly use the arguments in Example 5.3.3 to see this is in fact a non-asymptotic CI)

Example 6.2.2.

Suppose that X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), where Î¸=(Î¼,Ïƒ) and

fâ¢(x;Î¼,Ïƒ)=12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’(xâˆ’Î¼)2/(2â¢Ïƒ2)),xâˆˆâ„,Î¼âˆˆâ„,Ïƒ>0.

We consider the case where both Î¼ and Ïƒ are unknown and therefore, both of them need to be estimated. The likelihood function is

Lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ;X)=(12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ)nâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’12â¢Ïƒ2â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼)2)

and the log-likelihood is

lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ;X)=âˆ’nâ¢logâ¡(2â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ)âˆ’12â¢Ïƒ2â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼)2.

To find MLE for Î¼ and Ïƒ, we first take partial derivative to find the stationary point (Î¼^n,Ïƒ^n) of lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ;X):

âˆ‚lâˆ‚Î¼=1Ïƒ2â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼)=0,âˆ‚lâˆ‚Ïƒ=âˆ’nÏƒ+1Ïƒ3â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼)2=0

Solving these equations leads to

Î¼^n=XÂ¯n,Ïƒ^n2=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2.

Now, we must check this stationary point (Î¼^n,Ïƒ^n) is indeed the global maximum. There are many arguments one can use to justify it. One simple argument would be noticing that for any Î¼â‰ XÂ¯n

âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼)2>âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2.

Therefore, for any Ïƒ>0,

lâ¢(Î¼^n,Ïƒ;X)â‰¥lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ;X),

and it just remains to verify lâ¢(Î¼^n,Ïƒ;X) achieves its global maximum at Ïƒ^n. Taking the second derivative

âˆ‚2âˆ‚(Ïƒ)2â¢lâ¢(Î¼^n,Ïƒ^n)=âˆ‚âˆ‚Ïƒâ¢âˆ‚âˆ‚Ïƒâ¢lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ)|Î¼=Î¼^n,Ïƒ=Ïƒ^n=âˆ’2â¢nÏƒ^n2<0,

we can conclude that (Î¼^n,Ïƒ^n) is indeed the global maximum and hence the MLE for Î¸=(Î¼,Ïƒ).

A more direct approach to verify (Î¼^n,Ïƒ^n) is the MLE involves computing the Hessian matrix. We leave that as an exercise. Now, letâ€™s consider some statistical properties of the MLE (Î¼^n,Ïƒ^n) .

Asymptotic confidence interval for Î¼:

Recall from Proposition 5.3.4, a CI for Î¼ at level 1âˆ’Î± is

[XÂ¯nâˆ’Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2,XÂ¯n+Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2],

when Ïƒ is known. We also have shown in Example 5.3.10 that if we have a consistent estimator for Ïƒ, then we can just replace Ïƒ in the above CI by its estimator. To that end, we need to study the properties of Ïƒ^n2. The following identity is useful:

Ïƒ^n2=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi2âˆ’XÂ¯n2.

Now, by SLLN and continuous mapping theorem, we have

1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi2â¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢ğ”¼â¢[X12],XÂ¯n2â¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢ğ”¼â¢[X1]2,

Hence,

Ïƒ^n2â¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢ğ”¼â¢[X12]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[X1]2=Ïƒ2âŸ¹Ïƒ^nâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢Ïƒ.

Now that we have found a consistent estimator for Ïƒ, we can conclude

[XÂ¯nâˆ’Ïƒ^nnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2,XÂ¯n+Ïƒ^nnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2],

is an asymptotic CI for Î¼ at level 1âˆ’Î±, when Ïƒ is unknown, where Ïƒ^n=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2.

We note that a non-asymptotic CI for Î¼ can be constructed by introducing the studentâ€™s t distribution. We will discuss this later in the course in the context of hypothesis testing.

Confidence interval for Ïƒ2:

To construct a (non-asymptotic) confidence interval for Ïƒ, we need to understand the distribution of Ïƒ^2. We state the result directly. For a proof of this result, search Cochranâ€™s theorem.

Theorem 6.2.3.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2), then

âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2Ïƒ2âˆ¼Ï‡nâˆ’12.

To see this result intuitively, we note the following identity

âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2Ïƒ2=âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼)2Ïƒ2âˆ’nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼)2Ïƒ2âˆ¼Ï‡n2âˆ’Ï‡12,

the key calculation is to argue XÂ¯n and âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2 are independent.

Note that Theorem 6.2.3 implies

nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ïƒ2âˆ¼Ï‡nâˆ’12,

which leads to the following CI for Ïƒ2.

Corollary 6.2.4.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2), Ïƒ^n2=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2. Given the critical values Ï‡nâˆ’1,Î±/22 and Ï‡nâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/22, a confidence interval for Ïƒ2 at level 1âˆ’Î± is

[nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ï‡nâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/22,nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ï‡nâˆ’1,Î±/22]

The specific values of Ï‡nâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/22 and Ï‡nâˆ’1,Î±/22 can be obtain from R using the command

â¬‡
qchisq(1-alpha/2, n-1), qchisq(alpha/2, n-1),

respectively.

Proof.

Since nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ïƒ2âˆ¼Ï‡nâˆ’12, we know

â„™â¢(Ï‡nâˆ’1,Î±/22â‰¤nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ïƒ2â‰¤Ï‡nâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/22)â‰¥1âˆ’Î±,

by the definition of Ï‡nâˆ’1,Î±/22 and Ï‡nâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/22. Simply rewriting the inequalities inside the probability gives

â„™â¢(nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ï‡nâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/22â‰¤Ïƒ2â‰¤nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ï‡nâˆ’1,Î±/22)â‰¥1âˆ’Î±.

âˆ

In fact, we can immediately see from the proof above,

[nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ï‡nâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/22,nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ï‡nâˆ’1,Î±/22]

is a CI for Ïƒ at level 1âˆ’Î±, since â‹… is an increasing function. This is simple because our CI for Ïƒ2 is non-asymptotic. We shall see later that using asymptotic arguments, one need to resort to Delta method (Theorem 4.2.13) to derive asymptotic CI for Ïƒ.

The notion of sample variance:

Finally, we discuss another important terminology used widely in statistics - sample variance. To motivate it, we observe that since nâ¢Ïƒ^n2Ïƒ2âˆ¼Ï‡nâˆ’12, we have

ğ”¼â¢(Ïƒ^n2)=nâˆ’1nâ¢Ïƒ2,

using the property that ğ”¼â¢(W)=k, if Wâˆ¼Ï‡k2. This shows MLE are not necessarily unbiased. We easily construct an unbiased estimator for Ïƒ2 based on Ïƒ^n2. Indeed, we have

ğ”¼â¢(nnâˆ’1â¢Ïƒ^n2)=ğ”¼â¢(1nâˆ’1â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2)=Ïƒ2,

and this means S2:=1nâˆ’1â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2 is unbiased for Ïƒ2. We call S2 the sample variance essentially due to its unbiasedness.

Example 6.2.5.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), where

fâ¢(x;Î¸)=Î¸â¢eâˆ’Î¸â¢x,x>0,Î¸>0.

Thus, we have:

Lâ¢(Î¸;X)=Î¸nâ¢eâˆ’Î¸â¢âˆ‘i=1nXi,lâ¢(Î¸;X)=nâ¢logâ¡(Î¸)âˆ’Î¸â¢âˆ‘i=1nXi

To find the maximiser of lâ¢(Î¸;X), we can first compute âˆ‚lâˆ‚Î¸ and set it to zero to find stationary points:

âˆ‚lâ¢(Î¸)âˆ‚Î¸=nÎ¸âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nXi=0âŸ¹Î¸^n=1XÂ¯n.

where XÂ¯n denotes the sample mean. To verify the above Î¸^n indeed achieves maximum, we check

âˆ‚2lâˆ‚Î¸2=âˆ’nÎ¸2<0,

which concludes that Î¸^n=1XÂ¯ is the MLE. We studied its properties in Example 5.2.4 and we showed that

  • â€¢

    Bias(Î¸^n)=1nâˆ’1Î¸, MSE(Î¸^n)=n+2(nâˆ’1)â¢(nâˆ’2)â¢Î¸2â†’0, as nâ†’âˆ. Therefore Î¸^n is asymptotically unbiased but not unbiased for any finite n. It is consistent since it is mean square consistent.

  • â€¢

    We can actually show that nâ¢(Î¸^nâˆ’Î¸)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,Î¸2) using Delta method (Theorem 4.2.13) - check this yourself! We will present some more general arguments later on.

Exercise 6.2.6.

Suppose we observe actual data x={x1,â€¦,xn} and decide to model them by X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Berâ¢(p), where pâˆˆ(0,1).

(1) Write down the likelihood function and find the MLE for p.

(2) Construct an asymptotic confidence interval for p at level 1âˆ’Î± using the value Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2), where Î¦ is the CDF for Nâ¢(0,1), and justify your construction.

(3) Suppose the actual data we observe is x={1,0,1,1,1,0,0,1,0}. Write down an asymptotic confidence interval for p at level 0.95 based on your answer to (2).

Exercise 6.2.7.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), where

fâ¢(x;Î¸)=1Î¸,xâˆˆ[0,Î¸],Î¸>0.

(1) Write down the likelihood function. Show that the MLE for Î¸ is Î¸^n=X(n)=maxâ¡{X1,â€¦,Xn}.

(2) Show that

nâ¢(Î¸âˆ’Î¸^n)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Expâ¢(1/Î¸).

(This is in fact a purely probability exercise, but it demonstrates the fact that not all MLEs are asymptotically normal, i.e.Â some regularity conditions are required for asymptotically normality of MLE to hold!).

Exercise 6.2.8.

Suppose that X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), where Î¸=(Î¼,Ïƒ) and

fâ¢(x;Î¼,Ïƒ)=12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’(xâˆ’Î¼)2/(2â¢Ïƒ2)),xâˆˆâ„,Î¼âˆˆâ„,Ïƒ>0.

Verify that Î¼^=XÂ¯n and Ïƒ^=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2 are the MLE for Î¼ and Ïƒ, respectively, by showing that the Hessian matrix is negative definite at (Î¼^,Ïƒ^). This is the multivariate version of the second derivative test. Hint: this requires computing

âˆ‚2lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ;X)âˆ‚Î¼2,âˆ‚2lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ;X)âˆ‚(Ïƒ)2,âˆ‚2lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ;X)âˆ‚Î¼â¢âˆ‚Ïƒ,

where lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ;X) is the log-likelihood function.

6.3 Properties of MLE

6.3.1 Invariance - we did not cover this in the lecture so this subsection on invariance is not examinable

Now, suppose that we are interested in estimating a function of Î¸, denoted by Ï„=gâ¢(Î¸). If g is one-to-one (known as bijective), then we can define the likelihood function for Ï„ by replacing Î¸ in Lâ¢(Î¸;X) by gâˆ’1â¢(Î¸):

L~â¢(Ï„;X):=Lâ¢(gâˆ’1â¢(Ï„);X).
Theorem 6.3.1 (Invariance of the MLE).

Let X1,X2,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜. Let Ï„=gâ¢(Î¸) be a function of Î¸ such that gâˆ’1 exists, i.e. g is bijective. Then, if Î¸^n is the MLE for Î¸ then gâ¢(Î¸^n) is the MLE for gâ¢(Î¸).

Proof.

We need to show that if Î¸^n maximizes Lâ¢(Î¸;X), then gâ¢(Î¸^n) maximizes L~â¢(Ï„;X). By the definition of L~â¢(Ï„;X) and the existence of gâˆ’1, we have

L~â¢(gâ¢(Î¸^n);X)=Lâ¢(Î¸^n;X).

Hence for any other Ï„=gâ¢(Î¸),

L~â¢(Ï„;X)=Lâ¢(Î¸;X)â‰¤Lâ¢(Î¸^n;X)=L~â¢(gâ¢(Î¸^n);X),

and therefore gâ¢(Î¸^n) is the MLE for gâ¢(Î¸). âˆ

In the case where gâˆ’1 does not exist (e.g. gâ¢(x)=x2), one can modify the likelihood function for Ï„ but the conclusion of Theorem 6.3.1 still holds. (See Theorem 7.2.10 in Casella and Berger (2024))

6.3.2 Asymptotic properties

Theorem 6.3.2.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼iidâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„, and let Î¸^MLE be the MLE based on X=(X1,â€¦,Xn). Assume certain regularity conditions hold, including222For a full list of assumptions; see Casella and Berger (2024), Section 10.6.2:

  • â€¢

    {x:fâ¢(x,Î¸)>0} is the same for all Î¸âˆˆÎ˜.

  • â€¢

    The log-likelihood function lâ¢(Î¸;X) is differentiable in Î¸ and sufficiently smooth.

  • â€¢

    Î¸^MLE is the unique stationary point of lâ¢(Î¸;X).

Then the MLE Î¸^MLE is consistent and asymptotically unbiased. Moreover,

nâ¢(Î¸^MLEâˆ’Î¸)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,Iâ¢(Î¸)âˆ’1),

where

Iâ¢(Î¸)=Varâ¢[âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢logâ¡fâ¢(X1;Î¸)]=âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[âˆ‚2âˆ‚Î¸2â¢logâ¡fâ¢(X1,Î¸)].
Remark 6.3.3.
  • â€¢

    The regularity conditions guarantee that the MLE exists and is unique. They also exclude examples like X1â¢â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Unifâ¢(0,Î¸),Î¸>0, which violates asymptotic normality (See Exercise 6.2.7).

  • â€¢

    Since Î¸^MLE is both asymptotically normal and consistent, we can immediately write down an asymptotic confidence interval for Î¸ as:

    Î¸^Mâ¢Lâ¢EÂ±z1âˆ’Î±/2â¢1nâ¢Iâ¢(Î¸^Mâ¢Lâ¢E),

    assuming Iâ¢(Î¸) is continuous.

  • â€¢

    We call

    Sâ¢(Î¸;X1):=âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢logâ¡fâ¢(X1;Î¸),X1âˆ¼fâ¢(x;Î¸)

    the score function, and Iâ¢(Î¸), the variance of the score, is called the Fisher information (with sample size 1) and sometimes written as I1â¢(Î¸). Under the i.i.d assumption, we have

    Inâ¢(Î¸):=Varâ¢(âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢lâ¢(Î¸;X))=âˆ‘i=1nVarâ¢(Sâ¢(Î¸;Xi))=nâ¢Iâ¢(Î¸).
Lemma 6.3.4.

For any Î¸âˆˆÎ˜, suppose Xâˆ¼fâ¢(x;Î¸), assume sufficient strong conditions on fâ¢(x,Î¸) such that we can interchange integration and differentiation, then

ğ”¼â¢[Sâ¢(Î¸,X)]=0,Varâ¢(Sâ¢(Î¸,X))=âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢Sâ¢(Î¸,X)]
Proof.

We only prove the expectation statement, the variance part is left as an exercise. Note that

ğ”¼[S(Î¸,X)]=ğ”¼[âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸logf(X;Î¸)]==ğ”¼[âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢fâ¢(X;Î¸)fâ¢(X;Î¸)]=âˆ«âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢fâ¢(x;Î¸)fâ¢(x;Î¸)f(x;Î¸)dx=âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸âˆ«f(x;Î¸)dx=0.

âˆ

Exercise 6.3.5.

Suppose Xâˆ¼fâ¢(x;Î¸),xâˆˆğ’³,Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ and let Sâ¢(Î¸;X)=âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢logâ¡fâ¢(X;Î¸). Assuming sufficient strong conditions on fâ¢(x,Î¸) such that we can interchange integration and differentiation, we showed in lecture that For any Î¸âˆˆÎ˜,

ğ”¼â¢(Sâ¢(Î¸;X))=0.

By taking derivative with respect to Î¸ on both sides, show that

Varâ¢(Sâ¢(Î¸,X))=âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢Sâ¢(Î¸,X)].

Hint: You may use the identity: Sâ¢(Î¸,x)=âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢logâ¡fâ¢(x,Î¸)=1fâ¢(x,Î¸)â¢âˆ‚fâ¢(x,Î¸)âˆ‚Î¸,

Example 6.3.6.

Suppose that X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼iidâ¢Berâ¢(p),pâˆˆ(0,1). We know from Exercise 6.2.6, the MLE for p is

p^MLE=XÂ¯n.

By central limit theorem, we have

nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’p)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,pâ¢(1âˆ’p)).

Alternatively, we can obtain the same result using asymptotic normality of MLE by computing Iâ¢(p). Note that for Bernoulli random variable we have

fâ¢(X1;p)=pX1â¢(1âˆ’p)1âˆ’X1.

To find Iâ¢(p), we first compute

âˆ‚âˆ‚pâ¢logâ¡fâ¢(X1;p)=X1pâˆ’1âˆ’X11âˆ’p,

then we have

Iâ¢(p)=Varâ¢(âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢logâ¡fâ¢(X1;Î¸))=Varâ¢(X1pâˆ’1âˆ’X11âˆ’p)=Varâ¢(X1âˆ’ppâ¢(1âˆ’p))=1pâ¢(1âˆ’p)

Hence, by Theorem 6.3.2

nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’p)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,pâ¢(1âˆ’p)).
Proof sketch for Theorem 6.3.2.

We only sketch the proof for asymptotic normality. Denote Î¸^MLE by Î¸^ for notation simplicity and we write Î¸0 for the true parameter, i.e. X1â¢â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x,Î¸0),Î¸0âˆˆÎ˜. Note that the log-likelihood function is still lâ¢(Î¸)=âˆ‘i=1nlogâ¡fâ¢(Xi;Î¸). We also write lâ€²â¢(Î¸) for âˆ‚lâ¢(Î¸)âˆ‚Î¸, lâ€²â€²â¢(Î¸) for âˆ‚2lâ¢(Î¸)âˆ‚Î¸2, lâ€²â€²â€²â¢(Î¸) for âˆ‚3lâ¢(Î¸)âˆ‚Î¸3 and Sâ€²â¢(Î¸;X) for âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢Sâ¢(Î¸;X) . Note that lâ€²â¢(Î¸^)=0.

Using a Taylor expansion of lâ€²â¢(Î¸) around Î¸0, specifically Lagrange form of the remainder, we have:

lâ€²â¢(Î¸)=lâ€²â¢(Î¸0)+(Î¸âˆ’Î¸0)â¢lâ€²â€²â¢(Î¸0)+(Î¸âˆ’Î¸0)22â¢lâ€²â€²â€²â¢(Î¸~),

where Î¸~âˆˆ[Î¸,Î¸0]. Evaluate lâ€²â¢(Î¸) at Î¸=Î¸^:

0=lâ€²â¢(Î¸0)+(Î¸^âˆ’Î¸0)â¢lâ€²â€²â¢(Î¸0)+(Î¸^âˆ’Î¸0)22â¢lâ€²â€²â€²â¢(Î¸~),

which is equivalent to

nâ¢(Î¸^âˆ’Î¸0)=âˆ’nâ¢lâ€²â¢(Î¸0)lâ€²â€²â¢(Î¸0)+12â¢(Î¸^âˆ’Î¸0)â¢lâ€²â€²â€²â¢(Î¸~)=âˆ’nâ‹…1nâ¢lâ€²â¢(Î¸0)1nâ¢lâ€²â€²â¢(Î¸0)+12â¢(Î¸^âˆ’Î¸0)â¢lâ€²â€²â€²â¢(Î¸~)/n

Recall that

lâ€²â¢(Î¸)=âˆ‘i=1nâˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢logâ¡fâ¢(Î¸;Xi)=âˆ‘i=1nSâ¢(Î¸;Xi),

and lâ€²â¢(Î¸0) means that we evaluate the function of lâ€²â¢(Î¸) at Î¸=Î¸0 so that we have lâ€²â¢(Î¸0)=âˆ‘i=1nSâ¢(Î¸0;Xi). since Xiâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x,Î¸0), by Lemma 6.3.4, we have ğ”¼â¢(Sâ¢(Î¸0;Xi))=0 and Varâ¢(Sâ¢(Î¸0;Xi))=Iâ¢(Î¸0). Therefore, by CLT, we have

nâ‹…1nâ¢lâ€²â¢(Î¸0)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,Iâ¢(Î¸0)).

Similarly,

1nâ¢lâ€²â€²â¢(Î¸)=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nâˆ‚2âˆ‚Î¸2â¢logâ¡fâ¢(Î¸;Xi)=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nâˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢Sâ¢(Î¸,X1)â¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢ğ”¼â¢[âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢Sâ¢(Î¸,X1)],

since X1âˆ¼fâ¢(x,Î¸0), 1nâ¢lâ€²â€²â¢(Î¸0)â¢âŸ¶a.s.â¢ğ”¼â¢[Sâ€²â¢(Î¸0,X1)]=âˆ’Iâ¢(Î¸0).

Finally, we will assume it holds that the term

12â¢(Î¸^âˆ’Î¸0)â¢lâ€²â€²â€²â¢(Î¸~)/nâ¢âŸ¶â„™â¢0,

which can be shown using more involved arguments333These arguments are known as uniform law of large numbers. Note that here one cannot use continuous mapping theorem since lâ€²â€²â€²â¢(Î¸;X) is a random function. Together, we apply Slutskyâ€™s Theorem to conclude

nâ¢(Î¸^âˆ’Î¸0)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,1Iâ¢(Î¸0)).

âˆ

Theorem 6.3.7 (Multivariate version).

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼iidâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„d, and let Î¸^MLE be the MLE based on X1,â€¦,Xn. Define the Fisher Information matrix Iâ¢(Î¸)âˆˆâ„dÃ—d to be the covariance matrix of âˆ‡Î¸logâ¡fâ¢(X1,Î¸), i.e.

Iâ¢(Î¸)i,j=Covâ¢[âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸iâ¢logâ¡fâ¢(X1;Î¸),âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸jâ¢logâ¡fâ¢(X1;Î¸)]=âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[âˆ‚2âˆ‚Î¸iâ¢Î¸jâ¢logâ¡fâ¢(X1;Î¸)].

Assume the same regularity conditions hold as in Theorem 6.3.2, then the MLE Î¸^MLE is consistent and asymptotically unbiased. Moreover,

nâ¢(Î¸^MLEâˆ’Î¸)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,Iâ¢(Î¸)âˆ’1).

Note that we again have

Inâ¢(Î¸):=Varâ¢(âˆ‡Î¸lâ¢(Î¸;X))=âˆ‘i=1nVarâ¢(âˆ‡Î¸logâ¡fâ¢(Xi,Î¸))=nâ¢Iâ¢(Î¸).

due to the i.i.d assumption.

Example 6.3.8.

Recall the setup of Example 6.2.2, where we have X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), with Î¸=(Î¼,Ïƒ) and

fâ¢(x;Î¼,Ïƒ)=12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’(xâˆ’Î¼)2/(2â¢Ïƒ2)),xâˆˆâ„,Î¼âˆˆâ„,Ïƒ>0.

We consider the case where both Î¼ and Ïƒ are unknown. See the solution for Week 9 exercises where we obtain

âˆ‚2lâˆ‚Î¼2=âˆ’nÏƒ2,âˆ‚2lâˆ‚(Ïƒ)2=nÏƒ2âˆ’3Ïƒ4â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼)2,âˆ‚2lâˆ‚Î¼â¢âˆ‚Ïƒ=âˆ‚2lâˆ‚Ïƒâ¢âˆ‚Î¼=âˆ’2Ïƒ3â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼).

Taking expectation for each term, we have

ğ”¼â¢(âˆ‚2lâˆ‚Î¼2)=âˆ’nÏƒ2,ğ”¼â¢(âˆ‚2lâˆ‚(Ïƒ)2)=âˆ’2â¢nÏƒ2,ğ”¼â¢(âˆ‚2lâˆ‚Î¼â¢âˆ‚Ïƒ)=0

Therefore, the Fisher information matrix with sample size n is

Inâ¢(Î¸)=(nÏƒ2002â¢nÏƒ2,)

and

Iâ¢(Î¸)=1nâ¢Inâ¢(Î¸)=(1Ïƒ2002Ïƒ2).
Exercise 6.3.9.

Suppose that Yi=xiâŠ¤â¢Î²+Îµi,i=1,â€¦,n, where Îµiâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(0,Ïƒ2) with known Ïƒ>0, and xiâˆˆâ„d is assumed to be known and fixed/deterministic/non-random. Recall that the log-likelihood function is

lâ¢(Î²;Y,x)=âˆ’nâ¢logâ¡(2â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ)âˆ’12â¢Ïƒ2â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Yiâˆ’xiâŠ¤â¢Î²)2.

Find the Fisher information matrix Inâ¢(Î²)âˆˆâ„dÃ—d.

Now that we have discussed asymptotic properties of MLE. It is natural to wonder how does it compare to other potential estimators? The following result known as the CramÃ©r-Rao lower bound shows that MLE achieves the smallest variance among all unbiased estimators, asymptotically.

Theorem 6.3.10 (CramÃ©r-Rao lower bound).

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„, under certain regularity conditions, for any unbiased estimator Tâ¢(X) for Î¸, based on X=(X1,â€¦,Xn), it holds that

Varâ¢(Tâ¢(X))â‰¥1nâ¢Iâ¢(Î¸).
Remark 6.3.11.
  • â€¢

    We say an unbiased estimator based on X1,â€¦,Xn is efficient if its variance equals the lower bound 1nâ¢Iâ¢(Î¸), for any Î¸âˆˆÎ˜. However, as this is a non-asymptotic notion, finding efficient estimators can be difficult in general.

  • â€¢

    We can equivalently write the statement as, for any unbiased estimator Tâ¢(X)

    Varâ¢[nâ¢(Tâ¢(X)âˆ’Î¸)]â‰¥1Iâ¢(Î¸).

    Now, compare to the asymptotic normality of MLE in Theorem 6.3.2

    nâ¢(Î¸^MLEâˆ’Î¸)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,1Iâ¢(Î¸)),

    we observe that in the limit, MLE achieves the CramÃ©r-Rao lowerbound, which is the smallest possible variance among all unbiased estimators. Therefore, MLE is said to be asymptotically efficient.

  • â€¢

    Recall that given the asymptotically normality of MLE, we always have an asymptotic CI for Î¸ as

    Î¸^MLEÂ±z1âˆ’Î±/2â¢1nâ¢Iâ¢(Î¸^MLE),

    which has length

    2â¢z1âˆ’Î±/2nâ¢Iâ¢(Î¸^MLE)

    Therefore, we should expect asymptotic CI based on MLE to have the shortest length among all CIs based on asymptotically unbiased estimators.

6.3.3 Plug-in estimators and delta method

Theorem 6.3.12 (Delta method. This is a restatement of Theorem 4.2.13 for the purpose of inference).

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.d.â¢fâ¢(x,Î¸), Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„. Suppose

nâ¢(Î¸^nâ¢(X)âˆ’Î¸)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,Ïƒ2)

for some Ïƒ>0. Let g:â„â†’â„ be a function that is differentiable at Î¸, with gâ€²â¢(Î¸)â‰ 0. Then

nâ¢(gâ¢(Î¸^nâ¢(X))âˆ’gâ¢(Î¸))â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,(gâ€²â¢(Î¸))2â¢Ïƒ2).
Example 6.3.13.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.d.â¢Berâ¢(p), pâˆˆ(0,1). Recall from Exercise 6.2.6, the MLE for p is p^=XÂ¯n, and

nâ¢(p^âˆ’p)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,pâ¢(1âˆ’p)),

by either the CLT or by computing the Fisher information Iâ¢(p)=1pâ¢(1âˆ’p) (See Example 6.3.6).

Now, suppose we want to estimate the log-odds

gâ¢(p)=logâ¡p1âˆ’p.

The derivative of gâ¢(p) is

gâ€²â¢(p)=âˆ‚âˆ‚pâ¢(logâ¡pâˆ’logâ¡(1âˆ’p))=1p+11âˆ’p=1pâ¢(1âˆ’p)â‰ 0.

Therefore, using the plug-in estimator gâ¢(p^) and applying the delta method, we obtain

nâ¢(logâ¡p^1âˆ’p^âˆ’gâ¢(p))â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,1pâ¢(1âˆ’p)).

Since p^â¢âŸ¶â„™â¢p by the SLLN (also the fact that almost sure convergence implies convergce in probability), then

logâ¡p^1âˆ’p^Â±z1âˆ’Î±/2â¢1nâ¢p^â¢(1âˆ’p^)

is an asymptotic confidence interval (CI) for gâ¢(p) at level 1âˆ’Î±.

Theorem 6.3.14.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.d.â¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„. Let g be any function differentiable on Î˜, and let T be any unbiased estimator for gâ¢(Î¸) based on X=(X1,â€¦,Xn). Then

Varâ¢(Tâ¢(X))â‰¥(gâ€²â¢(Î¸))2nâ¢Iâ¢(Î¸).
Exercise 6.3.15.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸), where

fâ¢(x;Î¸)=Î¸â¢eâˆ’Î¸â¢x,x>0,Î¸>0.
  1. 1.

    Compute the Fisher information Iâ¢(Î¸).

  2. 2.

    Recall that Î¸^Mâ¢Lâ¢E=1/XÂ¯n, where XÂ¯n=âˆ‘i=1nXi/n. Using asymptotic properties of MLE, find an asymptotic CI for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î± with the value Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2), where Î¦ is the CDF for Nâ¢(0,1), and justify your construction.

  3. 3.

    Using the delta method to find an asymptotic CI for 1/Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î± with the value Î¦âˆ’1â¢(1âˆ’Î±/2). Could the same CI be obtained without using the delta method?

Note: You may use the fact that ğ”¼â¢(X1)=1/Î¸,Varâ¢(X1)=1/Î¸2.

6.4 Beyond MLE

It may appear that maximum likelihood estimation has largely â€˜solvedâ€™ the essential problem of learning from data that statistics is concerned with. Notably, MLEs enjoy a form of optimality in the form of asymptotic efficiency. What are some of its limitations that motivates statistical methodology beyond MLE?

In fact, there are many limitations. In particular, the assumption that we can always â€correctlyâ€ pick a statistical model is quite unrealistic. As famously said by George E. P. Box, an eminent British statistician, â€œall models are wrong, but some are usefulâ€. It would therefore make sense to consider the issue of model misspecification, e.g., X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Expâ¢(Î¸). but we treated them as X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2).

Recall that we can view MLE as maximizing some objective function, and the objective function that we choose is the likelihood function. In the case that we are not confident about our choice of statistical model, we may pick a different objective function, perhaps motivated by some characteristics that we observed in the data. Specifically, we may consider a slightly general form of obtaining estimators via optimising some objective function Mâ¢(Î¸;X). Given X=(X1,â€¦,Xn), X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜, consider

Î¸^â¢(X):=argâ¡maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡Mâ¢(Î¸;X) (6.1)

where

Mâ¢(Î¸;X):=âˆ‘i=1nmâ¢(Î¸;Xi).

Note that if mâ¢(Î¸;Xi)=logâ¡fâ¢(Xi;Î¸) and , then Î¸^â¢(X)=Î¸^Mâ¢Lâ¢Eâ¢(X). The estimator defined by (6.1) is known as M-estimators, and in the case Î˜âŠ†â„, it can be shown (Van der Vaart, 2000, Chapter 5) under some regularity conditions that

nâ¢(Î¸^â¢(X)âˆ’Î¸)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,ğ”¼â¢[(âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢mâ¢(Î¸;X1))2](ğ”¼â¢[âˆ‚2âˆ‚Î¸2â¢mâ¢(Î¸;X1)])2).

Note that when mâ¢(Î¸;X1)=logâ¡fâ¢(X1;Î¸),

ğ”¼â¢[(âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸â¢mâ¢(Î¸;X1))2](ğ”¼â¢[âˆ‚2âˆ‚Î¸2â¢mâ¢(Î¸;X1)])2=Iâ¢(Î¸)(Iâ¢(Î¸))2=1Iâ¢(Î¸),

that is if we manage to use the true log-likelihood function as the objective function, then we recover the CramÃ©r-Rao lower bound. Choosing mâ¢(Î¸;X) that is different from logâ¡fâ¢(X;Î¸) usually leads to a loss of efficiency but such a loss is usually compensated by some other benefits.

Example 6.4.1.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.d.â¢Nâ¢(Î¸,1), Î¸âˆˆâ„. The MLE for Î¸ is given by (Check this yourself!)

Î¸^MLE=argâ¡minÎ¸âˆˆâ„â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¸)2=XÂ¯n.

If we use mâ¢(Î¸,Xi)=|Xiâˆ’Î¸| instead, then

Î¸^=argâ¡minÎ¸âˆˆâ„â¢âˆ‘i=1n|Xiâˆ’Î¸|=medianâ¢{X1,â€¦,Xn}.

The median estimator Î¸^ is not as efficient as Î¸^MLE if the data are indeed generated from Nâ¢(Î¸,1), but it has the benefit of being robust to outliers within the data. Therefore, it can be imagined that Î¸^ is much more â€œefficientâ€ when the data are not normally distributed but follow a heavy-tailed distribution.

Example 6.4.2.

In the regression setting, we discussed in Exercise 6.1.4 that both MLE and ordinary least square lead to the estimator

Î²^MLE=argâ¡minÎ²âˆˆâ„dâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Yiâˆ’xiâŠ¤â¢Î²)2,

which can be solved as

Î²^MLE=(âˆ‘i=1nxiâ¢xiâŠ¤)âˆ’1â¢(âˆ‘i=1nxiâ¢Yi),

or equivalently,

Î²^MLE=(XâŠ¤â¢X)âˆ’1â¢XâŠ¤â¢Y,

if we rewrite X=(x1âŠ¤â‹®xnâŠ¤)âˆˆâ„nÃ—d and Y=(Y1â‹®Yn)âˆˆâ„n. For robustness, we can again consider

Î²^=argâ¡minÎ²âˆˆâ„dâ¢âˆ‘i=1n|Yiâˆ’xiâŠ¤â¢Î²|.

Another significant limitation of MLE in regression problems is that Î²^MLE only exists when d<n. In modern data sets, such high dimensional data sets are very common. It turns out that if we instead use

Î²^lasso=argâ¡minÎ²âˆˆâ„dâ¡{âˆ‘i=1n(Yiâˆ’xiâŠ¤â¢Î²)2+Î»â¢â€–Î²â€–1},

where â€–Î²â€–1=âˆ‘j=1d|Î²j|. Then Î²^lasso is still well-defined, even if dâ‰«n. This estimator is called the Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator (LASSO), and was proposed in Tibshirani (1996), which becomes the central object in high-dimensional statistics.

Chapter 7 Hypothesis testing

In point estimation, we focus on obtaining an estimator that is close to the true parameter and building confidence intervals based on some estimator can be seen as a way of quantifying the uncertainty of that estimator. Hypothesis testing takes a different perspective and it is about verifying certain hypothesis regarding the true parameter.

Historically, Fisher laid down the foundation of hypothesis test with the following anecdote: A colleague of Fisher claimed to be able to distinguish if in an English tea, milk was added before water (or the other way around). Fisher proposed to give her 8 cups of tea, 4 of which had milk first, and 4 of which had tea first in a random order. The point was roughly, that if she was â€œlabelingâ€ at random then she would have a small chance 1/(84)=1/70=0.014 of getting every cup right. She actually got them all correct, which would have happened by chance with probability 0.014. He concluded that since this probability was less that 0.05 that it was â€œstatistically significantâ€.

Although the language used in the above story is not based on statistical models, it represents how the null hypothesis is usually formulated in practice. The null hypothesis, denoted by H0, is usually something that you would believe to be true unless you see very strong evidence against it. Examples include that (1) a suspect is usually assumed to innocent unless there is very strong evidence against that assumption; (2) When a new drug is developed, we may assume it is not effective unless experiment results suggest otherwise; (3) We may assume after taking this module, the studentsâ€™ knowledge about statistics does not change unless the test scores suggest otherwise.

We will discuss how to make decisions based on data regarding whether to reject the null hypothesis. A very important note when interpreting the testing result is that if null hypothesis is not rejected, this does not imply it is true. Therefore, we would like to reject the null hypothesis whenever it is not true (or detect any deviation from the null) and this is essentially the role of alternative hypothesis. An alternative hypothesis, denoted by H1, is usually the complement of the null hypothesis, as implicitly assumed in the example of Fisher, although it can be anything that is different from H0. Jerzy Neyman and Egon Pearson explored the role of alternative hypothesis and developed the theoretical foundation for optimal hypothesis testing, which we shall explore later.

7.1 Testing framework and basic concepts

Suppose we are in the usual setting X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢PÎ¸,Î¸âˆˆÎ˜. The problem of hypothesis testing is usually formulated as

H0:Î¸âˆˆÎ˜0v.s.H1:Î¸âˆˆÎ˜1,

where Î˜0âˆ©Î˜1=âˆ…, but Î˜0âˆªÎ˜1 is not necessarily the whole parameter space Î˜. We call H0 the null hypothesis and H1 the alternative hypothesis. We say a hypothesis (either null or alternative) is simple if it specifies a specific value of Î¸, usually in the form of Î¸=Î¸0, for some known Î¸0. A hypothesis is composite if it is not simple, e.g.Â Î¸â‰ Î¸0,Î¸>Î¸0,Î¸âˆˆ[âˆ’Î¸0,2â¢Î¸0].

For a given testing problem, the goal is to make a choice between H0 and H1 based on some statistics Tnâ¢(X)âˆˆS, where X=(X1,â€¦,Xn). We shall call Tnâ¢(X) a test statistic and we say

Ï•â¢(X):=ğŸâ¢{Tnâ¢(X)âˆˆR}={1ifTnâ¢(X)âˆˆR0ifTnâ¢(X)âˆ‰R,

a statistical test with rejection region RâŠ†S based on Tnâ¢(X).

Example 7.1.1.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¸,1),Î¸âˆˆâ„. Suppose we want to test

H0:Î¸=0v.s.H1:Î¸â‰ 0.

Consider Tnâ¢(X)=XÂ¯n, then we may reject H0 if

|Tnâ¢(X)|>c

for some value c>0. The test is then Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{|Tnâ¢(X)|>c}, where c is a number that we need to specify. The rejection region is R=(c,âˆ)âˆª(âˆ’âˆ,âˆ’c), although we do not always need to write it out clearly as it can usually be inferred easily from the test Ï•â¢(X).

In the course of making a choice between H0 and H1, we are subject to two types of errors.

  • â€¢

    Type-I error (false positive): The null hypothesis is rejected when it is true.

  • â€¢

    Type-I error (false negative): The null hypothesis is accepted when the alternative is true.

Definition 7.1.2.

For a given test Ï•, the worst case probability of making a type-I error, supÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0â„™Î¸â¢(Tnâ¢(X)âˆˆR)=supÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0â„™Î¸â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1), is called the size or significance level of the test. We say a test has size Î±, for some Î±âˆˆ(0,1), if

supÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0â„™Î¸â¢(Tnâ¢(X)âˆˆR)â‰¤Î±,

and a test has asymptotic size Î± if

limnâ†’âˆsupÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0â„™Î¸â¢(Tnâ¢(X)âˆˆR)â‰¤Î±.

Typically the rejection region will be determined by Î± and the distribution of Tnâ¢(X) under H0. We call the distribution of Tnâ¢(X) when H0 is true, the null distribution of Tnâ¢(X).

The power function of a test is defined to be

Î²â¢(Î¸):=â„™Î¸â¢(Tnâ¢(X)âˆˆR),

and the power of a test is infÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜1Î²â¢(Î¸). We say a test has power Î², if infÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜1Î²â¢(Î¸)â‰¥Î².

Note that the notion of power is naturally related to the worse case probability of making a Type-II error:

supÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜1â„™Î¸â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=0)=1âˆ’infÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜1â„™Î¸â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1)=infÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜1Î²â¢(Î¸),

and having a small Type-II error is equivalent to having high power.

The general goal of hypothesis testing is to maximise Î²â¢(Î¸) for Î¸âˆˆÎ˜1 subject to supÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0Î²â¢(Î¸)â‰¤Î±, by designing a good test Ï•. The key to control the size of a test is to find the distribution of Tnâ¢(X) under H0, i.e.Â the null distribution.

Example 7.1.3 (Continuation from Example 7.1.1).

In Example 7.1.1, to make the test Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{|Tnâ¢(X)|>c} have size Î±, we need to choose a critical value c such that when Î¸=0

â„™Î¸=0â¢(|XÂ¯n|>c)â‰¤Î±.

Note that under H0, i.e.Â Î¸=0, we have

nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸)=nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ¼Nâ¢(0,1),

and therefore we can pick c=z1âˆ’Î±/2/n to see that

â„™Î¸=0â¢(|XÂ¯n|>z1âˆ’Î±/2/n)=Î±.

Hence the test

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{|XÂ¯n|>z1âˆ’Î±/2/n}, (7.1)

has size Î±. Much like our study of confidence intervals, we can obtain exact (non-asymptotic) size control of Ï•â¢(X) because we know the distribution XÂ¯n for every finite n. This knowledge is underpinned by the assumption that X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¸,1). When the data do not follow normal distribution, we usually need to resort to central limit theorem and related asymptotic results to obtain an asymptotic size control.

After controlling the size of Ï•â¢(X), letâ€™s consider the power function, i.e.

Î²â¢(Î¸)=â„™Î¸â¢(Tnâ¢(X)âˆˆR)=â„™Î¸â¢(|XÂ¯n|>z1âˆ’Î±/2/n).

Note that when Î¸=0, this is just the probability of making a type-I error. For a general Î¸, we have

â„™Î¸â¢(|XÂ¯n|>z1âˆ’Î±/2/n)=â„™Î¸â¢(XÂ¯n>z1âˆ’Î±/2/n)+â„™Î¸â¢(XÂ¯n<âˆ’z1âˆ’Î±/2/n).

To control the first term, we have

â„™Î¸â¢(XÂ¯n>z1âˆ’Î±/2/n)=â„™Î¸â¢(nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸)>z1âˆ’Î±/2âˆ’nâ¢Î¸)=1âˆ’Î¦â¢(z1âˆ’Î±/2âˆ’Î¸â¢n),

where the last inequality is due to nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸)âˆ¼Nâ¢(0,1) for any Î¸âˆˆâ„ and Î¦â¢(x) is the CDF for Nâ¢(0,1). Similarly, for the second term, we have

â„™Î¸â¢(XÂ¯n<âˆ’z1âˆ’Î±/2/n)=â„™Î¸â¢(nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¸)<âˆ’z1âˆ’Î±/2âˆ’Î¸â¢n)=Î¦â¢(âˆ’z1âˆ’Î±/2âˆ’Î¸â¢n).

Together, we obtain the power function for Ï•â¢(X) as

Î²â¢(Î¸)=1âˆ’Î¦â¢(z1âˆ’Î±/2âˆ’Î¸â¢n)+Î¦â¢(âˆ’z1âˆ’Î±/2âˆ’Î¸â¢n).

We make the following remarks regarding the power function

  • â€¢

    For Î¸=0, Î²â¢(Î¸)=Î±.

  • â€¢

    For any given value of Î¸â‰ 0, Î²â¢(Î¸)â†’1 as nâ†’âˆ. That is, if the data generating distribution is Nâ¢(Î¸,1), then the probability that the test Ï• rejects the null hypothesis (making the right decision) will increase as the sample size increases.

  • â€¢

    For any given value of n, Î²â¢(Î¸)â†’1 as |Î¸|â†’âˆ. That is, if we collect n data points, and assume that they are i.i.d from Nâ¢(Î¸,1), then the probability that the test Ï• rejects the null hypothesis (making the right decision) will increase as |Î¸| increases.

Remark 7.1.4.
  1. 1.

    The reason that we need to analyse the power function is that there are infinite number of tests that can have size Î±, i.e.Â control the probability of Type-I error to be at most Î±. Some of the trivial examples include Ï•1â¢(X)=0, which has size 0 and power 0, and Ï•2â¢(X)=Y, where Yâˆ¼Berâ¢(Î±) is a random variable that is independent of X, and it has size Î±, power Î±. Therefore, one should aim to choose a test that has the highest power among all size Î± tests. We will discuss this aspect in the simple vs simple testing scenario.

  2. 2.

    Now, letâ€™s formulate the typical steps that one would take in practice to perform a hypothesis test:

    • â€¢

      Formulate the null hypothesis and the alternative hypothesis(sometimes implicit) regarding some statistical model.

    • â€¢

      Find a test statistic Tâ¢(X) and determine the rejection region by controlling the size at Î±.

    • â€¢

      (*)Find the power function of your test. For a given value Î²âˆˆ(0,1), the power function can be used calculate the smallest n such that Î²â¢(Î¸)â‰¥Î² for some given value of Î¸. It can also be used to compute {Î¸:Î²â¢(Î¸)â‰¥Î²}.

    • â€¢

      Collect data and perform the test as determined in the second step.

7.1.1 One-sided tests and confidence intervals

Sometime, we might be interested in a one-sided test which has a different alternative hypothesis than the one in Example 7.1.1.

Exercise 7.1.5.

Let X1â¢â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2), where Ïƒ is known. Consider the following testing problem

H0:Î¼=0v.s.H1:Î¼>0.

Show that the test

Ï•1â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{nâ¢XÂ¯n>Ïƒâ¢z1âˆ’Î±}

has size Î±. Find the power function Î²1â¢(Î¼) for Ï•1â¢(X). Show that

Ï•2â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{|nâ¢XÂ¯n|>Ïƒâ¢z1âˆ’Î±/2}

also has size Î±. Find the power function Î²2â¢(Î¼) for Ï•2â¢(X). For a given value of n, guess which is larger, Î²1â¢(Î¼) or Î²2â¢(Î¼), when Î¼>0?

A general way to construct a reasonable test that has size control is using confidence intervals as shown in the following theorem.

Theorem 7.1.6.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„. Consider any testing problem that has H0:Î¸=Î¸0. Suppose Cnâ¢(X) is a confidence interval for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±. Then, the test

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{Î¸0âˆ‰Cnâ¢(X)}

has size Î±. If Cnâ¢(X) is an asymptotic confidence interval, then Ï•â¢(X) has asymptotic size Î±.

Proof.

To show Ï•â¢(X) has size Î±, we just check when Î¸=Î¸0

â„™Î¸0â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1)=â„™Î¸0â¢(Î¸0âˆ‰Cnâ¢(X))â‰¤Î±,

since â„™Î¸0â¢(Î¸0âˆ‰Cnâ¢(X))â‰¥1âˆ’Î± by the definition of a confidence interval. Taking the limit as nâ†’âˆ in the above equation validates the asymptotic case. âˆ

Example 7.1.7.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Expâ¢(Î¸),Î¸>0. Recall from Exercise 6.3.15 that the MLE for Î¸ is Tnâ¢(X)=1/XÂ¯n and it holds that

nâ¢(Tnâ¢(X)âˆ’Î¸)â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Nâ¢(0,Î¸2),

which implies

Cnâ¢(X)=[Tnâ¢(X)âˆ’z1âˆ’Î±/2â¢Tnâ¢(X)n,Tnâ¢(X)+z1âˆ’Î±/2â¢Tnâ¢(X)n]

is an asymptotic CI for Î¸ at level 1âˆ’Î±. Then consider the testing problem

H0:Î¸=Î¸0v.s.H1:Î¸â‰ Î¸0.

with the test

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{Î¸0âˆ‰Cnâ¢(X)}=ğŸâ¢{|Tnâ¢(X)âˆ’Î¸0|>z1âˆ’Î±/2â¢Tnâ¢(X)n}.

To see this test has asymptotic size Î±, we compute under H0â¢(Î¸=Î¸0),

â„™Î¸0â¢(|Tnâ¢(X)âˆ’Î¸0|>z1âˆ’Î±/2â¢Tnâ¢(X)n)=â„™Î¸0â¢(|nâ¢Tnâ¢(X)âˆ’Î¸0Tnâ¢(X)|>z1âˆ’Î±/2)â†’â„™â¢(|Z|>z1âˆ’Î±/2)=Î±.

7.2 Testing in normal models

We introduce some of the common tests in this section under the assumption that the data are normally distributed. The normal assumptions are critical in deriving the null distribution of test statistics and therefore we can have non-asymptotic size control in these cases.

7.2.1 One-sample t test

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2),Î¼âˆˆâ„,Ïƒ>0, with both Î¼ and Ïƒ unknown. Consider the testing problem:

H0:Î¼=Î¼0v.s.H1:Î¼â‰ Î¼0.

with the test statistic

Tnâ¢(X)=nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0S,

where S=1nâˆ’1â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2 is the sample variance. The (one-sample) t test takes the form

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{|Tnâ¢(X)|>c},

where c is chosen such that the test has size Î±. To choose the critical value c, we need to understand the distribution of Tnâ¢(X) under H0, i.e.Â the null distribution.

Recall that (nâˆ’1)â¢S2/Ïƒ2âˆ¼Ï‡nâˆ’12. Therefore, we have under H0,

Tnâ¢(X)=nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0S=nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0ÏƒS/Ïƒâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢ZW,

where Zâˆ¼Nâ¢(0,1) and W2âˆ¼1nâˆ’1â¢Ï‡nâˆ’12, and in fact Z and W are independent since XÂ¯n and âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2 are independent under the normal distribution assumption.

Definition 7.2.1.

If Zâˆ¼Nâ¢(0,1) and Uâˆ¼Ï‡n2 and Z and U are independent, then the distribution of

ZU/n

is call the t distribution with n degree of freedom, denoted as tn.

Therefore, under H0, we have

Tnâ¢(X)âˆ¼tnâˆ’1

and this null distribution suggests that choosing c=tnâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±, i.e. the value such that

â„™Î¼0â¢(|Tnâ¢(X)|>tnâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/2)=Î±, (7.2)

ensures the test Ï•â¢(X) has size Î±.

Remark 7.2.2.

More generally, for one-sided tests, e.g. H1:Î¼>Î¼0 or H1:Î¼<Î¼0. Tests Ï•1â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{Tnâ¢(X)>tnâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±} and Ï•2â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{Tnâ¢(X)<âˆ’tnâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±} would be preferred correspondingly.

Moreover, (7.2) actually implies a non-asymptotic CI for Î¼0, since

â„™Î¼0â¢(|Tnâ¢(X)|â‰¤tnâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/2) =â„™Î¼0â¢(|nâ¢XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0S|â‰¤tnâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/2)
=â„™Î¼0â¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Snâ¢tnâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/2â‰¤Î¼0â‰¤XÂ¯n+Snâ¢tnâˆ’1,1âˆ’Î±/2)=1âˆ’Î±

In fact, we can always obtain confidence intervals from the acceptance region of a test, as stated in the following result.

Theorem 7.2.3.

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„. Consider any testing problem that has H0:Î¸=Î¸0. If the test

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{Tnâ¢(X)âˆˆRÎ±â¢(Î¸0)}

has size Î±, then

Cnâ¢(X)={Î¸0:Tnâ¢(X)âˆ‰RÎ±â¢(Î¸0)},

is a CI for Î¸0 at level 1âˆ’Î±.

Exercise 7.2.4.

Prove the above theorem.

7.2.2 Two-Sample t Test

Many hypothesis testing problems arise in the context of comparing two sets of samples. The two-sample t test considers the following setup:

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼X,Ïƒ2) and Y1,â€¦,Ymâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼Y,Ïƒ2) with Î¼Xâˆˆâ„,Î¼Yâˆˆâ„,Ïƒ>0 all unknown. We are interested in testing

H0:Î¼X=Î¼Yv.s.H1:Î¼Xâ‰ Î¼Y

We shall use the following test statistic

T:=Tn,mâ¢(X,Y)=XÂ¯nâˆ’YÂ¯mSpâ¢1n+1m

where XÂ¯n and YÂ¯m are the sample means for X=(X1,â€¦,Xn) and Y=(Y1,â€¦,Ym), respectively, and

Sp2=(nâˆ’1)â¢SX2+(mâˆ’1)â¢SY2n+mâˆ’2=1n+mâˆ’2â¢(âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2+âˆ‘i=1m(Yiâˆ’YÂ¯m)2).

The test will be

Ï•â¢(X,Y)=ğŸâ¢{|T|>c},

where c is chosen such that Ï•â¢(X,Y) has size Î±.

To choose the critical value, we need to again understand the null distribution of Tn. To that end, we write

T=XÂ¯nâˆ’YÂ¯mSpâ¢1n+1m=XÂ¯nâˆ’YÂ¯mÏƒâ¢1n+1mâ‹…Ïƒ2/Sp2.

Note that under H0, XÂ¯nâˆ’YÂ¯mâˆ¼Nâ¢(0,Ïƒ2â¢(1/n+1/m)) and

Sp2Ïƒ2âˆ¼1n+mâˆ’2â¢Ï‡n+mâˆ’22,

since X and Y are independent. Therefore,

Tâ¢=ğ‘‘â¢ZW,

where Zâˆ¼Nâ¢(0,1) and W2âˆ¼1n+mâˆ’2â¢Ï‡n+mâˆ’22, and that means Tâˆ¼tn+mâˆ’2. Hence, choosing c=tn+mâˆ’2,1âˆ’Î±/2 ensures that Ï•â¢(X,Y) has size Î± since t distribution is symmetric.

7.3 Likelihood ratio tests

Using the duality between confidence interval and hypothesis tests, we can easily obtain tests with size control; see Theorem 7.1.6. These CIs are often obtained by the asymptotic properties of MLE. However, this approach of obtaining tests are (at least in our discussion) restricted to the case of testing a single univarite parameter, i.e.Â Î¸âˆˆÎ˜âŠ†â„. In this section, we introduce a more general approach that leads to tests for general parameter spaces Î˜ based on likelihood ratios.

7.3.1 Simple vs simple

We start with the following simple vs simple testing problem. Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜, and we are interested in testing

H0:Î¸=Î¸0v.s.H1:Î¸=Î¸1.

Consider the test statistic
