Tnâ¢(X)=Lâ¢(Î¸1;X)Lâ¢(Î¸0;X),

where Lâ¢(Î¸;X)=âˆi=1nfâ¢(Xi;Î¸) is the likelihood function. The likelihood ratio test in this case is

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{Tnâ¢(X)>c},
Theorem 7.3.1 (Neyman-Pearson Lemma).

In the likelihood ratio test Ï•â¢(X) defined above, if c is chosen such that PÎ¸0â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1)=Î±, i.e.Â the size of the test is equal to Î±, then for any other test Ï•â€²â¢(X) that has size Î±, it holds that

Î²Ï•â¢(Î¸1)=PÎ¸1â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1)â‰¥PÎ¸1â¢(Ï•â€²â¢(X)=1)=Î²Ï•â€²â¢(Î¸1).

In other words, Ï•â¢(X) has the highest power among all size-Î± tests. If the size of likelihood ratio test is asymptotically equal to Î±, then it has the highest power among all size-Î± tests asymptotically.

Proof.

We write

â„™Î¸1â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1)âˆ’â„™Î¸1â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1) =ğ”¼Î¸1â¢[Ï•â¢(X)]âˆ’ğ”¼Î¸1â¢[Ï•â€²â¢(X)]=ğ”¼â¢[Ï•â¢(X)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(X)]
=âˆ«(Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x))â¢âˆi=1nfâ¢(xi;Î¸1)â¢dâ¢x
=âˆ«(Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x))â¢Lâ¢(Î¸1;x)â¢ğ‘‘x

Note that due to the size constraints

ğ”¼Î¸0â¢[Ï•â¢(X)]=Î±=âˆ«Ï•â¢(x)â¢Lâ¢(Î¸0;x)â¢ğ‘‘x,ğ”¼Î¸0â¢[Ï•â€²â¢(X)]=âˆ«Ï•â€²â¢(x)â¢Lâ¢(Î¸0;x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ‰¤Î±,

which implies

âˆ«(Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x))â¢Lâ¢(Î¸0;x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ‰¥0andâˆ«(Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x))â¢câ¢Lâ¢(Î¸0;x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ‰¥0 (7.3)

for any constant c>0. Now, consider the quantity

âˆ«(Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x))â¢(Lâ¢(Î¸1;x)âˆ’câ¢Lâ¢(Î¸0;x))â¢ğ‘‘x,

and notice that

ifÂ â¢Lâ¢(Î¸1;x)>câ¢Lâ¢(Î¸0;x)âŸ¹Ï•â¢(x)=1âŸ¹Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x)â‰¥0,

since Ï•â€²â¢(x) and Ï•â¢(x) both only take value from {0,1}, and

ifÂ â¢Lâ¢(Î¸1;x)â‰¤câ¢Lâ¢(Î¸0;x)âŸ¹Ï•â¢(x)=0âŸ¹Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x)â‰¤0.

With these two observations, we conclude that

âˆ«(Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x))â¢(Lâ¢(Î¸1;x)âˆ’câ¢Lâ¢(Î¸0;x))â¢ğ‘‘xâ‰¥0.

Since

âˆ«(Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x))â¢câ¢Lâ¢(Î¸0;x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ‰¥0,

from (7.3), it holds that

â„™Î¸1â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1)âˆ’â„™Î¸1â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1)=âˆ«(Ï•â¢(x)âˆ’Ï•â€²â¢(x))â¢Lâ¢(Î¸1;x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ‰¥0,

which is the statement that we aim to prove. âˆ

Example 7.3.2.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2) with known variance Ïƒ2. We want to test:

H0:Î¼=Î¼0v.s.H1:Î¼=Î¼1,

where Î¼1>Î¼0. The likelihood ratio test statistic can be computed as

Lâ¢(Î¼0) =âˆi=1nfâ¢(Xi;Î¼0)=(12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ2)nâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼0)22â¢Ïƒ2),
Lâ¢(Î¼1) =âˆi=1nfâ¢(Xi;Î¼1)=(12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ2)nâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼1)22â¢Ïƒ2).
Tnâ¢(X) =expâ¡(âˆ‘i=1n{(Xiâˆ’Î¼0)2âˆ’(Xiâˆ’Î¼1)2}2â¢Ïƒ2).

Since

âˆ‘i=1n{(Xiâˆ’Î¼0)2âˆ’(Xiâˆ’Î¼1)2}=âˆ’2â¢âˆ‘i=1nXiâ¢(Î¼0âˆ’Î¼1)+nâ¢(Î¼02âˆ’Î¼12),

We have

Tnâ¢(X)=expâ¡(2â¢nâ¢XÂ¯nâ¢(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼0)+nâ¢(Î¼02âˆ’Î¼12)2â¢Ïƒ2).

Now the likelihood ratio test suggests that we use

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{Tnâ¢(X)>c},

where c is chosen to make the test has size Î±. However, Tnâ¢(X) is a complicated function of the data and we notice that since Î¼1>Î¼0, Tnâ¢(X) is an increasing function of XÂ¯n, which implies

{Tnâ¢(X)>c}â‡”{XÂ¯n>câ€²}.

Therefore, we can just find the value câ€² and the test Ï•â€²â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{XÂ¯n>câ€²} would be equivalent to Ï•â¢(X) with a corresponding value c, i.e.Â they have the same power function. Now, since under H0, XÂ¯nâˆ¼Nâ¢(Î¼0,Ïƒ2/n), we have

â„™Î¼0â¢(nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)Ïƒ>z1âˆ’Î±)=Î±âŸ¹â„™Î¼0â¢(XÂ¯n>Î¼0+Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±)=Î±.

Therefore,

Ï•â€²â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{XÂ¯n>Î¼0+Ïƒnâ¢z1âˆ’Î±}

has size equal to Î± and according to the Neyman-Pearson Lemma, it is the most power test against H1 among all size Î± tests.

7.3.2 Generalised likelihood ratio tests

Let X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜. In this section, we are interested in a general hypothesis testing that is beyond the simple vs simple case. In particualr, consider

H0:Î¸âˆˆÎ˜0v.s.H1:Î¸âˆ‰Î˜0.

The generalised likelihood ratio (GLR) statistics is defined as

Tnâ¢(X)=maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0â¡Lâ¢(Î¸;X)maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡Lâ¢(Î¸;X),

where Lâ¢(Î¸;X) is the likelihood function. The GLR test is defined as

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{Tnâ¢(X)â‰¤c},

where c is some value that is chosen to make Ï•â¢(X) has size Î± or asymptotic size Î±.

To compute this test statistic, we need to find two â€˜MLEâ€™s. One of them is the usual MLE, i.e. Î¸^=argâ¢maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡Lâ¢(Î¸) and the other is the MLE when the parameter space is restricted to Î˜0, i.e. Î¸^0=argâ¢maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0â¡Lâ¢(Î¸). Once these two MLEs are found, the GLR statistic is just

Tnâ¢(X)=Lâ¢(Î¸^0;X)Lâ¢(Î¸^;X).

Note that when H0 is a simple hypothesis, i.e. H0:Î¸=Î¸0 (which implies H1:Î¸â‰ Î¸0), then the GLR statistic simplifies to

Tnâ¢(X)=Lâ¢(Î¸0;X)Lâ¢(Î¸^;X).
Example 7.3.3.

Suppose X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2) with known variance Ïƒ2, Î¼âˆˆâ„. We want to test:

H0:Î¼=Î¼0v.s.H1:Î¼â‰ Î¼0.

The likelihood function is:

Lâ¢(Î¼)=âˆi=1n12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’(Xiâˆ’Î¼)22â¢Ïƒ2).

Under H0, which is a simple hypothesis

Lâ¢(Î¼0)=âˆi=1n12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’(Xiâˆ’Î¼0)22â¢Ïƒ2).

Recall that the MLE of Î¼ is Î¼^=XÂ¯n=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nXi. Thus:

Lâ¢(Î¼^)=âˆi=1n12â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒâ¢expâ¡(âˆ’(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)22â¢Ïƒ2).

The GLR test statistic is:

Tnâ¢(X)=Lâ¢(Î¼0)Lâ¢(Î¼^)=expâ¡(âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)22â¢Ïƒ2âˆ’âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼0)22â¢Ïƒ2).

Using the decomposition âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼0)2=âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2+nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)2, we get:

Tnâ¢(X)=expâ¡(âˆ’nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)22â¢Ïƒ2)

There are two ways we can find tests that are equivalent to ğŸâ¢{Tnâ¢(X)â‰¤c}, one is noticing that the function eâˆ’x2 is a decreasing function of |x|, and therefore

Tnâ¢(X)â‰¤câ‡”|nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)2â¢Ïƒ|â‰¥câ€².

It is sufficient to choose câ€² such that the equivalent test has size Î±. Observe that under H0

â„™â¢(|nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)Ïƒ|â‰¥z1âˆ’Î±/2)=Î±.

Therefore, we can use the test

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{|nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)Ïƒ|â‰¥z1âˆ’Î±/2},

which is equivalent to the likelihood ratio test that has size Î±.

Another possibility that is more general is to consider

âˆ’2â¢logâ¡(Tnâ¢(X))=nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)2Ïƒ2.

Since the function âˆ’2â¢logâ¡(x) is decreasing in x, we can equivalently reject H0 when

nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)2Ïƒ2â‰¥câ€²â€²

for some câ€²â€². Under H0, (XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)/(Ïƒ/n)âˆ¼Nâ¢(0,1), so âˆ’2â¢logâ¡(Tnâ¢(X)) follows a Ï‡12 distribution. Therefore, we have

â„™Î¼0â¢(nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)2Ïƒ2>Ï‡1,1âˆ’Î±2)=Î±,

and an equivalent test to the likelihood ratio test that has has size Î± is

ğŸâ¢{nâ¢(XÂ¯nâˆ’Î¼0)2Ïƒ2>Ï‡1,1âˆ’Î±2}.

This example also shows Ï‡1,1âˆ’Î±2=(z1âˆ’Î±/2)2, e.g. z0.975=1.96,Ï‡1,0.952=3.84 which can be obtained using qnormâ¢(0.975) and qchisqâ¢(0.95,1) in R, respectively.

A general rule to select critical values for a GLR test to achieve asymptotic size Î± is stated in the following theorem.

Theorem 7.3.4 (Asymptotic property of the GLR test under H0).

Suppose that X1,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢fâ¢(x;Î¸),Î¸âˆˆÎ˜0, where Î˜0 is the space in H0. Under some regularity conditions (similar to those required for the asymptotic properties of MLE to hold), then

âˆ’2â¢logâ¡(Tnâ¢(X))â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Ï‡k2,

where

Tnâ¢(X)=maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0â¡Lâ¢(Î¸;X)maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡Lâ¢(Î¸;X),

and k=dimâ¢(Î˜)âˆ’dimâ¢(Î˜0).

Recall that âˆ’2â¢logâ¡(x) is a decreasing function in x, the above theorem shows that the test

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{âˆ’2â¢logâ¡(Tnâ¢(X))>Ï‡k,1âˆ’Î±2}

has asymptotic size Î±111Technically speaking, Theorem 7.3.4 only implies limnâ†’âˆâ„™Î¸â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1)=Î± for all Î¸âˆˆÎ˜0. When Î˜0 is a composite hypothesis, we essentially need limnâ†’âˆsupÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0â„™Î¸â¢(Ï•â¢(X)=1)â‰¤Î± to claim it has asymptotic size Î±; See Definition 7.1.2. However, we ignore this difference between pointwise convergence and uniform convergence and still say that Ï•â¢(X) has asymptotic size Î±..

The dimension in the theorem statement can be thought as the number of free variables in the space, e.g. in Example 7.3.3

  • â€¢

    H0:Î¼=Î¼0 can be written as H0:Î¼âˆˆ{Î¼:Î¼=Î¼0}. Since there is no free variable (the only variable Î¼ is fixed to the value Î¼0), therefore dim(Î˜0) = 0. The whole parameter space {Î¼:Î¼âˆˆâ„}={Î¼:Î¼âˆˆ(âˆ’âˆ,âˆ)} has dimension one, i.e. dim(Î˜)=1.

Note that the above theorem does not apply to the simple vs simple testing problem! - this is because the proof of this theorem relies on asymptotic property of MLEs whereas in the simple vs simple testing problem, no computation of MLE is involved.

Example 7.3.5.

X1,X2,â€¦,Xnâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2), Î¼âˆˆâ„ and Ïƒ>0. Both Î¼ and Ïƒ are unknown. Consider

H0:Î¼=Î¼0v.s.H1:Î¼â‰ Î¼0.

Note that this is exactly the same setup as the one-sample t test. You will show in an exercise the t-test is equivalent to the GLR test. Let Î¸=(Î¼,Ïƒ2), since Ïƒ is unknown, the full parameter space is

Î˜={(Î¼,Ïƒ2):âˆ’âˆ<Î¼<âˆ,Ïƒ2>0}

and

Î˜0={(Î¼0,Ïƒ2):Ïƒ2>0}.

H0 is a composite hypothesis with one free variable, and therefore dimÎ˜0=1. Hence k=dimÎ˜âˆ’dimÎ˜0=2âˆ’1=1.

Now the likelihood is

Lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2;X)=(2â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ2)âˆ’n2â¢expâ¡{âˆ’12â¢Ïƒ2â¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼)2}.

Under H0, Î¼=Î¼0 and Lâ¢(Î¼0,Ïƒ2;X) is maximised by taking Ïƒ2 equal to

Ïƒ~2=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Î¼0)2.

(Check this!) That is

maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜0â¡Lâ¢(Î¼0,Ïƒ2;X)=(2â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ~2)âˆ’n2â¢expâ¡{âˆ’n2}.

The usual unrestricted MLEs are Î¼^=XÂ¯n and Ïƒ^2=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯n)2, so that

maxÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡Lâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2;X)=(2â¢Ï€â¢Ïƒ^2)âˆ’n2â¢expâ¡{âˆ’n2}.

Therefore the GLR statistic is

Tnâ¢(X)=(Ïƒ~2Ïƒ^2)âˆ’n2,

and H0 is rejected if Tnâ¢(X)â‰¤c for some c. One way to determine the critical value is by realising that the one-sample t-test is an equivalent test and we can achieve non-asymptotic size Î± control. Alternatively, we can use the asymptotic property of GLR in Theorem 7.3.4, i.e. Under H0,

âˆ’2â¢logâ¡(Tnâ¢(X))=nâ¢(logâ¡(Ïƒ~2)âˆ’logâ¡(Ïƒ^2))â¢âŸ¶ğ‘‘â¢Ï‡2âˆ’12=Ï‡12.

Therefore,

Ï•â¢(X)=ğŸâ¢{nâ¢(logâ¡(Ïƒ~2)âˆ’logâ¡(Ïƒ^2))>Ï‡1,1âˆ’Î±2}

has asymptotic size Î±. âˆ

We will cover the material below if there is sufficient time.

We conclude our discussion on hypothesis testing with a multinomial example. We first introduce the multinomial distribution. Recall that if Y1,â€¦,Ynâ¢âˆ¼i.i.dâ¢Berâ¢(p), then Y=âˆ‘i=1nYiâˆ¼Binâ¢(n,p), where Y just counts the number of successful trials. Multinomial distribution is an extension of the binomial distribution. Suppose each trial has k distinct possible outcomes, and we independently perform n such trials. Let Xi denote the number of trials that i-th outcome occurs. We write

(X1,â€¦,Xk)âˆ¼Multinomialâ¢(n;p1,â€¦,pk),withÂ â¢âˆ‘i=1kpi=1.

and it has probability mass function

Pâ¢(X1=x1,â€¦,Xk=xk)=n!x1!â¢â‹¯â¢xk!â¢p1x1â¢p2x2â¢â‹¯â¢pkxk,forÂ â¢âˆ‘i=1kxi=n.

Note that the parameter space Î˜={p1,â€¦,pk:âˆ‘i=1kpi=1,0â‰¤piâ‰¤1,i=1â¢â€¦,k} has dimension kâˆ’1, as once kâˆ’1 of the values of pi are known the remaining value is also known. Note that X1,â€¦,Xn are not independent as âˆ‘i=1nXi=n. Given the pmf, we may find the MLE for p1,â€¦,pk with the constraint that âˆ‘i=1kpi=1, i.e.

argâ¢maxp1,â€¦,pk:âˆ‘i=1kpi=1â¡Lâ¢(p1,â€¦,pk)=argâ¢maxp1,â€¦,pk:âˆ‘i=1kpi=1â¡n!X1!â¢â‹¯â¢Xk!â¢p1X1â¢p2X2â¢â‹¯â¢pkXk

This constraint optimisation problem can be solved using the Lagrange multipliers method, i.e.

lâ¢(p1,â€¦,pk,Î»):=logâ¡(Lâ¢(p1,â€¦,pk))+Î»â¢(âˆ‘i=1kpiâˆ’1).

Setting the partial derivative with respect to each pi and Î» to 0, yields

p^i=XiÎ»âˆ€i={1,â€¦,k},âˆ‘i=1kp^i=1âŸ¹p^i=Xin,

which are in fact the MLE for pi.

Example 7.3.6 (Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium).

Now, we consider a specific example of hypothesis testing that involves the multinomial example. At a single diallelic locus in the genome with two possible alleles A and a, any individual can have genotype Aâ¢A, Aâ¢a, or aâ¢a. If we randomly select n individuals from a population, we may model the numbers of individuals with these genotypes as (XAâ¢A,XAâ¢a,Xaâ¢a)âˆ¼Multinomialâ¢(n,(pAâ¢A,pAâ¢a,paâ¢a)).

When the alleles A and a are present in the population with proportions Î¸ and 1âˆ’Î¸, then under an assumption of random mating, quantitative genetics theory predicts that pAâ¢A,pAâ¢a, and paâ¢a should be given by

pAâ¢A=Î¸2,pAâ¢a=2â¢Î¸â¢(1âˆ’Î¸),paâ¢a=(1âˆ’Î¸)2

â€”this is called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. In practice, we do not know Î¸, but we may still test the null hypothesis that Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium holds for some Î¸:

H0:pAâ¢A=Î¸2,pAâ¢a=2â¢Î¸â¢(1âˆ’Î¸),paâ¢a=(1âˆ’Î¸)2â¢for someÂ â¢Î¸âˆˆ(0,1).

and H1 is simply H0 is not true. This null hypothesis has dimension 1 (with a single free parameter Î¸) and the full parameter space {pAâ¢A,pAâ¢a,paâ¢a:pAâ¢A+pAâ¢a+paâ¢a=1} has dimension 2. We first find the GLR test statistic.

The multinomial likelihood is given by

Lâ¢(pAâ¢A,pAâ¢a,paâ¢a)=(nXAâ¢A,XAâ¢a,Xaâ¢a)â¢pAâ¢AXAâ¢Aâ¢pAâ¢aXAâ¢aâ¢paâ¢aXaâ¢a,

where (nXAâ¢A,XAâ¢a,Xaâ¢a)=n!XAâ¢A!â¢XAâ¢a!â¢Xaâ¢a!. Letting p^Aâ¢A,p^Aâ¢a,p^aâ¢a denote the full-model MLEs and p^0,Aâ¢A,p^0,Aâ¢a,p^0,aâ¢a denote the MLE under H0, the generalized likelihood ratio is

Tn=(p^0,Aâ¢Ap^Aâ¢A)XAâ¢Aâ¢(p^0,Aâ¢ap^Aâ¢a)XAâ¢aâ¢(p^0,aâ¢ap^aâ¢a)Xaâ¢a,

so

âˆ’2â¢logâ¡Tn=2â¢XAâ¢Aâ¢logâ¡p^Aâ¢Ap^0,Aâ¢A+2â¢XAâ¢aâ¢logâ¡p^Aâ¢ap^0,Aâ¢a+2â¢Xaâ¢aâ¢logâ¡p^aâ¢ap^0,aâ¢a.

The full-model MLEs are p^Aâ¢A=XAâ¢An, p^Aâ¢a=XAâ¢an, and p^aâ¢a=Xaâ¢an as discussed before this example. To find the MLEs under H0, note that under H0, the multinomial likelihood as a function of Î¸ is

Lâ¢(Î¸)=(nXAâ¢A,XAâ¢a,Xaâ¢a)â¢(Î¸2)XAâ¢Aâ¢(2â¢Î¸â¢(1âˆ’Î¸))XAâ¢aâ¢((1âˆ’Î¸)2)Xaâ¢a=(nXAâ¢A,XAâ¢a,Xaâ¢a)â¢2XAâ¢aâ¢Î¸2â¢XAâ¢A+XAâ¢aâ¢(1âˆ’Î¸)XAâ¢a+2â¢Xaâ¢a.

Maximizing the likelihood over parameters (pAâ¢A,pAâ¢a,paâ¢a) when H0 is true is equivalent to maximizing the above over Î¸. Differentiating the logarithm of the above likelihood and setting it equal to 0, we obtain the MLE

Î¸^=2â¢XAâ¢A+XAâ¢a2â¢XAâ¢A+2â¢XAâ¢a+2â¢Xaâ¢a=2â¢XAâ¢A+XAâ¢a2â¢n

for Î¸ (Check the second order derivative yourself!), which yields

p^0,Aâ¢A=(2â¢XAâ¢A+XAâ¢a2â¢n)2,
p^0,Aâ¢a=2â¢(2â¢XAâ¢A+XAâ¢a2â¢n)â¢(XAâ¢a+2â¢Xaâ¢a2â¢n),
p^0,aâ¢a=(XAâ¢a+2â¢Xaâ¢a2â¢n)2.

Substituting these expressions into equation (22.1) yields the formula for âˆ’2â¢logâ¡Î› in terms of the data XAâ¢A,XAâ¢a,Xaâ¢a. The difference in dimensionality of Î˜0 and Î˜ is 2âˆ’1=1, so by the asymptotic property of the GLR test,

Ï•â¢(XAâ¢A,XAâ¢a,Xaâ¢a)=ğŸâ¢{âˆ’2â¢logâ¡Tn>Ï‡1,1âˆ’Î±2}

has asymptotic size-Î±.

As a numerical example, suppose n=1029 and XAâ¢A=342, XAâ¢a=500, Xaâ¢a=187, and we may calculate âˆ’2â¢logâ¡Î›=0.0325. Since Ï‡1,0.952=3.84, we cannot reject H0 with a test has asymptotic size 0.05. If we choose an Î±>0.05, then it is easier to reject H0. One may ask what is the smallest Î±, such that we can reject H0 given this data. It turns out that since Ï‡1,0.1432=0.03247, we can reject H0 at level 1âˆ’0.143=0.857, which means the probability that we wrongly H0 is as high as 0.857! The notion of the smallest Î±, such that we can reject H0 is known as p-value. In words, the p-value of a test is the probability of the test statistics being at least as extreme as the result actually observed, under the assumption that the null hypothesis is correct. The value of 0.014 in Fisherâ€™s story is also an example of p-value. The notion of p-value is none-examinable, but for some technical details, see Section 2.5.

Appendix A Technical Appendix

Proof of Lemma 1.1.14.
  1. (i)

    Let (Bn)nâˆˆâ„• be defined by

    B1 =A1
    B2 =A2âˆ–A1
    â‹®
    Bn =Anâˆ–(A1âˆªâ‹¯âˆªAnâˆ’1).

    Clearly, this sequence is pairwise disjoint. Moreover, observe that

    An+1=(An+1âˆ–â‹ƒk=1nAk)âˆªâ‹ƒk=1nAk=Bn+1âˆªâ‹ƒk=1nAk,

    since (An)n is increasing. It therefore follows easily by induction that for any nâˆˆâ„•, â‹ƒk=1nAk=â‹ƒk=1nBk and therefore also â‹ƒn=1âˆAn=â‹ƒn=1âˆBn. Consequently, using disjointness and Ïƒ-additivity, we have

    Î¼â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•An)=Î¼â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•Bn) =âˆ‘nâˆˆâ„•Î¼â¢(Bn)
    =limnâ†’âˆâˆ‘k=1nÎ¼â¢(Bk)
    =limnâ†’âˆÎ¼â¢(â‹ƒk=1nBk)
    =limnâ†’âˆÎ¼â¢(â‹ƒk=1nAk)
    =limnâ†’âˆÎ¼â¢(An),

    where the last line follows from the assumption that (An)n is increasing.

  2. (ii)

    Since An+1âŠƒAn we have A1âˆ–AnâŠ‚A1âˆ–An+1. Thus, the sequence (A1âˆ–An)n is increasing and (i) yields

    Î¼â¢(A1âˆ–â‹‚nâˆˆâ„•An)=Î¼â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•(A1âˆ–An))=limnâ†’âˆÎ¼â¢(A1âˆ–An)=limnâ†’âˆ(Î¼â¢(A1)âˆ’Î¼â¢(An))=Î¼â¢(A1)âˆ’limnâ†’âˆÎ¼â¢(An),

    where we used the assumption Î¼â¢(A1)<âˆ for the third equality. The statement now follows from Î¼â¢((â‹‚nâˆˆâ„•An)c)=1âˆ’Î¼â¢(â‹‚nâˆˆâ„•An).

Proof of Proposition 2.1.2.

If f is measurable, then since â„°âŠ‚Ïƒâ¢(â„°)=â„¬â¢(â„) it holds that fâˆ’1â¢(â„°)âŠ‚â„¬â¢(â„). Conversely, suppose that fâˆ’1â¢(â„°)âŠ‚â„¬â¢(â„). Consider the family of sets

ğ’â‰”{Bâˆˆâ„¬â¢(â„):fâˆ’1â¢(B)âˆˆğ’œ}.

We claim that ğ’ is a Ïƒ-algebra over â„. Indeed,

  1. (i)

    â„âˆˆğ’ since fâˆ’1â¢(â„)=Eâˆˆğ’œ;

  2. (ii)

    if Bâˆˆğ’ then

    fâˆ’1â¢(Bc)=fâˆ’1â¢(â„)âˆ–fâˆ’1â¢(B)=â„âˆ–fâˆ’1â¢(B)âŸâˆˆğ’œâˆˆğ’œ,

    since the Ïƒ-algebra ğ’œ is closed under taking complements. It follows that Bcâˆˆğ’ as well;

    for a sequence (Bn)nâˆˆâ„•âŠ‚ğ’ we have

    fâˆ’1â¢(â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•Bn)=â‹ƒnâˆˆâ„•fâˆ’1â¢(Bn)âŸâˆˆğ’œâˆˆğ’œ,

    where the inclusion follows from Ïƒ-stability of a Ïƒ-algebra. Therefore, â‹ƒnBnâˆˆğ’.

We have shown that ğ’ is a Ïƒ-algebra and by definition of ğ’ we have â„°âŠ‚ğ’. Since Ïƒâ¢(â„°) is the smallest Ïƒ-algebra containing â„°, this entails â„¬â¢(â„)=Ïƒâ¢(â„°)âŠ‚ğ’ as desired. âˆ

Proof of Proposition 3.3.2.

Linearity is not obvious from the definition that we provide for the conditional expectation and requires a deeper measure theoretic understanding that is out of scope of this module. The tower property follows from the calculation

ğ”¼â¢[ğ”¼â¢[Xâˆ£Y]]=ğ”¼â¢[âˆ«â„xâ¢fXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£Y)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)] =âˆ«â„mâˆ«â„xâ¢fXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£y)â¢fXâ¢(x)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)â¢dÎ½â¢(y)
=âˆ«{fYâ‰ 0}âˆ«â„xâ¢fXâˆ£Yâ¢(xâˆ£y)â¢fYâ¢(y)âŸ=fX,Yâ¢(x,y)â¢Â onÂ â¢{y:fYâ¢(y)=0}â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)â¢dÎ½â¢(y)
=âˆ«â„m+1fX,Yâ¢(x,y)â¢dÎ¼âŠ—Î½â¢(x,y)
=1,

where we used a version of Fubiniâ€™s theorem for integrable functions, usually referred to as Tonelliâ€™s theorem (or often also Fubiniâ€“Tonelli theorem). Finally, if X and Y are independent we have â„™-a.s.

ğ”¼â¢[Xâˆ£Y]=âˆ«â„xâ¢fX,Yâ¢(x,Y)â=fXâ¢(x)â¢fYâ¢(Y)fYâ¢(Y)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)â¢ğŸ{fYâ¢(Y)â‰ 0}=âˆ«â„xâ¢fXâ¢(x)â¢dÎ¼â¢(x)=ğ”¼â¢[X],

where we used â„™â¢(fYâ¢(Y)=0)=âˆ«{y:fYâ¢(y)=0}fYâ¢(y)â¢dÎ½â¢(y)=0. âˆ

A.1 Borelâ€“Cantelli lemma

Let (Î©,â„±,â„™) be a probability space and (An)nâˆˆâ„•âŠ‚â„± be a sequence of events. We define

lim supnâ†’âˆAn =â‹‚n=1âˆâ‹ƒm=nâˆAm
={Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:âˆ€nâˆˆâ„•â¢âˆƒmâ‰¥nâ¢Â s.t.Â â¢Ï‰âˆˆAm}
={Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:Ï‰âˆˆAnâ¢Â for infinitely manyÂ â¢nâˆˆâ„•}.
Lemma A.1.1 (Borelâ€“Cantelli).

Let (Î©,â„±,â„™) be a probability space and (An)nâˆˆâ„•âŠ‚â„± be a sequence of events. Then,

âˆ‘n=1âˆâ„™â¢(An)<âˆâŸ¹â„™â¢(lim supnâ†’âˆAn)=0.
Proof.

Let Bn=â‹ƒmâ‰¥nAm. then, (Bn)n is decreasing, whence continuity of probability measures implies that

â„™â¢(lim supnâ†’âˆAn)=â„™â¢(â‹‚n=1âˆBn)=limnâ†’âˆâ„™â¢(Bn). (A.1)

Since by assumption âˆ‘n=1âˆâ„™â¢(An)<âˆ, we have limnâ†’âˆâˆ‘mâ‰¥nâ„™â¢(Am)=0. Monotonicity of probability measures gives

limnâ†’âˆâ„™â¢(Bn)â‰¤limnâ†’âˆâˆ‘mâ‰¥nâ„™â¢(Am)=0.

Plugging this into (A.1) yields the result. âˆ

This allows to prove Lemma 4.1.6.

Proof of Lemma 4.1.6.

Let

Î›:-{limnâ†’âˆYn=Y}.

We have to show that the given assumption implies â„™â¢(Î›)=0, or equivalently, â„™â¢(Î›c)=1. Noting that

Î›c={lim supn|Ynâˆ’Y|>0}=â‹ƒN=1âˆâ‹‚n=1âˆâ‹ƒmâ‰¥n{|Ynâˆ’Y|>1/N}=â‹ƒN=1âˆlim supnâ†’âˆ{|Ynâˆ’Y|>1/N},

continuity of probability measures gives

â„™â¢(Î›c)=limNâ†’âˆâ„™â¢(lim supnâ†’âˆ{|Ynâˆ’Y|>1/N}).

By assumption, for any Nâˆˆâ„• it holds that

âˆ‘n=1âˆâ„™â¢(|Ynâˆ’Y|>1/N)<âˆ,

so Borelâ€“Cantelli yields that for any Nâˆˆâ„•,

â„™â¢(lim supnâ†’âˆ{|Ynâˆ’Y|>1/N})=0.

This now implies â„™â¢(Î›c)=0, which finishes the proof. âˆ
